[Bàn]
AD = Ailean Dall ’ s Songs ( Orain , Marbhrannan , agus Duanagan Ghaidhealach Le Ailean Dughalach ) . 2nd ed . Inverness . 1829 .
AF = A . R . Forbes , Gaelic Names of Beasts etc . Edinburgh . 1905 .
AiD =Aithdioghluim Dána ( ed . L . McKenna ) . 2 vols . Irish Texts Society . 1939 , 1940 .
AMD ( 1751 ) = Alexander MacDonald ’ s Songs ( Ais - Eiridh na Sean - Chanoin Albannaich : no an nuadh Oranaiche Gaidhealach ) . Edinburgh . 1751 .
AMD ( 1924 ) = The Poems of Alexander MacDonald ( ed . Revs . A . and A . MacDonald ) . Inverness . 1924 .
AMD Voc , AMV = Alexander MacDonald , A Galick and English Vocabulary . Edinburgh . 1741 .
Arm = R . A . Armstrong , A Gaelic Dictionary . London . 1825 .
BGh = Bardachd Ghaidhlig ( ed . W . J . Watson ) . 3rd ed . Stirling . 1959 .
Bidrag = Carl J . S . Marstrander , Bidrag til det norske Sprogs Historie i Irland . Kristiania . 1915 .
BL = Bardachd Leodhais ( fo laimh Iain N . MacLeoid ) . Glaschu . 1916 .
BTh = Na Baird Thirisdeach ( ed . Rev . H . Cameron ) . Stirling . 1932 .
Calvin ’ s Catechism = Adtimchiol an Chreidimh ( ed . R . L . Thomson ) . Scottish Gaelic Texts Society . Edinburgh . 1962 .
Cameron = John Cameron , The Gaelic Names of Plants . Glasgow . 1900 .
Cnósach Focal ó Bhaile Bhúirne … Mícheál Ó Briain … a bhailig ( ed . Brian Ó Cuív ) . Dublin . 1947 .
Contrr = Kuno Meyer , Contributions to Irish Lexicography . Halle . 1906 .
CPNS = W . J . Watson , The History of the Celtic Place - Names of Scotland . Edinburgh . 1926 .
CR = The Celtic Review . 10 vols . Edinburgh . 1904 - 1916 .
DB = The Songs of Duncan Ban Macintyre ( ed . Angus MacLeod ) . Scottish Gaelic Texts Society . Edinburgh . 1952 .
Dieckhoff = H . C . Dieckhoff , A Pronouncing Dictionary of Scottish Gaelic . Edinburgh . 1932 .
DIG = Dàin Iain Ghobha ( ed . G . Henderson ) . 2 vols . Glasgow . 1893 , 1896 .
Dinn = P . S . Dinneen , An Irish - English Dictionary . New ed . Irish Texts Society . Dublin . 1927 .
DMcL = Donald MacLeod ’ s Songs ( Orain Nuadh Ghaeleach le Domhnul MacLeoid ) . Inverness . 1811 .
DSG = Deoch - slàinte nan Gillean : Orain a Barraidh ( ed . Colm Ó Lochlainn ) . Dublin . 1948 .
Duan ( aire ) = An Duanaire ( ed . Donald Macpherson ) . Edinburgh . 1868 .
Dw = Edward Dwelly , The Illustrated Gaelic Dictionary . Glasgow . 1941 .
E = The Eigg Collection of Gaelic Songs ( Comh - chruinneachidh Orannaigh Gaidhealach le Raonuill MacDomhnuill ) . Edinburgh . 1776 .
EIHM = T . F . O ’ Rahilly , Early Irish History and Mythology . Dublin . 1946 .
EL = J . L . Campbell and Derick Thomson , Edward Lhuyd in the Scottish Highlands 1699 - 1900 . Oxford . 1963 .

E . MacLachlan = Ewen MacLachlan ’ s Gaelic Verse . Comprising a translation of Homer ’ s Iliad , Books I - VIII , and original compositions ( ed . John MacDonald ) . Aberdeen University Studies . Inverness . 1937 .
Ét . Celt . = Études Celtiques . Vols . i - . Paris . 1936 - .
Fr . Allan = Gaelic Words and Expressions from South Uist and Eriskay ( coll . Rev . Fr . Allan McDonald ; ed . J . L . Campbell ) . Dublin . 1958 .
G = Gillies ’ Collection ( Sean Dain agus Orain Ghaidhealach ) . Edited and published by John Gillies . Perth . 1786 .
GB = The Gaelic Bards ( ed . Rev . A . Maclean Sinclair ) . 4 vols . Charlottetown , P . E . I . 1890 , 1892 ; Sydney , C . B . 1896 , 1904 .
Gill . Caimbeul = Orain le Gilleasbuig Caimbeul , aig Ceann - Loch - Earn . Edinburgh . 1851 .
Gill - easbuig Grannda = Dain agus Orain , le Gilleasbuig Grannda , Bard Ghlinnemorasdain . Inverness . 1863 .
GlenB = Comhchruinneachadh Ghlinn - a ’ - Bhaird : The Glenbard collection of Gaelic Poetry ( ed . Rev . A . Maclean Sinclair ) . Charlottetown . 1890 .
Hessen = Hessens Irisches Lexikon . 2 vols . Halle . 1933 - 1938 .
MacLeods = I . F . Grant , The MacLeods : The History of a Clan 1200 - 1956 . London . 1959 .
HM = The Highland Monthly . 5 vols . Inverness . 1889 - 1893 .
Holmer = Nils M . Holmer , Studies on Argyllshire Gaelic . Uppsala . 1938 .
HP = Highland Papers ( ed . J . R . N . MacPhail ) . 4 vols . Scottish History Society . Edinburgh . 1914 , 1916 , 1920 , 1934 .
HSD =The Highland Society ’ s Dictionary . 2 vols . Edinburgh . 1828 .
HS ’ 45 = Highland Songs of the Forty - Five ( ed . J . L . Campbell ) . Edinburgh . 1933 .
IL = Orain le Iain Lom Mac - Dhomhnaill ( ed . Rev . A . Maclean Sinclair ) . Antigonish . 1895 .
JMC= The Songs of John MacCodrum ( ed . William Matheson ) . Scottish Gaelic Texts Society . Edinburgh . 1938 .
Kenneth MacKenzie = Orain Ghaidhealach … le Coinneach Mac Coinnich . Edinburgh . 1792 .
Leabhar Sheáin Í Chonaill ( ed . J . H . Delargy ) . [Dublin . ] 1948 .
LG = Leabhar nan Gleann ( ed . G . Henderson ) . Edinburgh . 1898 .
MacL , Maclennan = Malcolm Maclennan , A Pronouncing and Etymological Dictionary of the Gaelic Language . Edinburgh . 1925 .
Mary Macpherson = Dain agus Orain Ghàidhlig le Mairi Nic - a - phearsoin ( ed . Alexander MacBain ) . Inverness . 1891 .
MB = MacDonald Bards ( ed . K . N . MacDonald ) . Edinburgh . 1900 .
MC = The MacDonald Collection of Gaelic Poetry ( ed . Revs . A . and A . MacDonald ) . Inverness . 1911 .
McA , MacAlpine = Neil M ‘ Alpine , A Pronouncing Gaelic Dictionary .
McB = Alexander MacBain , An Etymological Dictionary of the Gaelic Language . Inverness . 1896 .
MTT = MacTalla nan Tur ( ed . Rev . A . Maclean Sinclair ) . Sydney , C . B . 1901 .
MWHT = More West Highland Tales ( ed . J . G . Mackay and others ) . 2 vols . Edinburgh . 1940 , 1960 .
NGP = A Collection of Gaelic Proverbs and Familiar Phrases ( ed . Alexander Nicolson ) . Edinburgh . 1881 .
NGR = Gaelic Riddles and Enigmas ( ed . Alexander Nicolson ) . Glasgow . n . d . [c . 1938 . ]
NICS = G . Henderson , The Norse Influence on Celtic Scotland . Glasgow . 1910 .
OL =Orain Luaidh Màiri nighean Alasdair ( ed . K . C . Craig ) . Glasgow . 1949 .
Or = An t - Oranaiche ( ed . and pub . Archibald Sinclair ) . Glasgow . 1879 .
OT = Duncan Macvean ’ s Collection of Songs ( Co - chruinneachadh de dh ’ Oranan Taoghta ) . Glasgow . 1836 .
PB = The Poetry of Badenoch ( ed . Rev . T . Sinton ) . Inverness . 1906 .
PSAS = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland . Vols . i - . Edinburgh . 1855 - .
RD = Songs and Poems of Rob Donn ( ed . Hew Morrison ) . Edinburgh . 1899 .
Rel . Celt . = Reliquiae Celticae ( Rev . Alexander Cameron ; ed . Alexander MacBain and Rev . John Kennedy ) . Inverness . 1892 , 1894 .
RG = Rosg Gaidhlig ( ed . W . J . Watson ) . 2nd ed . Glasgow . 1929 .
RIA Contrr = Contributions to a Dictionary of the Irish Language . Royal Irish Academy . Dublin . 1942 - 1964 .
RIA Dict = Dictionary of the Irish Language . Royal Irish Academy . Dublin . 1913 - 1957 .
S = Stewarts ’ Collection ( Cochruinneacha Taoghta de Shaothair nam Bard Gaeleach ) ( ed . A . and D . Stewart ) . Edinburgh . 1804 .
SCR = The Scottish Celtic Review . I vol . Glasgow . 1881 - 1885 .
SD = Sgialachdan Dhunnchaidh ( ed . K . C . Craig ) . Glasgow . n . d .
SGS = Scottish Gaelic Studies . Vols . i - . Celtic Department of the University of Aberdeen . Oxford . 1926 - .
SHR = The Scottish Historical Review . Vols . i - . Edinburgh . 1903 - .
SO = Sar - Obair nam Bard Gaelach : The Beauties of Gaelic Poetry ( ed . John MacKenzie ) . John Grant . Edinburgh . 1907 .
SVDL = Scottish Verse from the Book of the Dean of Lismore ( ed . W . J . Watson ) . Scottish Gaelic Texts Society . Edinburgh . 1937 .
T = Turner ’ s Collection ( Comhchruinneacha do dh ’ Orain Taghta Ghàidhealach le Paruig Mac - an - Tuairneir ) . Edinburgh . 1813 .
TGSI = Transactions of the Gaelic Society of Inverness . Vols . i - . Inverness . 1871 - .
Tolmie = Frances Tolmie ’ s Collection of Gaelic Songs ( Journal of the Folk - song Society No . 16 ) . London . 1911 .
UB = Uist Bards ( ed . Rev . A . MacDonald ) . Glasgow . 1894 .
WHT = Popular Tales of the West Highlands ( ed . J . F . Campbell ) . 4 vols . 2nd ed . Paisley . 1890 - 1893 .
WR = Poems and Songs by William Ross ( Orain Ghàelach le Uilleam Ros ) ( ed . John MacKenzie ) . 3rd ed . Edinburgh . 1868 .
ZCP = Zeitschrift für celtische Philologie . Vols . i - . Halle . 1899 - .
Zoëga = Geir Tómasson Zoëga , A Concise Dictionary of Old Icelandic . Oxford . 1910 .

E , Eng . = English
E . Ir . = Early Irish
Fr . = French
Ir . = Irish
L , Lat . = Latin
M . Eng . = Middle English
Mod . Ir . = Modern Irish
OE = Old English
ON = Old Norse
OS = Old Style
Sc . = Scots
v . n . = verbal noun
W = Welsh

A bhuile bhù .
An exclamation . Fr . voulez - vous ? [Unlikely . Perhaps from A Mhuire bhùidh ? ]

aban .
A backwater . [Cf . àban ,
a backwater ; Watson , Prints of the Past around Inverness , 2nd ed . , p . 47 . Cf . abdan , Contrr ? ]

abhsadh .
See allsadh .

acainn leighis .
See spreaghan .

acrachan .
See gadmann .

adharcag .
Lapwing . The people believed that the eggs of the lapwing produced fertility . [adaircín , Contrr . ]

aghasach . Boireannach aghasach ,
a forward , impertinent woman . [Cf . aghach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

aibeoil . An aibeoil ,
an illness to which cattle , especially young cattle , are liable . A straw rope twisted sunwise and rolled round the body of the animal is used to counteract this illness .
aileach , faileach ( f . ) . A print , impression , as of a foot .

ailmeid .
Green dye of boiled heather tops and alum .

ailte mòine = amhailte mhòine .
A burning peat . [= athailte ( with initial vowel nasal ) . Cf . aithinne . ]

aimeist ( ? ) , ainneist .
Kine , cattle . See aineist .

àine .
Beauty , splendour , gladness . [See fàine , fàin , fàn . From àn ,
bright , brilliant , as in àine an latha ,
when the sun is at its height ( cf . Mur àin ’ an la ,
S , 284 ) . See O ’ Rahilly , EIHM , 286 - 307 ; Vendryes , Lexique Étymologique , A - 72 . ]

aineist , ainneist .
Kine , cattle , flocks . See aimeist .

aingeal .
Angel . See comain .

aingeal .
Without feeling in hand or in foot or any part of the person from cold . Tha mo chasan anns an aingealdaich ,
my feet are benumbed with cold . [In Lewis , tha neulaich ’ na mo làmhan .
In N . Uist an aighealaich ,
with the initial vowel nasalised and pronounced è . aingealaich ( S . Uist ) , iongallach ( Moidart ) . Cf . nialach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

airgead .
See cnò .

ais , aisean .
Steep place , steep precipice .

aisir , aisirean .
Lump .

aiteal , faiteal .
Slight , frail . [Doubtful if this is an adj . Cf . aiteal ,
a lull , a slight breeze , Fr . Allan . The more common meaning is ‘ a gleam , bright colour ’ , cf . mar aiteal nan caor ,
AD , 57 ; … nan ros ,
id . , 139 . ]

alabhar .
Almanack . [alamar ,
Gairloch . ]

alaire , alair , ealaire .
Funeral , funeral entertainment . [falairidh , falaraidh ( cf . Fr . Allan ) , lykewake . Dissimilated forms of forair ( for + aire ) . ]

alla . Alla gach dùil bheòtha ,
the Chief of all things living . Alla nan alla ( Skye ) , God of the gods , Chief of the chiefs . See s . v . carran .

alla .
Knowledge . Thubhairt an té a bha falamh / chan alla dhomh e . [But see the following word . ]

alladh , alla .
Fame , good or bad .

’ S ann a thogadh orm alla , [chuir iad orm , dh ’ fhàg
Bho nach robh mi aig baile , iad mar
Gun d ’ fhàg mi gun anam
Mo charaide féin .
Glas - làmh agus chas orm ,
’ S mo riasladh aig eachaibh ,
Ma loisg mi riamh saighead
Air an lasgaire threun .

allail .
Famous , noble , beauteous .

C ’ àit an d ’ fhàg thu ’ n t - àrmann allail ,
Mac ’ ic Alasdair nam mór - fhear ? [ - ghnìomh
Dh ’ fhàg mi e air sgeir mhara
’ S fhuil gu frasach air an rò - shruth .

Where did you leave the illustrious hero , Glengarry of the great men ? I left him upon a sea - rock and his blood in showers upon the current .
[Refers to Angus MacDonell , younger of Glengarry , who was killed by the MacKenzies at the Cailleach Rock in 1602 ? ]

allsadh , abhsadh . Allsadh a ’ chromain - luch ,
‘ the down - hauling of the kestrel ’ , applied to the clumsy slackening of the sail with a jerk . [ ON hálsa segl , to clew up the sail . Abhsadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

altradh .
Rearing , upbringing , akin to altrum ,
rearing , nourishing , and to altaich = neartaich . [But for the latter word cf . , perhaps , altaich , altraich ,
to make the joints supple . Cuir a mach an crodh ged nach dèanadh iad dad ach gun altraicheadh iad an cnàmhan ,
Lewis . ]

altrap , altrapadh , ealtrap , ealtrapadh .
Accident , mishap , misfortune . [alltrapadh ( Benbecula ) ; anntapadh ( Lewis ) ; all - tapadh ( McB . ) ; ealtradh ( s . v . iubhar ) . ]

amh .
See famh .

amhailte .
See ailte .

amhas ( Mull and Morvern ) ; amhasan ; annsadh , ausa ( Loch Fyne ) . One of the names of the gannet or solan goose . It is an incredibly gluttonous bird . Some years ago a boat was fishing near the island of Troday , off Trotternish in Skye . A few herring lay on the bottom planks . A gannet dived at these with such violence that it drove its

powerful beak to the base through the planks , making a hole which had to be plugged . At one time the gannet was used for food in the Isles . It was customary , old men told me , to sink in the sea a thick board with a herring fixed to its face . The gannet swooped at the herring with such force as to kill itself against the board . [Cf . Onnsa ,
the nickname of a Pabbay man ; Henderson , LG , 85 . ]

àn , àna , àin , àine ,
pl . ànan , ànann , àinean .
Liver , fish liver , oil , grease , suet , fat , butter . Cha dèan corrag mhilis àn , cha dèan glàm càise ,
sweet finger will not make butter , nor will glutton cheese .

Thig , a storrach , thig !
Thig , a storrach , thig !
Àn gu uileann ,
Blàthach gu dorna ,
Thig , a storrach , thig !

Loch Ciarain àna Cinn Tìre , Loch Fìne àn Earra - Ghàidheal ,
Loch Ciarain , the liver of Kintyre , Loch Fyne , the liver of Argyll . Tìr chràdach ( ? ) Choille Nàis , àna Mhuc Arna , Tìr riadach / ritheadach Mhuc Arna , àna Latharna ,
the teazel ( ? ) land of Coille Nàis , the liver of Muckairn , the nowt / cattle land of Muckairn , the liver of Lorne . Another form says , Coille Nàis àna Mhuc Arna , Tìr mhine àna Latharna ,
Coille Nàis the liver of Muckairn , meal land the liver of Lorne . [There is no mark of length in the MS . , but if these are syncopated forms of adhanna ( n ) ,
pl . of adha ,
liver , then the initial vowel is long . ]

an .
Rich , fat . Muir an ,
rich sea . Loch an ,
rich loch . Talamh an ,
rich land .

Is iomadh dìth agus tàir
An dàil muir an an domhain .

[There is no mark of length in the MS . , although the couplet quoted might suggest the vowel is long . But if connected with Early Irish anae , ‘ richesse , prospérité ’ the vowel should be short ; Vendryes , Lexique Étymologique , A - 72 . ]

àn .
Beautiful , splendid , gladsome . See àine .

àn , àine .
Wisdom , knowledge .

anagladh , anacladh .
Rear , nurture , bring up ; nurse , nursemaid , maid , maiden , handmaid , bondmaid .

Dèan do leanabh anagladh
Le marrum / bainne chur ’ na ghob ,
Le chur ’ na laighe bog blàth
Gun am barr / cé a thoir dhe chuid .

[E . Ir . anacul , protecting . Cf . E ga d ’ anacladh o phiantaibh bàis ,
S , 232 ; Aon mhac De ga d ’ anacladh ,
id . , 233 ; Aingil naobha Mhic Dhe / ’ Bhi mar sgeith dhuit ga t ’ anagladh ,
GB , ii , 17 . ]

anaid , ainid .
Heifer cow . [Cf . ainmhide ,
a heifer ( Sutherland ) , TGSI , xxv , 120 ; ainbhte ( West Ross ) , TGSI , xxiv , 353 . ]

anainn .
See stéill .

anart .
See lìon - anairt .

annlan .
See coidhean .

annraisd .
See ionnrais .

annsadh .
See amhas .

antìd .
See cambar .

aon - bhualach ,
one striker ; aon - ghuthach ,
one - voiced . These are terms applied to the woman who strikes up the air of the song at the waulking - frame . She is selected by the waulking - women present and all look to her for guidance in voicing the air of the song .

arabocan .
Lintel of door ( Uist ) .

àrach . Cha robh àrach agam air ,
I was not responsible , I could not help it . Cha robh àrach aige air a sin ,
he could not help that . Tha iad ag àrach orm ,
they are charging me . [The general meaning of àrach is ‘ blame ’ . See Éigse , vi , 59 - 60 . See also Fr . Allan . ]

àrc .
Water - passage of cow or animal of cow kind . A waterfall on the south shoulder of Cruachan is called Arc Eas Bheann ,
the àrc of the waterfall of the peaks . [àrc ,
vulva vaccinea , Dw . ]

àrna Moire .
See cnò .

arrais .
Wicked , wicked one , probably the same as dearrais ,
wicked , venom , venomous , serpent .

asc [asg] .
Snake , adder , serpent .

asgart .
Coarse cordage , the refuse of flax and hemp . In Perthshire the husks of the hemp heckled off the thread ; was used to spread over thatch as it had a clinging nature and was not readily blown off .

Bhiodh do mhìolchoin air astar
Air asgart ’ s air éill ,
’ S to triall chun a ’ mhonaidh ,
’ S cuid dhiùbh romhad ’ s ad dhéidh .

[E . Ir . escart , tow ; refuse , offscourings . Also used of small unusable potatoes , etc . in Lewis . asgartach lìn :
BGh , l . 4596 . ]

at - cìche .
See fiar - fà .

àthadh .
Working in the kiln or àth .
In Uist the àth and the barn are inseparable , for in every little barn there is a small kiln ; hence barn and kiln are almost synonymous . [In Uist the initial vowel of àth is nasalised . Cf . àmh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

athaidh .
In the phrase am beul an athaidh ’ s an anamoich ,
at the mouth of dusk and of lateness . [Precise meaning uncertain . Cf . E . Ir . athach , athaid , athaig , interval of space or time ? See Vols . iii , 154 ; v , 132 ; WHT ( 2nd ed . ) i , 14 , 16 , 18 ; ii , 476 , 478 ; Waifs and Strays , iv , 257 . ]

athailt .
Mark , as of a foot in mud , sand or anything soft or impressionable . [Also ‘ scar ’ . ]

athais .
Secret . Athais dealain ,
telegraph . [ ? ] [Cf . aithisg ,
report , etc . Dw . ]

atharais , atharrais .
Think , ruminate , rehearse in the mind . [Usually ‘ imitate , mimic ’ . ]

atharla , arla , arlu .
A cow , heifer , heifer of first gestation , of first calf .

atharrach . Tha each a sin gun atharrach ,
there is a horse there of a verity . [Gun atharrachadh = just so , exactly ( Uist ) . ]

athonach .
Doubt , second opinion .

ausa .
See amhas .

babhd .
See sabhd .

bà - chaorain = sgàinteag . [Cf . bàchar ,
a beech mast , an acorn . Cnò bhàchair ,
mimosa scandens , … the Molucca bean , HSD . ]

baca .
A bank . [ ON bakki , a bank . ]

bac - cliabh .
A small creel . [In Lewis bachliabh ,
for baccliabh ,
a small creel in which , e . g . , Point women carried their messages from Stornoway . ]

bàchain .
See cnò .

bachall .
A useless thing , as bachall bròig ,
a useless shoe ; bachall boireannaich ( or bachallach ) , a useless , slipshod woman ; bachall duine ,
a lout , a slow , lazy fellow . [Sc . bauchle , an old shoe . ]

badadh .
The act of plucking bits of ripe corn , leaving the rest to ripen ; plucking wool off sheep . [See badadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

badhal .
Wandering , hence wandering of wits , insanity . Dar théid an gobha air bhadhal , théid e buileach ann ,
when the smith goes insane he goes there completely . Dar théid an gobha air bhadhal is fearr a bhith réidh ris ,
when the smith goes insane it is best to be at peace with him . [Cf . Aithneachadh bó badhail ,
NGP , 8 ; coin bhadhail ,
id . , 384 ; aoir bhadhail ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 320 ; ’ Se donnal a choin bhadhail ud / Dh ’ fhàg bodhar mo dha chluais ,
MTT , 30 . See also GB , i , 184 ; Glen B , 157 . ]

bàirneach . ‘ Air sealbh bhàirneach ! ’
‘ For abundance of limpets ! ’ said Iain Bàn , aged eighty - two , throwing the ord bhàirneach ,
limpet - hammer , behind him . This was the way to get fish and shell - fish the next day . See cladach .

bàirnich nan stuagh .
The crests of the waves ( Uist , Mull ) . [Cf . bàirneach na stròine ,
Fr . Allan . ]

balachd = cleasachd .
Playfulness ; probably from balach ,
a youth . [Perhaps rather a short form of ballachd - bùird ( cf . SD , 27 , 35 , 51 ) , and therefore ballachd .
Cf . balachd ,
Fr . Allan . ]

balagh , baladh .
Profit , benefit , bounty , advantage . [A misreading of soladh ,
profit ? ]

balc .
A satire .

Duine balcach breun ,
Cha niarachd a théid fo theangaidh .

[A guess ? Cf . bailc ,
defiance ; bailceach ,
proud , HSD . ]

balg - abhrais .
Bag for holding wool oiled and prepared for spinning . [See abhras balg ,
Fr . Allan . See also MWHT ii , 366 n . 2 . ‘ Blàthaich do làmh ’ nad abhras ’ ,
‘ Warm your hand in the oiled wool ’ , said by a lazy young wife when she threw difficult bits of wool into the fire so as to keep pace with her mother - in - law . ]

balg - buill .
Ball bag , the bag in which the witches kept and carried their worsted balls for raising storms . There are many graphic stories told of these witches when they threw out their worsted balls and raised storms and drowned enemies . The best known in Argyll is when Gormshuil [Gormal] Mhór na Moighe , at the bidding of the Lady of Duart , raised a storm and sank the Spanish ship at anchor in Tobermory Bay . Maclean of Duart , like many more men of Mull and Morvern , visited the Spanish ship of war at Tobermory . The Lady of Duart heard that her lord was dallying with the royal princess Viola on board . She sent for her confidante Gormshuil [Gormal] Mhór , who threw out the worsted balls and raised a storm and sank the ship , drowning all aboard save a few favourite friends of the witch . The body of the princess was recovered and buried in the beautiful burial - place of Kilchoan . [Another account states that she was buried in Kilcolumbkill , Morvern . — MacLeod , Reminiscences of a Highland Parish , 2nd ed . , 55 . ]

balg - càirein .
Gumboil .

balg - sìdh .
A fairy bag , a bag in which fairies keep good things for those they love .

balg - solais .
Satchel , literally ‘ bag of enlightenment ’ , because it carries books . [Mistake for balg - solair ? ]

balgan - béiste .
A small globular growth with an insect inside . This was kept and when a cow swallowed an insect this was put in water and a little of that water was sprinkled upon the cow .

ball - seirc .
See breac - seirc .

ball - taobh .
See biast - mhaol .

ballaire - bòdhar .
Speckled loon . See bialaire - bòthan , bura - bhuachaill . [Cf ballaire - bòdhain / bòthain ,
cormorant . ]

ballan - buaile .
The tub slung on a pole in which milkmaids carry home the milk from the fold to the house . In carrying home the ballan - buaile they keep step and to aid them in this they sing a milking march . [ballan ,
a tub with two ears , Fr . Allan . ]

bànag .
See gealag , samhnachan .

banas .
See brioghas .

baobach , baobach boireannaich .
The female equivalent of trusdar , trusdar duine . Baobach ort !
an imprecation . See tapag .

baosg , baosgan , baosgair .
A foolish man . baosgaid , baosgag .
A foolish woman , silly woman . baosgaideach .
Foolish person , harum - scarum , disorderly .

barr - feall .
See uanallach ; caora .

barr meodhail .
Full talk , full conversation . [See meadhail , meobhail , meodhail ,
Fr . Allan . meadhair . ]

barragal , barraisgeal .
Proud , conceited . [Cf . bàirisgeach ,
JMC , l . 903 and Glossary ; leig seachad do chuid bàrasglaich ,
Mary Macpherson , 11 ; TGSI , xxiii , 84 ; bàrraisg ,
boaster , braggadocio , Dw . ]

barran .
Linen band tied round a child ’ s head from birth . In some places , crosgaileit , crosgalait ,
q . v . [barran ,
a cap , or covering of the head with a handkerchief or shawl , Fr . Allan . ]

bàsdag .
A woman in a dying condition . bàsdan .
A man in a dying condition .

bata .
A staff . According to the staff the herdsman or boy carried , so it fared with the cows he herded —

Bata daraich , dàiridh crodh , [dàir air a ’ chrodh
Bata beithe , beiridh crodh ,
Bata calltainn , call air chrodh , [calltar
Bata caorrainn , caoil air chrodh . [caon ; caontar

bata goirealaich .
See goirealach .

bàta .
See nasg .

beall .
Flameless glowing fire , smokeless fire ; diminutive beallag . Beall is applied to the sun when distinct and glowing , as beall na gréine ,
the glow of the sun , beall beannaichte na gréine ,
the blessed glow of the sun .

bean - bàireach , bean - faire , bean - fhaireadh - tuill .
Terms for ‘ midwife ’ in use among tinkers . [Other terms for ‘ midwife ’ are : bean - ghlùin ; bean - asaid ; bean - chobhair ; bean - chomain ; bean - chomhnadh , bean - chonganta ; bean - choimheadaidh ; bean - shiùla ; bramach / bromach - inilt , brannach / bronnach - inilt . ] See glùn . [See siùbhla or siùla ,
Fr . Allan . ]

beannach . [Horned or pointed . ] See caora bheannach . [beannach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

beannachd Samhna .
See Samhain .

beannag .
( See bréid . ) A small shawl worn by women in Uist , sometimes on the shoulders and sometimes on the head . It is formed into a triangle . If not made on purpose the square is doubled into a triangle . The two ends are tied below the chin , the other corner falling down behind the head . On each side of the eyes the kerchief is folded neatly and in a becoming manner — a frequent headgear among Uist women , especially at outdoor work . In the early half of the nineteenth century all young women in Uist put up the beannag on the morning of their wedding . This was of white linen formed into thin broad bands or hems from the forehead to the crown of the head . It was pretty and becoming . This was the badge of marriage ( see bréid ) . Now the ring on the finger has taken the place of the beannag and the matron is not so easily distinguishable from the maidens , at which the girls murmur . [A ’ bheannag bheag

was the corner of the shawl turned down and put straight across the shoulders , the opposite corner hanging down the back . A ’ bheannag mhór ,
the rest of the shawl ( Lewis ) . ]

beanntag .
A three - cornered corn - fan , from beann ,
a horn , peak . See fasnag and guit . A tray formed of a hoop , c . 18 - 20 inches in diameter . A partially dressed sheepskin is fixed to this hoop . This fan is used for fanning grain where fanners are not available . Of old the beanntag was triangular , hence the name . Anything of three sides , anything with corners . Air a cheithir beanntagaibh ,
on its four corners . Leigeadh am blai - lìn a nuas air a cheithir beanntagaibh ,
the linen sheet was laid down upon its four corners . [air a cheithir bheannagan ,
Lewis . ]

beanntagach .
See bréid .

beinn .
See stuagh .

beinnteal .
A snare for birds . [Cf . peinnteal . See paighisteal ,
Fr . Allan . E . Ir . paintér , paintél , snare , trap obsol . Eng . panter , net , snare . Cf . col ( comhla ) a ’ bhigein = Lewis bùthach ,
TGSI , xxxvii , 32 . ]

beirteachadh .
See mulchag bheirteachaidh .

beithe .
Birch . Birch leaves make an excellent hair - wash and are used in Kintail for this purpose .

beòshlainte .
Living , good or bad . Is math beòshlaint ’ a ’ mhanaich , olc no math aig a ’ chléireach ,
good living has the monk , be it bad or good with the cleric . Is math beòshlaint ’ an t - sagairt ’ s gun deò an anam a ’ chléirich ,
good living has the priest and the breath not in the soul of the cleric . [cléireach should here be translated ‘ clerk ’ . Cf . the proverb
‘ Cha ’ n fhiach sagart gun chléireach ’ .
— A priest is nothing without a clerk . ( NGP , 119 . ) The reference is to the parish clerk , who assisted the priest in some of the latter ’ s duties . ( See further Wigtownshire Charters ( S . H . S . ) , 153 ff . ; Essays on the Scottish Reformation , 93 - 95 . ) The clerk had custody of the aspersorium ( sprinkler ) and the amphora for holy water , and his office was often hereditary . ( See an instrument , dated 15th July , 1548 , appointing as parish clerk of Sanquhar Thomas Clerk , son of Edward Clerk , the previous incumbent . — Wilson , Folklore and Genealogies of Uppermost Nithsdale , 250 - 251 . ) Similarly , in Ness , Lewis , when the mentally deranged resorted to Teampull Mo - lughaidh ,
there to be sprinkled with holy water , the stone cup in which it was brought from St Ronan ’ s Well was in the custody of a family who were descended from ‘ the clerk of the temple ’ ( cléireach an teampuill ) , which suggests that the office had been hereditary ( PSAS iv ( 1863 ) , 268 ) . There are various other sayings apparently referring to the poverty of the clerk in comparison with the priest . ‘ Is miann leis a ’ chléireach mias mhèith ’ bhi aig an t - sagart . ’
— A fat dish to the priest is the clerk ’ s wish . ( NGP , 275 . ) ( The reason was perhaps that there would then be some hope of adequate leavings for himself . ) ‘ Cho fuar ri màthair a ’ chléirich . ’
— As cold as the beadle ’ s ( recte clerk ’ s ) mother . ( NGP , 140 , where the explanation given is unconvincing . ) A variant ( not given

in NGP ) is
‘ Cho fuar ri càl a ’ chléirich ’ .
— As cold as the clerk ’ s kail . ( The idea may be that the priest had to be provided for first . ) After the Reformation the term cléireach continued in use among Protestants in the Highlands in the sense of beadle or church officer . ]

beulaiche , bialaiche , beòlaiche , beulanach , bialanach , beolanach .
A speaker , talker , narrator , newsmonger . beulum , bialum , beòlum .
A smooth - tongued person , a tale - teller . beulaireachd .
A contest of wit between two poets . beulaisg , bialaisg .
Loquacious , open - mouthed [person ? ] .

Cha robh Nollaig Mhór gun fheòil ,
Cha robh beòlanach gun tlachd ,
Cha robh còisir òg gun cheòl ,
Cha robh bean d ’ a deòin gun mhac .

biadhag .
See gruaigean .

biadhtach .
See biatach .

bial - bristidh .
See lacha - liath .

bial na h - oidhche .
See uchd .

bialaire - bòthan .
Cormorant . See ballaire - bòdhan .

biast - mhaol .
A seal .

Cha deach mi riamh an cuan seo
Gun bhall - taobh ’ s gun taod - guailne ,
Gun trì chupaill chaola chruaidhe ,
’ S gun an rac bhith sàs ’ s a ’ bhuanaich . [leg . bhuaraich
Nàile bhi ’ s na hó ró

Cha do rinn mi beud no pudhar
Mar do mharbh mi fiadh am bruthach ,
No biast - mhaol an caolas cumhang ,
No dubh - sgarbh air calg an rubha .
Nàile bhi ’ s na hó ró

[See rac . This is from the Iorram Dharaich composed by one of the Morisons of Ness about the end of the sixteenth century , in which he expresses his hatred , and possibly fear , of the famous Neil MacLeod , bastard son of Roderick MacLeod , the last Lord of Lewis . Was executed at Edinburgh in 1613 . The chorus in other versions runs Nèill , a mhic ’ s na hó ró .
See Eilean Fraoich , pp . 30 - 32 . ]

biatach , biadhtach .
Glutton .
Fear a bha dol seachad aig Bac am Barraidh agus chunn e gille ag itheadh dhiasan seagail agus thuirt e —

A man was passing Back in Barra and he saw a lad eating ears of rye and he said : ‘ Are you not the glutton for eating the ears ! ’ ‘ The One who created the ears , may he take from thee thy teeth before the end of a year and a day ! ’ The boy ’ s retort pleased the man so well that he took him with him to Orkney and his descendants are still there . He was known as boc Thangasdail ,
the buck of Tangasdal !

[biatach ,
feeder , purveyor , supplier , Fr . Allan . ]

bilisteir .
Busybody . [piliostar ,
what sticks to the side of the vessel when milk has been in it a long time ( Uist and Lewis ) . pileistreadh ,
rancidness , Dw . peileastair in Lewis is an annoying urchin ; pealastair in N . Uist . ]

bìn , binid .
Rennet , curd . bainne bìn , bainne binndichte , bainne binid . [binideachadh , binndich , minid , pinndich ,
Fr . Allan . People used to make binid by putting half a cup of warm milk per day in a calf ’ s stomach . ]

binneal = cuman .
Milk - vessel . binneal binndichidh ,

biolair Moire .
Water cress .

bionach , bionnach .

bior - gràbhainn .

biorach .

A bird flitting about from place to place . Nach tu am biorsaiche ,

The end of a corn - stalk bearing the seed ; the end of the seed attached to the ear . [ ? Cf . Tha cùl as a Niseach is bith as a Rubhach ( bith ,

bìth .

biteal .

blai - lìn .

blàinteag .
A lullaby , a crooning song sung to soothe children and especially cows when being milked . blàinteagan bleoghain ,
the milking melodies common at one time among the Isles people and still to some extents The cows will not give milk without them , which makes cow - buyers from the Mainland reduce their prices for Island cows and reluctant to take them . [There is no mark of length in the MS . , but it seems to be a syncopated form of bleoghainteag ,
and if so the vowel must be long . ]

blàr cathaich .
Battle plain . The knoll where the blackcocks fight each year for the hens , as the stags for the hinds . They fight so fiercely that their feathers fly about and cover the ground , and blood sprinkles the

bleidir .

blianan = blianag .
A smooth green grassy plain amid rough herbage ; a field for games . [See màthair - tala . blian ,
Fr . Allan . ]

bloinigein . Lus a ’ fàs an sùgh an todhair , an tiùrr an làin ; dath glas air ; stamagach .
A plant growing in the liquid of the sea - ware , in the heap left by the high tide ; has a grey hue ; medicinal .
bòchaidh . [ ? ]

bòchain .

bochd .
Poor . trì buichd ,
three paupers . [A noteworthy inflexion . ]

bodach .
Carle , sometimes derisive . Cha leiginn urram an dorais do bhodach tha beò ,
I would not allow the honour of the door to a carle alive . Also a monk , an unfruitful man , the counterpart of cailleach ,
a nun , an unfruitful woman . Bodach bàn = white friar . Bodach glas = grey friar . Bodach dubh = black friar . Cailleach dhubh = black nun . Cailleach gheal = white nun . Cailleach chràbhaidh = praying nun , nun of a close order . [Also ‘ a changeling ’ , Fr . Allan . ]

bodha .
See bristeadh - bodha .

bodha sionn .
See sionn .

bòdhag .
See brollach - bòdhaig ; tàsg ; trotag - thràghad .

bogha muc / mucag .
See brocan .

bòichioll .
Daft , outrageous . [There is no mark of length in the MS . , but it is perhaps bàth , baoth + ciall . ]

boil .
A disease peculiar to horses and to which running horses are more liable than working horses . There are three kinds , boil fhiadhaich ,
wild boil ; boil chabhagach ,
hurried boil ; and boil chadalach ,
sleepy boil . In the boil fhiadhaich the animal becomes mad and dies in about twenty - four hours . The boil chabhagach is slower and the animal may last a week or two or even three weeks . In the boil chadalach the animal starts nodding , inclining to fall forward , and then suddenly pulls up . Horses grazing on sandy soil are liable to the boil .
Uist generally is bad for the boil ,
especially the islands of Illeray , Kirkibost and Vallay .

boinneag [buinneag] .
See sealbhag .

boitean .
See broc ; dloighidh .

bolgach .
Smallpox . bolgach bhog .
Swinepox .

bollta ,
pl . bolltaichean .
A bolt ( English ) . [Used especially for the iron pins which pass through each side of the box of a cart and through the axle . bobhta ,
Fr . Allan . ]

bonnach - boise = deàrnagan .
A small bannock prepared on the palm of the hand , deàrna na boise . [It was not baked on a griddle but standing to the fire , ri golag , ri toll ,
i . e . , a peat is removed from the front of the fire to open a way to the red - hot heart of the fire . bonnach boise ,
Fr . Allan . ]

bonnach - gropaidh .
Livers of fish and oatmeal baked into a bannock . ceann gropaidh ,
‘ crappit heid ’ , fish livers and oatmeal boiled together in a fish ’ s head , nourishing and sustaining food . [Also ceann - cropaig , ceann - propaig . ]

bonntach , bunntach , bonntadh .
Foundation . bonntachadh , bunntachadh , bonntaigh .
Farm steading , the whole farm . bonntach math ,
good foundation . bonntachadh math ,
good farmstead , good homestead , good possession , good occupancy .

bòrlanachd , bòrlandachd , mòrlannachd .
Besides the càin of the sheep , the hens and the eggs , the people had to give so many days ’ work . This was called bòrlandachd or mòrlannachd ,
the whole being termed caraiste or cairiste ( q . v . ) . The latter term , however , denoted the labour exacted from the tenant of the fear - baile ,
tacksman , rather than that exacted by the tighearna ,
lord , laird . The man had to give seven days ’ free labour in spring , seven days in autumn , and seven days in summer air rathad an rìgh ,
on the king ’ s highway . This road labour was exacted from crofters in the Isles and in other remote places although they never saw nor set foot on ‘ the king ’ s highway ’ except during the seven days they spent mending it . This labour on the roads , called ‘ statute labour ’ , was converted into a money - tax collected with the other assessments ; but on many estates the labour itself continued to be exacted long after the conversion into money had come into force , and the parallel exactions were made simultaneously . Only when the Royal Commission brought these and many other miserable abuses to the light of day did they fall into abeyance .

The last factor in Lewis who exacted these cains was Donald Munro , called Domhnall Ruadh nan Cearc ,
Red Donald of the hens . A satire on him has the lines :

O gun robh do spiorad fiar
Gu sìorraidh a ’ ruith nan cearc !
Agus Domhnall Dubh nam briag
’ Gad riasladh air sliabh nam peac !
[For other crofters ’ dues see : caora chàraidh ; cearc fearainn ; each ursann . ]

borr .
Great , noble , superb , proud , haughty . bus borr ,
projecting mouth , pouting mouth . borra - gheilleach ( - ghoilleach ? ) ,
dour , sulky . [Cf . Brìde bhorr ,
ii , 112 . ]

borrach , burrach .
Projecting , uprising , proud , haughty , oblique

swollen . duine borrach ,
a man of thick projecting lips . an fhairrge bhorrach ,
the swollen sea . A sept of the MacGregors , noted for their protruding mouths , gave in to the Government when proscribed . They became known as Clann - a - Ghéill ,
the yielding clan , and Borr - a - Ghéill ,
the projecting yielding mouths . The former gave great offence to the sept , but the latter was insufferable . [This may be a fanciful explanation of an epithet borra - ghéilleach ,
which may come , not from giall hostage , but from giall ,
jaw , cheek . Clann - a - Ghéill apparently means ‘ children of the hostage ’ ( giall ) . ]

borrasg = borrasag .
A bad , forward woman . [Eisd a bhorrasach shalach ,
UB , 185 . ]

bòsdan .
Boaster . bòsdag .
Female boaster .

bosladh .
Infant baptism .

bòthag [bòdhag] .
See trotag - thràghad ; brollach - bòdhaig .
bothaidh [better boghaidh ? ] . A horn ring used by tinkers to keep the laothadair [better laghadair] , mould , closed .

bothan , bothan - àirigh .
See màrag , màrrag .

brà , bràth .
Quern . Generally only one woman works the quern , as Duncan Campbell said :

Bean ’ na suidhe air an làr ,
Brà eadar a dà chois ,
Tàillearan a ’ sireadh snàth ,
Bonnaich bhàn ’ gan cur ri cloich .

[brà ,
Fr . Allan . ]

brabh .
See raidhne . [Perhaps bràbh ,
as it replaced stàth . ]

bradaire , bradaiche .
A thief .

braiceam .
A big rope of straw for carrying a meal bag through hilly ground . [braicheam ,
pack - saddle , horse - collar , Dw . Sc . brecham . ]

braidean .
A little thief . A woman had been abducted and had a son . When nursing the child she sang a lullaby , the burden of which was that the child would follow the example of his father ’ s people and harry the kindred of his mother :

Gura mise th ’ air mo chràdhlot
Ag altram mo dhearg - nàmhaid ;
Dar a théid thu null air Màman
Creachaidh to bràthair do mhàthar ,
’ S théid braidean ri chàirdean fhéin .
[braidean very often is not used in the literal sense , but is almost an affectionate term for a clever fellow . ]

braise .
See sriutan .

bralain .
Bull , old bull , effete bull , bull that has lost the hair of his tail through age . See raidhne . [Perhaps bràlain .
It rhymes with brabh , q . v . , the quantity of which is uncertain but brabh replaced stàth , and may therefore be bràbh ? ]

bramach - inilt , bromach - inilt .
A midwife . Also brannach - inilt , bronnach - inilt .
Chiefly a St . Kilda term . See bean - bàireach ; glùn .

bramach - roid , bramachan - roid .
A term applied in Rannoch to the corncrake . See treòn .

braman .
See tapag .

brànradh , bràradh .
Obstacle , obstruction , opposition , hindrance , mishap , accident . Nach ann orm a thànaig am brànradh / bràradh ,
is it not upon me that the mishap has come . [For the term in place - names see CPNS , 487 . ]

braogh , braoghach , braoghaich .
Sturt , temper , ill temper , burst of temper . bragh , braghad , braghadaich ,
pride , bursting with pride , puffed with pride . [Cf . braodag ,
a tantrum , TGSI , xxii , 35 ; bradhag ,
a huff , tantrum , id . , xxiv , 354 . ]

braoisgean .
Flounder . See cama - chraosan ; liabag .

bras .

brat .
The grain laid on a kiln to dry . [But see sorrag , where it is explained as the covering on which the grain is dried . ] The brat is on the traoghaig [straothag ,
Dw . ] ( = sreathainn , q . v . ) , the traoghaig on the cuiligean [ - ù - ? ] , the cuiligean rest above on the maide - sùirn ,
and below on the sòrn of the kiln . [See tarran ,
Dw . ]

brataidh .
Ill - tempered . [cf . brataich ,
kindle , rouse , ferment , excite , Dw ? ]

bràth mu casan [sic] . Doomed , a person doomed to die [ ? ] . Bha a bhràth mu chasan ,
his fate was sealed [ ? ] . [Gu h - aimlìsgeach fhuair an dara fear litir an fhir eile , agus bha a bhràth mu na casan ,
An Gàidheal Òg , May 1950 , p . 20 ( = ‘ the fat was in the fire ’ ) . ]

breabadair .
A weaver . Breabadair nan casa buidhe / ’ na shuidhe air a ’ gharman ,
the weaver of the yellow legs sitting on the weaver ’ s beam . [Cf . breabadair nan casan loisgt ’ ,
the burnt - legged weaver ( used as term of contempt ) , Dw . ]

breac beadaidh , breac feadaidh .
Loach .

breac donn .
Loch - trout . breac mara .
Sea - trout .

breac - seirc = ball - seirc .
A love spot , beauty spot .

breac - sìdh ( a ’ bhreac - shìdh ) .
See meilcheart .

breacag .
A large thin cake . The bonnach is a thick round bannock . [In Uist breacag is used instead of bonnach . ]

breallach .
See tapag . breallach breac .
See conachan .

breas , brias , briais .
A chief , a noble , a prince , a king , a god . Brian , a man ’ s name , is mistakenly used for briais ,
a prince . O bhriais Mhìcheil , bi - s ’ an cinnseal m ’ anama ,
O noble Michael , be thou in charge of my soul . Ged thug thu bhriais dhonais leat , is oil leam ( var . oileach ) and rud a rinn thu ,

though thou didst take with thee the evil god ( devil ) , well I am pleased [sic] with what thou hast done . [Cf . breaschathair ,
a throne , AMV , p . 44 . ]

breas , breis briarn ( briam , buarn ? ) = bras ,
high - mettled . each bras ,
rash high - mettled horse . duine bras ,
high - tempered man . [For briarn etc . read briais ? ]

breasgach , briosgach .
Apt to be startled , easily startled . Tha bhó ruadh breasgach ,
the red cow is easily startled , likely to upset the milkpail and sometimes the milker . Thug a ’ bhó briosg aisde .

breicioll , breichioll ( MS . brech - ) . A daft , silly , soft - headed person . [Cf . breitheal ,
confusion , as of mind , delirium , raving , etc . , Dw ? ]

bréid .
Coif . bréid = beanntag = bréid beanntagach = bréid beannach = bréid crannaig = bréid an crannaig .

Saoil nach mise bha uallach
Dar a fhuair mi am bréid , [bhuannaich mi ’ m
Dar a bhuannaich mi bheannag [anart
Chaidh a cheannach dhomh fhéin .
[Cf . Or . , 511]

Rìgh gur mise fhuair am beum ,
Oigread chuir mi suas am bréid , [leg . Og ged
’ S mór tha m ’ aithreachas ’ na dhéidh ,
Rinn thu féin le d ’ bheul mo mhealladh .

O ’ s ann tha mo ghaol - sa thall
Fo dhubhar nan craobh ’ s nam beann ,
Sgiobair thu air luing nan crann ,
’ S mór tha m ’ annsachd air a ’ mharaich ’ .
[Cf . MC , 200 - 201 . ]
[Sec stìom , beannag . ]

breoghas ( MS . breothas ) . Heat , fire , flame , warmth , affection . See brioghas . [duine breoghasach ,
N . Uist . ]

breothail .
Decent , becoming .

brianag .
The feminine of Brian ,
the god of light and leading among the Celts .

Is tu mo bhrianag bhòidheach bhinneach ,
Is tu mo bhrianag bhòidheach ,
Is tu mo bhrianag bhòidheach bhinneach
As gile cneas ’ s as boidhche . [còmhnadh

Brian meant a leader , a guide , a father , and Brianag a light , a guide , a mother , a sweetheart . [In the proverb is brian air caillich a h - aon bhó ,
Rel . Celt . , ii , 495 , brian seems to mean ‘ pride ’ . The Lewis equivalent is :

uaill na caillich as a h - aona bhoin .
In the well - known song Och - óin mo chailin ’ s mo shùil ad dhéidh the line on chualas gun deach thu le Brian a dh ’ òl seems to mean that the poet had heard that his love had died , not that she had taken to tippling with an Hibernian student of that name , as John MacKenzie would have it in Sàr Obair ! Brian here is the Otherworld god . For Brian , one of the three gods of craftsmanship , see O ’ Rahilly , EIHM , 308 ff . ]

brias , briais .
See breas .

bricein buidhe .
Yellow trout . bricein dubh .
Black trout ( Loch Awe ) . In some parts of Loch Awe the yellow trout is yellower and the black trout blacker than in other parts . The natives can tell at a glance in what part of Loch Awe each kind of trout was killed , and know the trout of each lake and stream . In Loch Awe is Kilchurn Castle , Caisteal Caol Chùirn ,
where the osprey used to breed ; picnic parties lighted fires in the chimneys of the old castle and the noble bird left the place and never came back .

brig .
Bread , baked bread in contrast to taois ,
dough .

brigis bheag , triubhais bheag .
Small trews . brigis mhàis .
Seat trews . These were small trews worn by the young men in réis each ,
horse racing , gearradh leum ,
jumping , and other sports for which the kilt was less suitable . brigis ghlùn .
Knee breeches , knickerbockers . brigis mhór .
When the trews and stockings appeared as one , used by gentlemen when riding .

brioganan ( ? ) .
See logaid .

brioghas [ì ? ] . Dalliance , passion , procreation . Banas agus brioghas dha mo nighean donn ,
wifehood and motherhood to my brown maid . Banas agus brioghas ort !
wifehood and procreation upon thee ! These were expressions common among men when receiving carrots from women . See breoghas ; tapag . [brīoghasach ,
GlenB , 385 . ]

brionnag .
A mother , a matron , a beautiful woman , from brionn ,
bright , brilliant . This word has fallen to mean a giddy woman , a lightsome woman . Brionnag a ’ bhaile ,
the talkative woman of the town , seen everywhere save in her own house and among her own family . Aontachadh brionnaig ri / le breugaig ,
the agreeing of the giddy one with the lying one . Dithis a tha colach ri chéile , breugag is brionnag ,
two who are like one another , the lying one and the giddy one .

Aontaichidh brionnag le breugaig ,
Aontaichidh breugag le bradaig ;
Triùir a tha colach ri chéile ,
Brionnag is breugag is bradag .

Is truagh nach mi ’ s mo rogha céile
Bha ’ s a ’ ghleann ud thall ag éirigh ,

[brionnag means a deceitful woman . The interpretation of brionn as bright is perhaps accounted for by association with brionngheal ,
white - breasted , which however is connected with brù , broinn ,
or bruinne ,
breast . A Lewis example is : Is mór le brionnag a cuid abhrais ,
an uncapable woman loathes the amount of wool she has to work . Cf . bithidh iad breannach , breugach ,
S , 369 ; Dia brionnach gun sùilean ,
SO ( 1907 ed . ) , 316a ; dh ’ fhalbh mi le Bréigein brionnach ,
An Gàidheal , vi , 336 . ]

brionngheal , brionnagheal , brionnaghal .
White - breasted .

briosgach .
See breasgach .

bristeadh - bodha .
Broken reef , breakers on a reef . The surge that rises suddenly over a reef or unseen rock on the west coast is dangerous and appalling when one is near it . Every now and then it is fatal even to those well acquainted in the locality . bristeach .
A broken sea over a reef , the sea that breaks over small reefs in the Atlantic and in the creeks of the west coast . [Cf . am bial bristidh s . v . lacha - liath . bodha ON boði , a breaker ( on hidden rocks ) . ]

britheir .
Prior .

broc .
Badger . The badger is fond of carrots and will carry corn in the straw into his den . Broc coin ,
dog badger ; broc muic ,
pig badger . These are two different kinds , which existed side by side in Morvern , though they are both extinct now . Robert Livingstone saw both there , but never heard of them elsewhere . [They were also said to have been found in the Campsie Fells , AF , 65 . ]

Am broc stiallach ,
Striachach , streamach .

Chan iarr am broc
’ Na shloc ach e fhéin .

When a man stands [ ? stamps] in a temper it is said , ‘ Tha e cur bhroc as a ladhran ’ ,
‘ He is casting badgers out of his feet ’ , i . e . getting rid of his temper . [Cf . AF , 65 . ] Broc metaphorically means ‘ curmudgeon ’ .

The shy badger has his home in a retired gully , burrowed deep into the earth . Like other hibernating animals he grows very fat in the fall of the year , an t - Sultain .
During the October moon he cuts grass and on a fine moonlight night a cautious spectator may see him turning and drying the grass round about his den . By daylight he has taken it all

inside . The grass is for warmth in winter and for food . This process is called am broc a ’ caoineachadh a ’ bhoitein ,
the badger winning or drying his pottle of grass .

At Sloc an Luaidh ,
the gully of the waulking , in Barcaldine , a badger had its den for many years . Hard by were fields under the usual crops — corn , potatoes , etc . , and plots of vegetables . The badger helped himself occasionally to the corn , but if carrots were sown he would leave very little of the crop .

brocan , bogha - muc , bogha - mucag .
Blue hyacinth . [bo - muc ,
Fr . Allan . ]

bròg an eich - uisge .
‘ The shoe of the water - horse ’ , marsh marigold , from the plant ’ s supposed resemblance to the hoof of the each - uisge .
broidealan , broidleachan = broidileag = brù - dhearg .

broillean , proillean , brollan , broilleachan , brollachan ( all mas . ) . broilleag , brollag ( both fem . ) . Breastling , child at the breast , brollan balaich ,
a breastling boy . brollanach is sometimes applied to an ill - conditioned boy who ought to know better manners . See brostan .

broitseach , proitseach .
Breastling ( child ) . [proitseach ,
a gallant young man , Fr . Allan , 265 ; proitseach ,
boy , stripling ; good lump of a boy , Dw . Cf . Bha i falbh ’ s i ’ na proitseach ,
‘ she was going about as a slip of a girl ’ , Waifs and Strays , v , 18 . ]

brollach - bòdhaig / bòthain ,
also bòdhag , bòthag .
The shore pipit . Also defined as a ( shore ) plover when he assumes his spring garb ; see Tennyson , Locksley Hall . [brollach - bothan ,
black - throated diver , TGSI , xii , 80 . ] See trotag - thràghad .

bromach air tharrach .
Topsy turvy , hurly burly , upside down [head over heels] . Also bronnach air thorach , turach air thorach , tromach air thorach , turrach air tharrach , truimeach air thearrach . [bronnach etc . , Fr . Allan , 257 . Perhaps originally dromach ( druim ,
gen . droma ) or dronnach ( dronn ,
back ) air tharrach ( tarr ,
belly ) . ]

bròn an t - samhraidh .
‘ Sorrow of summer ’ , means the finest day or the finest period of the summer . It is not now known what day or period is meant . Whether or not the word bròn has become corrupted it is what the old people say , though they cannot explain it . [Cf . bruthainn ,
sultriness ? ]

brosnachadh bàire , brosnachadh blàir , brosnachadh bualaidh .
An incitement to battle . A boy stretches out his arm and says : ‘ Am fear as fìne fuil tilgeadh e smugaid thar a siod ’ ,
‘ He whose blood is most wine - like let him throw a spittle over that ’ . A boy throws a spittle over the out - stretched arm and in return gets a slap in the mouth from the insulted arm . The fight is on and the two combatants pound away at one another , to the admiration of the other boys . Sometimes the boys are unequally matched and the other boys take sides and the combat becomes general — the wine - blood of the boys flowing freely from cheeks , noses and mouths .

brostan .
A breastling , child ; also brollachan .
See broillean .

brothag .
A little female , a little woman of pronounced breasts , from broth ,
breast , pap , projection .

An oba ghlan chuir Moire gheal
Chon Brìghde broth nam buadh ,
A null air lear , a null air mear ,
A null air ceal ( ? ) , a null air cuan . [cear ( ? )

[brothag ,
the bosom , a fold of the breast clothes , McB . ]

bruathradh nan cnàmh .
The sound of the breaking of bones . [leg . bruanradh ? Cf . bruanadh . ]

brùca .
See cambar . [ON brúk , a heap of seaweed . ]

brugh .
An underground dwelling , a fairy dwelling in a knoll . brughairean .
Dwellers therein .

brunndail .
See monabar .

bua .
Gleam , glow , ray , ember . bua - theine .
Ember - fire ; bua - theine na h - oidhche ,
the fire coruscation of the night . bua - dhealt . [fuar - dhealt ,
Dw . ] Mildew .

buad .
Is used to mean the moon in phrases such as buad Mhic Phàrlain , buad Mhic an Tòisich , buad Mhic Dhomhnaill Dhuibh , buad Mhic Mhannain ,
the lantern of Macfarlane , the lantern of Mackintosh , the lantern of Cameron of Lochiel , the lantern of MacMannan . [The Gaelic of the last name should be Mac Bhannain ,
anglicised as Buchanan in Skye and Lewis . ]

Buad Locha Buidhe ,
Ceann - uidhe nam meàirleach .

The reference is to cattle - raids made by these chiefs by the light of the moon , generally that of Martinmas or Hallowtide . This was a pastime of chiefs throughout the Highlands , as well as throughout the Borders , for the filling of their larders . It gave rise in the case of the Macfarlanes to the saying Crò Mhic Phàrlain ,
Macfarlane ’ s cattle - fold , meaning his neighbour ’ s cattle - fold , and to the famous pibroch Thogail nam bó . [buait ,
Dw . Sc . booat , bouet , bowet , lantern . See TGSI , xxvii , 335 ; History of Clan Macfarlane , 14 . ]
buag . [Spigot , plug ? Non est ? ] See iris .

buaile .
A burial place [an extended use of buaile ,
a fold for cattle , a circle] . The ancient burial grounds were circular , possibly emblematic of eternity . In Cnapadal ,
Knapdale , there are circular burial places with mounds of earth surrounded by boulders . Several of this nature are at the head of Loch Suain [recte Loch Suibhne] , Loch Sween , and are called Na Cladhannan ,
the graveyards . At Achadh Ur , in Lismore , is a burial place called Cill an t - Suidhe , Cill an t - Suidhinn , Cladh nan Cruinneach [Cruithneach ? ,
the graveyard of the Cruithnich , Picts] , and other names . This is supposed to have been the burial place of the Pictish kings of Benderloch . Buaile a ’ chlaidh means the circle of people round a grave at a funeral .

buaile .
See ballan - buaile .

buaileag .
A whirlpool , from buaile ,
ring , circle .

buailim anns a ’ cheann thu .
See Ràghall agus Cairistìne .

buailtean .
Flail - rod . This was of mountain - ash , to prevent the witches from threshing the corn and carrying away the grain from the àth ,
kiln , barn . [Lorg - shùist was the part in the hand , the handle . The buailtean was the heavy part that did the actual threshing . They were tied together by the iall - shùist of sheepskin , often steeped in water so that it could be knotted . — Lewis . In Bernera , Lewis , the handle of the flail is làmhcharan , làmhcharan sùiste ,
TGSI , xxxvii , 19 ; lamhargan ,
Arran ; iall shùiste , sail shùiste ,
Dw , s . v . sùist . ]

bualan boireann .
The ‘ female ragweed ’ is good for plàsd ,
plaster or poultice . Beat the dìthean ,
bloom , of the bualan boireann and mix it with ola dhorn mhart ( q . v . ) , neat ’ s foot oil , and it is good for sore knee . The bualan fireann ,
‘ male ragweed ’ , has no bloom , and is pulled green and put in layers throughout cornstacks by Uist farmers and crofters . Its smell keeps rats away . [The plant is certainly ragweed , still used for the latter purpose ; but owing to partial corrections in the MS . , it is not certain whether the ‘ male ’ or the ‘ female ’ plant has the bloom . buadhghalan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

buarach .
See biast - mhaol ; rac .

buarach .
See buidhean .

buarm = beag - nàrach .
Impudent , shameless .

budhag .
Boulder . [bulbhag ,
McB . , 391 . budhag ,
bundle of straw , Dw . ]

buidhean , buidheag .
A kit for carrying milk , a staffless churn , a circular vessel of dressed skin for carrying milk from the buaile ,
fold , in the hill to the dairy at the house . It varied in size according to the number of cows ; it ranged from 1½ to 2 feet in diameter . It was carried on the dairymaid ’ s back , the buarach ,
spancel , being passed through the two cluaiseanan ,
ears , of the buidhean ,
and its two ends fastened in front of the dairymaid . As she walked she span with the cuigeal ,
distaff — an instructive sight and a proof of the industry of the old people . It was used only when there was a buaile of some size and milk in some quantity . It was higher , but not broader , than the cuman .
It had two short ears like a ship ’ s bucket , with a rope between them . It was also used for water . See coidhean .

buigirisg .
Soft weather .

buil - féin .
See dìol - féin .

bùilig .
See imdeal .

buinne .
A strong current , rushing tidal stream , the sea caused by a strong stream and a strong current going against one another . A space of sea near the Lady ’ s Rock [Sgeir na Baintighearna :
formerly an Lethsgeir] at the end of Lismore is called Buinne nam Biodag ,
the current of the dirks .

bùirean , bùran .
See punan .

bun dearg .
Fern cut for thatch . bun dubh .
Fern pulled for thatch . Fern is the material used for thatching in the wide district of Loch Alsh , Loch Long and Loch Duich . The fern is laid thickly and lasts long , especially if laid on with clay or even common mud . [bun - dubh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

bunach .
Refuse of any kind , the refuse of wool , hemp and flax ; also the ground - end of sheaves of corn . [Cf . bunalach ,
new wool which spoilt the calanas when sheep were too late in being clipped . Also wool on sheepskin if killed shortly after shearing . ]

bunndaist .
See cùileag .

bura - bhuachaille , buna - bhuachaille , bun - bhuachaille ,
etc . The great northern diver . This large handsome bird is common at all seasons in the west of Scotland , but neither its nest nor its young have been found . Its wings are small in proportion to its body , and it flies heavily , clumsily and low above the water , but it is a wonderful swimmer and diver . In Glen Elg the curious belief prevails that it hatches under water , an egg under each wing , and takes a year in hatching .

Seachd bliadhna ’ na learga - dhearg ,
Seachd bliadhna ’ na learga - dhubh ,
Seachd bliadhna ’ na sgarbh - callaig ( ? ) ,
Seachd bliadhna ’ na bhallaire - bòdhain ,
Seachd bliadhna ’ na bhuna - bhuachaille bòchain
A ’ gurasgaich an grunnd a ’ chuain .

[gurasgaich should perhaps be gurasglaich .
Cf . An losgadh ort a ghurasglach ! ,
OT , p . 61 . Cf . also the incident told of the first Laird of Struan : ‘ He cast off all his clothes , and stark naked ( there being a small rivulet of water and mire near to it ) , he threw himself into the mire . Whenever the woman perceived him , she screamed aloud , desiring him for God ’ s sake , if he was a man of this world to tell what he was . He cautioned her not to be afraid , that he would do her no harm , that his residence was there always , and that his name was Gurisglich . ’
( Collectanea de Rebus Albanicis , p . 293 ; HP , i , 19 . ) ]

bùrn .
Water . In Lewis water brought in on Sunday is called uisge ,
water brought in on any other day is called bùrn .
The people will not wash on Sunday with water brought in the previous day . [This does not hold for recent times as no water is taken in on Sunday . Uisge was a tabu word on the Flannan Islands . It had to be called bùrn .
See Martin Martin , 98 . ]

burraghlas .
Overgrown dogfish .

butar - scionn , butars - cionn .
Upside down , topsy - turvy , awry . [Cf . Chaidh mi butarscionn ’ s mo bhean ,
I fell out with my wife , MC , 332 . ] Chuir thu butar - scionn e = You have put it ‘ through other ’ .

buthail , buthailt .
See puthail .

butrais , butarras , butarrais .
Refuse , trash . Also = garbh - shìde , droch - shian , don - aimsir ,
when all the elements are let loose together . [utaras ,
Fr . Allan , p . 268 . ]

cabar .
See suimir .

cabhan , caibhean , caimhean , cabhanach .
Troutlet , small trout . [caimheanach ,
Raasay ; caimeineach , caimheineach , caibheineach ,
Dw ; caimeach ,
AF , p . 391 ; caimeineach ,
TGSI , xxiii , 85 ( Skye Gaelic ) ; caimheineach ,
Mary Macpherson , p . 18 ; càimeineach ( sic ) , id . , p . 53 . ]

cabhar .
A bird , invariably confined to the larger kinds . cabhar creige ,
eagle , from creag ,
rock ; cabhar criathraich ,
bird of the harrier kind , from criathrach ,
mossland ; cabhar cluain ,
bird of the goose kind , from cluain ,
plain ; cabhar lòin ,
bird of the swan kind , from lòn ,
lake ; cabhar coille ,
bird of the capercailzie kind , from coille ,
wood . [Cf . cubar ,
a bird of prey ; cupar , a kite , Contrr . ]

cados , cathdos .
Hose , stocking hose , kilt hose . [See SHR , xxix , 132 . ]

cadus .
Noble , grand ; nobility .

cailbeag - shìonain .
Fire , wildfire . See coill .

cailcein .
Land on a sea - bank above its surroundings . [cailcein .
Islet formed when the tide recedes , usually in an estuary , Dw . ]

caile .
See irghinn .

càilein .
See càirnein .

cailleach .
See coinnleag ; struilleag .

cailleach .
A storm - anchor , also called cruaidh [a ’ chruaidh , Dw] . [cailleach was also used for the turf seat in the àirigh ,
sheiling ; shuidh e air a ’ chaillich ( Lewis ) . ]

cailleach .
An old potato - skin full of water .

cailleach - chràbhaidh ,
pl . cailleachan - cràbhaidh .
A nun . See bodach .

caimein .
A speck of light . caimein fiodha ,
a burning chip . caimein fraoich ,
a burning heather - twig .

caimhleachadh .
Hemming , surrounding , pressing inward from without . A term used in Uist for catching fish in a stream . The stream is dammed and the trout are driven down to the pool thus formed . A net is placed inside the wall of the dam and the sluice of the dam is opened and the fish secured . [Cf . caimhleachadh ,
environing , i , 238 ; caimleachadh ,
encompassment , iii , 228 ; caimleachadh , cuingleachadh ,
ii , 242 ; a choimhleachadh na h - aibhne ,
iv , 9 ; caimleachadh bhreac ,
‘ guddling

trout ’ , ii , 242 . See cabhuil , caibhlich , caimhlich ,
Fr . Allan , and coileachadh ,
p . 258 . ]

caimid , caimideal .
Crooked . caimidealach .
Crooked , troublesome , dilatory . duine caimidealach ,
a slow , unreliable man . creutair caimidealach ,
a vexatious person . creutair caimileideach ( sic ) , a person wavering to and fro .

caimilein .
A crooked narrow channel .

caimilisg .
See càrn .

càin a ’ ghobha .
See cùileag . càin nan cearc .
See cearc - fearainn .

càineach , càinear .
A man who collects dues upon land , from càin ,
cain / kane , tax . A man in Cowal was known as Am Baran Càineach ,
from his office as collector of dues . His son is known as Mac a ’ Chàinich ,
son of the duesman , and Mac a ’ Bharain Chàinich ,
son of the baron duesman .

caineal .
Canella , cinnamon , was much used to give fragrance to the breath , and is often mentioned in Gaelic .

Gura cubhraidh ’ na ’ n caineal
Liom anail do bhràghad .

Tha t ’ anail lioms ’ na ’ s cubhraidh ’
Na ubhlan ’ s iad ’ gam buain ,
Na ’ n caineal caoin ’ ga shùghadh
A thiubhrar thar a ’ chuain .

cainein [cainnean] , coinein .
A speck of light for kindling , as cainein fraoich ,
a small sprig of heather to light a pipe . cainein mòine ,
a small bit of peat to light a pipe . cainein fiodha ,
a small chip of wood to light a lamp , candle , fire .

caingean .
Tribute , tax . [E . Ir . caingen , exaction , tribute , Contrr . ]

cainichean , canachan = canach ,
cotton grass ( q . v . ) .

Dar thig cìob is cainichean air bhrath ,
tha biadh a ’ chruidh a mach . [ri sheanchas ; ’ na aimsir

When deer - grass and cotton grass are come ,
the food of the flocks is outside . [in evidence ; in season

cainir [càinir ? ] .
Salmon fisher . cainirireach [ ? ] . Salmon fishing . [Cf . càinear ,
a salmon - fisher , fisher for salmon in tidal waters , TGSI , xxiv , 355 . ]

càirdeachadh a chéile .
Meeting each other in friendship .

càirean .
See balg càirein .

cairmein , gairmein .
Rough place , rough surface , from garbh ,
rough . gairmeineach .
Rough - surfaced , granulated .

càirnein , cairinnein .
Awn of barley , a thing that adheres , a prickly adherent physically or morally , e . g . is tu an càirnein granda . càirnein eòrna ,
awn of bere . Sometimes used = càilein ,
a husk of oat or chaff ; a thing in one ’ s eye , akin to smùirnein .

cairt - loch .
See logaire .

caiseil , caiseil - chrò [E . Ir . cossair chró] , crà - leap , crò - leaba , carbad , crò - charbad .
Bier , the frame on which the dead are carried to the grave . It was customary all over Appin to break the carbad — as the bier was called in Appin — immediately the grave was filled in . This was to prevent the witches , sluagh or fairies , from carrying away the bodies of the dead . This was an ancient custom and hardly yet discontinued . It is said that the crò - charbad was made of wicker - work . This could not have been in any of the Outer Isles where there are now no woods . A bier made of mountain ash was preferable , the mountain ash being sacred . [Cf . ii , 246 ; v , 152 . The bier was also called eiletriom ( Lat . feretrum ) and eislig , islig . ]

caisein - fighe .
Treadles of loom . [casachan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

Caisir Neamha .
See Saothair an Daobh .

caisneach .
Grieved , sorrowful .

Is caisneach mo chadal
O ’ n taca seo ’ n dé ,
On thug mi ’ n cion falaich
Do ’ n chailin gun chré .

[Cf . cais , caise ,
anger , shortness of temper . caiseanachd ,
fretfulness , peevishness , shortness of temper , Dw . ]

càlag [ - à - marked thus] . Puffin ( Tiree ) . [Cf . caileag , calltag ,
black guillemot , Dw . ]

càlaidh ( in other hand caileadh ) . Partition wall in a house , division , fence , wall . Streap a ’ chait ris a ’ chàlaidh ,
the climbing of the cat to the partition — applied to a thing difficult to do . Streap a ’ chait chaothaich ris a ’ chàlaidh chreagach ,
the climbing of the mad cat to the rocky partition — applied to a desperate thing , a thing impossible to do , struggle as one may . [cailbh ,
Fr . Allan . cailbh ’ ,
NGP , 268 . From calbh , colbh ,
Ir . colbha , a pillar . ]

Calainn .
For a Rann C . see s . v . tur .

calanas .
See canach ; corra - chrosgag ; topan .

calg an rubha .
See biast - mhaol .

callasaid , callasaideach .
Beating , beating to death , thrashing , thrashing a person to death .

calltainn .
Hazel . Snakes are said to be easily killed by a blow from a hazel rod . Emigrants from Ireland are known to have taken hazel rods with them to America to kill snakes .

cama - chraosan .
Flounder . See braoisgean , liabag . [Cf . iv , 10 . ]

cama - lìon .
See lìon leathann làir .

camart .
Kill ; dead ; died . [Cf . comart ,
death , killing , HSD . ]

cambar , campar . [ON kambr , a comb , crest , ridge of hills ; freq . in local names of crags rising like a crest . — Cleasby and Vigfusson . ] A burial mound , place of burial . About a hundred yards from Cill Àisinn ( q . v . ) in Berneray , Harris , is An Cambar ,
a burial ground still in use , beautifully situated above the only bay in Berneray . Some knolls near are called Na Cambair Bheaga ,
the Little Mounds .

A girl of South [sic ; leg . North] Uist died in Berneray . The weather was so stormy that her body could not be removed across the narrow sea to Uist , and her mother was in great distress . There is a dedication to St Columba at Sand in Uist , sometimes called Clachan Chaluim Chille ,
the Church - town of Columba , and sometimes Clachan Sannd ,
the Church - town of Sand . The mother appealed to Columba , saying :

A Chaluim Chille an Sannda ,
Na leig mo ghaol dh ’ an Chambar !
Ciùinich féin an t - anntid
Is leig a nall mo ghaol .

Columba , who never turned a deaf ear to the distressed , appealed to God , and the storm abated and the girl ’ s body was laid with the bodies of the fathers in the Clachan of Columba . [Cf . ii . 241 . ]

A burial place in St Kilda is also called An Cambar ;
its situation is like that of the one in Berneray , above the stormy exposed bay of the island . It seems to be mentioned in the following lines taken down in May 1865 from an old woman in St Kilda , Eibhrig Nic Cruimein , aged eighty - four years :

Tobar Childa Chalda , [Childar Chaldar
Allta Chamar nan Lobhar .
The well of Kilda of Kalda , the stream of the Camar ( Burial Place ) of the Lepers . [Calda may be ON kaldá , cold stream . ]

Both in Berneray and in St Kilda there is a well near the graveyard called Tobar a ’ Chambair ,
the Well of the Burial Mound . The St Kilda rime is known elsewhere , in the islands and on the mainland .

There is a place in Ness , Lewis , called An Cambar ; air a ’ Chambar ,
at Cambar . An old Lewis song says :

Chì mi uam an Cambar thallad ,
Is truagh nach robh mi air a leac ,
. . . . . . .
A ’ cromadh gu leathad glas .

Bha mi oidhche air àirigh uarad , [MS . fhuarad
Ghabh mi crith ’ s cha b ’ e crith fhuaire ,
Dh ’ fhairich mi fear làmh fhuil . —
A ’ sgaoileadh bhreacan air m ’ uachdar
’ S a ’ cur nan arm ( ? ) an taobh shuas dhìom .

M ’ eudail air mnathan mo dhùthcha ,
’ S iad a dheidheadh deas dh ’ an bhrùca
Le treudan geala air an cùlaibh [leg . bréidean
’ S cha bhiodh iad air dath an dùdain .

canach , cana , can , can an t - sléibhe , canach na mòintich .
Cotton grass , mountain down , moor cotton . clach cana ,
white stone . clacha cana ,
hailstones . In the Highlands a girl was not considered fit for marriage gun an dèanadh i léine canaich dh ’ a leannan agus paidhir stocainn dhi fhéin ,
until she made a shirt of the mountain down for her lover and a pair of stockings for herself . This was the test in calanas ,
wool - working , and calanas was the criterion in housewifery . At the Exhibition of 1851 there were several exhibits made of mountain down , made by the deft hands of crofter women of Ross and Inverness - shire ; they were much admired for their beauty and fine texture . See cainichean .

canndal , canndail .
Rushes . These were used in making light chairs , for bedding , for thatching houses , churches or other buildings , and for other purposes . They are still used to strew the floors of houses and churches . The fine imposed by the Church for delinquency included rushes and a contribution to the maintenance of the poor . A certain eccentric cleric raised the penalty , which had the desired effect of stopping delinquency , but also lessened the amount of money for the poor and left the church short of thatch . Through the leaky roof the rain came down upon the cleric ’ s head as he was officiating in the church , and he exclaimed :

Seo ! seo ! a mhacanan uilc ,
Masa trasg fóghnaidh ;
An t - seann chàin dh ’ an t - seann chluichd ,
An t - seann ghàire dh ’ an t - seann chóineadh ;
. . . . . . . .
Trì tasdain airgid dha na buichd ,
Trì ghàdag channdail dh ’ an eaglais .

Come ! come ! ye sons of evil , if it be abstinence , it suffices ; the old fine to the old game , the old laugh to the old weeping … ; three silver shillings for the poor , three measures of rushes for the church .

caob fearainn .
A piece of land . caobadh .
The act of portioning land into shares .

caoibhreachan .
Marsh rag - wort . See cuibhreachan and caoireachan . [caoibhreachan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

caoin .
An air , tune , melody , refrain , chorus . caoin òrain ,
air of song .

caoineachadh .
See broc .

an caoireachan ( some plant ) . Is good for all ills beneath lag a ’ bhràghad ,
the hollow above the breastbone , but not above that . See caoibhreachan and cuibhreachan .

caor .
Bunch , clump , as caor sheilich ,
clump of willow .

caora .
Sheep . ‘ Is beothach beannaichte a ’ chaora — bheannaich Crìosda fhéin i . Nam faice tu caora no baidne chaora ’ nad chadal is e ainglean a bhiodh ann . Tha saorsa bheannaichte ri fhaicinn dhut a dh ’ oidhche no a latha , ad chadal no ad dhùsga . ’
— ‘ The sheep is a blessed animal — Christ Himself blessed her . Wert thou to see a sheep or a little flock of sheep in thy sleep , it is angels that would be there . A blessed freedom ( redemption ? ) is to be seen by thee by night or by day , in thy sleeping or in thy waking . ’

The sheep is treated with tender care , even its bones being sacred . The native Highland sheep has a long tuft of wool down the forehead , like the long tuft of hair down the forehead of the Highland cow and of the horse . This is called in all three cases , logaidh .
The sguman [sgùman ? ] ,
on the other hand , is properly the lock falling back upon the neck . [logaidh ,
tuft of hair above forehead ; sgùmban ,
the top of the head or crown , Fr . Allan . sgùman ,
Dw . ] The sheep itself forbade denuding it of its logaidh ,
which gives it a pretty and picturesque appearance :

Na lom mo logaidh ,
Na loisg mo chasan ,
Na leig mo chasgairt
Dha na coin mhóra .
Do not clip my lock , do not burn my feet , nor let me slaughtered by the big dogs . [Cf . i , 288 f . ]

Cnàmh do chìr , a chaora lom ,
Cnàmh do chìr , a chaora lom ,
Cnàmh do chìr , a chaora lom ,
Cnàmh do chìr , a chaorag ,

Is mìlse liom na sgal na pìoba
Ceòl nan cìr aig gaolag . [Car

Cnàmh do chìr , a chaora lom ,
Cnàmh do chìr , a chaomhag ;
Is mìlse liom na blas na fìge
Fuaim na cìdhle aig caomhag . [anail mhìn mo chaoireag

caora bheannach [see also corra - bheannach] . A sheep with three , four , five , six or even seven horns . caora sgalach .
A wide - horned sheep . caora sgrogach .
A sheep with short stumpy horns . caora sgumain [probably sgùmain] . A tufted sheep . caora Spàinteach .
A usual name for a caora mhaol ,
Cheviot sheep , whence their wool is called clòimh Spàinteach . caora lachdann .
A sheep peculiar to St Kilda , with wool of cinnamon colour . caora bhan feall [ ? leg . c . bharr pheall ; cf . uanallach] . A sheep which has to be fleeced fully in time else the wool becomes felted in hard balls which cannot be teazed or disentangled . [See beannach ; sgùmban ,
Fr . Allan . ]

caora chàraidh .
Every crofter under a tighearna ,
lord or laird , or under a fear - baile ,
tacksman , was bound to give his ground - superior a fat sheep on Latha Samhna ,
Hallowmas . This sheep was called caora chàraidh . [caora chàraidh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

caorrann .
The berry of the rowan makes miniceir , mionaicir ,
vinegar . caorrann caothaich = caorrann nan con ,
birdcherry . [caorunn - caoich ,
species of cranberry supposed to be poisonous , Dw , HSD ; caorann - cuthaich ,
a species of wild berry , MacL . ]

capallan .
Possibly the sea - mouse , is a small animal about the shape and size of a mouse . It is found in pools on the sea - shore . Cats bring it home and place it beside their young ; the mother cats enjoy seeing their kittens playing with it as it tries to escape .

càraid .
See cathul .

càraidh .
See caora chàraidh .

caraiste , cairiste .
See bòrlandachd . [càraisde ; cairbhist ,
p . 257 , Fr . Allan . Cf . Gu bhi saor o gach cairbheist ,
RD , 113 ; Cha ’ n ainmeil sior chairbheist , ’ s cha seirbhis na stracaidhnean ,
id . , 265 . M . Eng . cariage . ]

càramh .
Embroidery , needlework ; laying out a body on a bier .

carbad .
See caiseil .

càrlas .
See talcas .

càrn .
A heap of stones . càrn caimilisg ,
cairn of confusion . càrn conaisg ,
literally cairn of whins , metaphorically a cairn of stones raised near the house of an enemy to show the contempt in which he is held and to despite and annoy him . [But see coinneasg . ]

càrn .
Trouble , difficulty , sorrow , uneasiness , in straits ; air chàrn ,
a fugitive , outlaw . [Cf . fear cùirn ,
really from càrn ,
cairn , like tha e fo ’ n choill ,
he is in the ‘ greenwood ’ . ] A fugitive said : cha do shuidh duine riamh socair air chàrn ,
no man ever sat easy upon a cairn . càrn tuathal ,
‘ withershin cairn ’ , a cairn whither misfortune came in .

càrn .
See leid .

càrnach .
From càrn ,
a heap , a burden , a difficulty , as :

An am a ’ chur ’ s a ’ chàrnaich
Gur beag a lùth ’ s a thàbhachd ,
O Ios ’ , a Rìgh nan gràsan ,
Dèan fuil - bhràthrachd ris .

[An leg . An am a chur ’ s a ’ chàrnaich ,
at the time of putting him among the cairns , i . e . outlawing him ? ]

càrnach .
Grave , durance , entombment , grave - mound .

Tha t ’ athair a ’ mire ’ s a ’ mànran
Is mise ’ s a ’ chàrnaich nach dùisg .
[This might be the meaning in the quatrain under càrnach supra . ]

carnadh .
See mìr .

carr .
Anything hard , tough , and immovable . carr mòine ,
moss roots . carr cinn ,
scab on the head . Also a strong root . Tha e ’ na charr ’ san talamh , tha e ’ na aon charr ,
it is one root in the earth . In some districts the earr - thalmhainn is called carr - thalmhainn from its strong - rootedness . [càrr ,
Fr . Allan . Whence carrach ,
scald - headed , as in Alasdair Carrach . ]

carra - lighe , carra - shlighe .
A difficult pass , a thing difficult to follow , a difficult object to overcome . There is a Carra - lighe in Eilean na h - Airde Móire , another in Eilean Bàn , and another in Eilean Oirisgeig , Ìochdar , South Uist . [If the word be carra - lighe ( coirthe lighe )
it may indicate the presence in these places of memorial stones in a recumbent position ? ]

carraig . carraig na biodaig ,
the rough handle of the dirk . [Carraig ,
Fr . Allan . Hence the adj . cairgeach , carraigeach ,
Fr . Allan . Also carraigneach ( carraigean ) . ’ S iad gu cnottach , cnappach , faobach , / Gu cairgineach , raodach , miarach ,
DMcL , p . 49 ; Snìomhan lìonmhora croma / Air a cois dhromanaich chargnaich ,
DB , l . 960 and n . ; Le ’ d bhiodaig ghlais ort is carraigneach cas ,
PB , 107 ; Biodag charraigneach , bhreac , fhuilteach ,
id . , 296 ; Biodag ghlas bu chairgneach cas ,
AD , 28 ; Bhiodag chairineach chnapanach ,

Gill - easbuig Grannda , 81 ; Thainig thair muir chairginich ghairbh ,
G , 317 ; fiodh carraigneach ,
NGP , 91 . ]

carraigh .
A lair , burial place . [ ’ S chìthinn cnaimhean Eoghainn Ruaidh / ’ N carraigh Chluainidh an tasgaidh ,
PB , 239 ; Gu n - ur cuir far ’ m bu dual dhuibh , / Ann an carraigh nan uaislean ,
id . , 310 ; Tha cuideachd mhòr de ’ m chairdean ann / An tasgaidh bhuain fo ’ n fhòid ; / ’ S ged theid mi dh ’ fhios an carraighean , / Cha ’ n fhaigh mi guth am beoil ,
id . , 315 ; Thug pailteas làmh gu cairidh e ,
id . , 285 . An extension of caraidh , cairidh ,
E . Ir . cora , weir ? ]

carran , carraigean [N . Uist cairrchdean] . A species of seaweed much used for food , carrigeen moss . It is nutritious , but its value is often lost by the mistaken process of bleaching . Preparations from carraigean are called carran ,
as sùghan carrain , làgan carrain ,
carrigeen pudding ; easan carrain ,
carrigeen gruel ; lite carrain ,
carrigeen porridge .
A woman in Uist sang [the relevance of this is not clear] :

Guma fallain am bliadhna
Ailean riabhach mo rùin - sa ,
Ris na dhealaich mi anmoch ,
Tha do mheanm ’ orm mar chùram .

Nam biodh to ag òl fìona
Mar dhìolt air luchd sùgraidh , [sùghain ?
Nàile bheirinn mo bhriathar
Cha duirt Diarmad Ó Dùinne . [sic

Cha diochd fhad ’ s tha mi ’ g éisdeachd
Ri bléidrich mo mhàthar ,
A ’ sìor mholadh Sir Ailein , [recte , Sìol
Ceann - alla nam meàirleach , [recte , Cinn
’ S a liutha caile dhubh shuarach [shalach
Bhiodh a gruag air dhroch càramh [falt
Bho na dh ’ òl thu ’ n deoch bhainne —
Meadar carrain a b ’ fheàrr dhut .
[Mary , daughter of Alexander the Red , said to her mother that she was seven times sick and tired listening to her flattery , and said she : ]

More than long am I listening to the wheedling of my mother , ever praising Sir [recte , the race of] Allan , very chief of the thieves , and the many worthless hussies whose hair would be in ill array since [recte , from whom] thou didst drink the milk drink — a cogue of ‘ carran ’ had fitted thee better .
carran - midhg ( mìg ) , cailleach - mhidhg ( mhìg ) . [A kind of spider found among sand . ] A rime among children in Uist was :

Carran - midhg !
Carran - midhg !
Dhomhsa meadhg !
Dhomhsa meadhg !
No diongam na casan dhìot .
