Cailleach - mhidhg !
Cailleach - mhidhg !
Stad do dheann !
Stad do dheann !
No bheir mi ’ n ceann ’ s na casan dhìot .
( No cuirim call nan casan ort . )

This spider emits a grey fluid very like whey . The lines were addressed to the spider ; if the fluid was not emitted the threat was carried out . No one knows how the rime originated or why it is continued . [Cf . damhan - alla . ]

an carrs .
The buttercup . It was applied instead of a poultice . Tha an carrs faisg air a ’ ghobhair chon a comhnadh ,
the buttercup is near the she - goat to protect her .

cartan .
See giùran , giughran . [cartan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cas .
See corrail .

casa cainibe , casa cainbe .
The rays shooting out under the sun , a sign of bad weather . Casa cainb na gréine , gaoth agus uisge ,
the ‘ hempen legs ’ of the sun , wind and rain . [casan - cairbe , casachain - gréine ,
Dw . casa - cearbain , casan - cainbe ,
MacL . Other forms are casan - cearban ( Bernera , Lewis , TGSI , xxxvii , 19 ) , casan - ceirb ( Ness , Lewis ) , casan - carbad ( Applecross ) , casa ( n ) - cairbinn . ]

cas - arain , casarain .
Toaster , bread - toaster . [Cf . crann - arain ,
s . v . faircill . ]

cas - chrom .
Bent spade ( ii , 246 ) .

cas - dhìreach .
A narrow spade made for delving and delving only . [cas - dhìreach , Fr . Allan . ]

càthadh .
Winnowing corn in the barn — the first operation ; the second and final operation was fasgnadh ,
winnowing on the knoll . The toll - càthaidh ,
‘ chaff - hole ’ , was a small hole about three feet square in the back wall of the kiln to admit wind to clean the corn . This hole was on the ground and , when not required , was closed with a board , or a plàt made of straw or bent or rushes .

cathail = dripeil ,
busy .

cathan .
Warping on the floor . [cathan ,
yarn on the warping machine , Dw . ]

cathul , cathuil .
A group , cluster , farmstead , all the houses on a farm . The word occurs in the following lines attributed to an ecclesiastic who is said to have been insane and to have lived seven years with the deer in the mountains :

Is blàth a bhuil air [a chruth
Luchd bristidh na Sàbaid ,
Luchd nam briathar ’ s nam mionnan
As lìonar uile shliochd Adhaimh ,
Gum bi iadsan ’ nan cathuil ,
Mar dheamhain air càraid , [dub . lect .
Agus Crìosda Fhé gealltainn
Nach seall e gu bràth riu .

Clear its effect on the people who break the Sabbath , the people of blasphemy and swearing who are the most numerous of the seed of Adam , they shall be in groups like the devil incarnate [devils who have multiplied ( ? ) ] , and Christ Himself promising that He shall never behold them .

cé .
See anagladh .

ceairle .
See cuach fhraoich ; corra - chrosgag .

cealach .
Flue , the flue of a kiln , the fire - place in a kiln . Cealach fada fiar ’ s aghaidh ’ san iar - ’ eas ,
a flue long and curved facing the south - west . This was the kind of flue the old people desired in their kilns . The SW was the source of their prevailing winds . [ceallach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

ceamp .
A spinning ‘ darg ’ or competition . This kind of competition was common in Perthshire down to the middle of the nineteenth century . All the maids and matrons of the village met in one another ’ s houses and competed keenly at the ceamp ,
quantity for quantity and quality for quality . In spinning lint it was common to have two threads going at the same time , one in each hand . This needed great skill and dexterity and could only be done with lint , not wool . [Sc . kemp . ]

ceangal .
See nasg .

ceannag ; cianag , cionag ; ceapag .
A small piece of land . ceannag nam bochd ,
a piece of land given to the poor . [For ceannag cf . ceann - mhàg ( recte ceannmhag ) , Dw . McB compares cionag ,
defined as a small portion of land , a fourth of a cleitig ,
or an eighth of a “ farthing ” land , with Ir . cionóg , a small coin . ]

ceannaire .
A person leading the horses in the plough with a hand in the reins of the two front horses and walking backwards . [In E . Ir . cennairem ; the rear ploughman was tónairem . Cf . DB , l . 1756 n . ]

ceannaire .
The head rig in a field . [Also ceannmhag ,
cf . ceannag . ]

ceann - dubhan = ceann - phollan , - phollag ,
tadpole . The tadpole is also called ceann - simid .

ceann - dubhan .
The black - headed gull . The more correct form is ceann - doghan ,
‘ singed head ’ , from the pale black singed appearance of the bird ’ s head .

ceann - làidir = crois - iarna ,
for which see Dwelly .

ceann - simid .
See ceann - dubhan and simid .

ceap .
Turf laid over a grave , a grave . Is caomh liom an ceap aige ,
I love his turf , i . e . his grave . The word is used when turf , and not a stone , covers the grave , as leac ,
flag , is used for grave when a stone , not turf , covers the grave . sgrath ,
divot , is not applied to the covering laid on a grave though it is applied to grassy turf used for other purposes . [ceap ,
a sod , Fr . Allan . fòd , fòid is also used in this sense and is differentiated from the doublet fàd ,
peat . ]

ceapag .
See ceannag .

ceap - clogaid .
Vizor .

cearamh [ceathramh ? ] - dubh .
Black spaul . The blood of the animal becomes black .

cearc - fearainn .
Every tenant under a tighearna or fear - baile was bound to give him a fat hen on Latha Samhna ( Hallowmas ) . This was called a cearc - fearainn ,
and the tax was càin nan cearc ,
the kain or tax of the hens . On some estates a dozen or two dozen eggs must go with the hen . The writer saw yearly the Baileveolan tenants going across from Lismore to Druim a ’ Bhuic in Appin with càin nan cearc .

On some estates a man was appointed to collect the hens . He was called am maor - chearc ,
the hen - bailiff , and was held in great contempt .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , s . v . cas . ]

A mhic mhaoir ruaidh nam prat ,
Dh ’ am bu dual bhith ruag nan cearc ,
’ S e mo dhùrachd dhut mar chleachd
Thu bhith tuirling anns a ’ ch - c .

[cearc - fearainn ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cearc - mhara .
The lesser black - backed guillemot , gearra - breac , q . v . [cearc - mhara ,
not identified , Fr . Allan . ]

na ceàrdan .
The tinkers . On the high road between Ord and Urray , Ross , I saw an arrangement of stones that puzzled me much . There were five small heaps of small stones along the road , four of the heaps twenty - one feet apart and one thirty - nine feet from the nearest of these . There were just five stones in each cairn . No one could tell me what they meant . I found later that they were messages left by tinkers who had passed for those who were to follow .

ceàrd - tràghad .
See trotag - thràghad .

cearrarach .
Four - cornered . [Perhaps four - sided , from ceithir ,
four , and ochrach (
eochair ,
edge ) , or oireach ?
Cf . a dh ’ iarraidh a ’ Chupain Cheathraraich ,
‘ to seek the four - sided cup ’ , Waifs and Strays , iii , 44 . ]

cearrdubhan .
The sacred beetle . Other forms are cearrloman , cearraloman , gearraloman .
It is also called cearran dubh nan each ,
the black cearran of the horses , and cearran dubh nan creach ,
the black cearran of the forays . In the latter , creach is perhaps a corruption of each .
It is associated with horses probably because it deposits its eggs in horse - dung , which is more heating than any other . An observant person in the country in July , August or September will see the beetle rising and soaring in the air above his head with a strann ,
hum , and then suddenly descending with a thud into the horse - dung at his feet . [ceardabhan , carnabhan ,
Dw ; cern - dubán , Contrr . ]

ceasach = duine leasgach leathan làidir mì - chumadail , cliobastach ’ na chainnt , mì - sgiobalta ’ na aodach ,
a lazy well - built strong ungainly man , clumsy in his speech , untidy in his dress . See also ceus , cias ? [ceasach ,
ungainly , awkward , Dw . Cf . ceasadach ,
F . Allan ? ]

ceasal = ceasad ,
hiding , denying . [ceasad ,
grumbling for lack of a thing , Fr . Allan . Tog a d ’ cheasad , ’ s na bi leisg ,
AD , vi . See also JMC , l . 550 . E . Ir . cessacht , niggardliness , grumbling , Contrr . ]

ceasgach .
See ceus , cias .

céileach [céilidheach] .
Given to visiting houses overmuch .

Is coma liom dha ’ n té bhios céileach ,
Is tric a thug i breug a triall ;
Té mhullach nach aithnich a càirdean
Chan i as fhearr a chumas miamh .

Is coma liom dha ’ n té ribeineach rìomhach [riabhach
Nach dèan gnìomh air snìomhadh snàth ,
Nam faighinn an té bhanail bhiangheal [mhìngheal
Is i bu mhiann liom fhéin thar chàch ,

céirein , céirein leighis .
See spreaghan .

ceiseach .
A frail farm bridge across a drain or ditch for sheep and cattle , from ceis ,
wattle , the bridge being constructed of some form of wattle work . céiseach , céisleach are applied to a loosely formed frowsy woman , céisleach mhór mhnatha . [Different words are represented here . The word for bridge appears as ceasach ,
with short vowel , in both MacAlpine and Dineen . If so , it is not from céis ,
wattle , which appears to have the vowel long . Cf . ’ S lìonmhor treun óg ’ s maighdeann bheul - dearg , / Chuir e an céis le laimh ,
PB , 335 , with the note : Corpses were formerly enclosed in wicker - work coffins . Often they were merely laid in long withs bound round . céiseach ,
of a woman , is perhaps to be compared with ceusach , s . v . ceus , infra . ]

Céitean .
See Màrt .
céitean , céiteanach = piocach = saith .

ceòsach .
See ceus , cias .

ceotharn .
A bodyguard , thirteen in number , with a leader . [= ceathairne . ]

ceus - chrann , ceus - chrannd ( a ) . Luibh air an do shaltair ( sheas ) Iosa dar a bhathar ’ ga chur ris a ’ chrann - cheusta . Is e sin as adhbhar dha ’ n ainm . Tha an luibh a ’ fàs an àite clachach a measg nam beann . Ma tha dosgaidh a measg dhaoine cuiridh an luibh bheannaichte seo stad air . Cuirear a ’ cheus - chrannd os cionn ardoras a ’ bhàthaich agus ann an cachaileith na cuidhe . Tha i colach ri roinneach ach goirid .
— A plant on which Jesus stood when He was being placed on the cross . That is the reason for the name . The plant grows in stony places among the mountains . If people are suffering loss of cattle through any disease this blessed plant will check it . It is placed above the lintel of the byre and in the doorway of the fold . It is like fern but short . [céis , céis - chrannda ( from Carmichael ’ s lists ) , Fr . Allan . ]

ceus , cias .
Rough hair or grass , tufted grass , tufted heather . ceusach , ciasach , ceòsach .
Hairy , shaggy , untidy , rough , rugged , unkempt . ceusach , ceasach , ceasgach .
A clumsy person , a dowdy person , lazy man , big untidy woman . ceusach mhór bhoireannaich ,
a large , clumsy woman .

An guidhe rinn mise dha mo bhràthair ,
Nar ann dhà a laigheas gìomh ,
Ach dha ’ n a ’ chnocan chorrach chiasach
’ S air caigeann fhiadh a ’ ghlinn ud shìos .
The spell that I made to my brother , may not the harm fall on him , but on the tufted rugged knoll and on the two deer of yonder glen . [Cf . v , 152 , 160 . ]

[Again there are different words here . In ceusach mhór bhoireannaich the word is probably ceusach , ciasach , ceòsach ,
big - hipped . ceasgach does not belong here , nor does ceasach if the vowel is short . ]

ciall .
See rian .

cianag , cionag .
See ceannag .

cìlig .
Rock eel . [cìlean , cìlig .
Large cod fish , Dw , HSD , McA , AF . Cf . ON keila , a sea - fish allied to the cod . ]

cinnseal .
See breas .

cìob .
See rusan .

cìoch , cìoch - shlugain .
See sineag .

cìochan na mnà - sìdh .
See sìdhean mòr .

cion [lack ? ] . Nach cuir thu cion air a ’ chuilein choin sin agad ,
will you not ‘ extinguish ’ that puppy dog of yours ? Cuir cion air a ’ chat ghranda sin ,
‘ extinguish ’ that horrid cat . Cionaich an cat , ‘ extinguish ’ the cat , kill the cat . [Cf . cuir ceal air ,
put an end to it , ii , 248 ; iv , 184 , 220 , 290 . ]

ciopan , cipean .
See luirgneachan ; roith , raith , raoith .

cioraich .
See goillse .

cirb .
Skirt , fragment etc . ; dimin . cirbeag , cilbeag ,
bit , rag , corner [ cearb] .

cìrean - cròin .
Sea serpent . Seachd muca - mara sàthadh a ’ chìrein - chròin ,
the cìrean - cròin takes seven whales to satiate it . [Cf . cionaran - crò ,
i , 127 ; ii , 348 ; cean - chrò ,
Rel . Celt . , ii . 504 ; ceánnrobhán crón , Béaloideas , xv , 246 . See Campbell , Superstitions of the Scottish Highlands , 220 . ]

ciste mhine .
Meal chest , meal girnel for keeping the household meal . The meal is pressed with the hands and tramped with the feet in order to exclude air and prevent moisture .

ciuthal = cùil ,
corner ( Lismore ) .

clab cìocharain .
See mac - làmhaich .

clabar - nasg .
Tie to go round the neck of a cow in the stall .

clach Moire .
Hail - stone .

clach nathrach .
Serpent ’ s stone . A glass bead perforated from end to end . Man and beast are cured of sickness by drinking the water in which the stone has lain . It is also called sgeith nathrach ,
serpent ’ s vomit . [See ii , 335 ; iv , 204 . It is also called glaine nathair , glaine nan Druidh ,
Smith ’ s Gaelic Antiquities , 53 ; Campbell , Witchcraft and Second Sight in the Scottish Highlands , 84 - 88 . See TGSI , xxxvii , 10 . ]

clacharan , clachran , cloichirean .
Stonechat ; with some , wheatear [see ii , 251] . The bird has often been found dormant in Coll ; ‘ fear dha na cadalaich , a rùin ’ ,
‘ one of the sleepers , my dear ’ , said a man in Coll who had often seen it thus .

clach sgonnaig .
See sgonnan .

clach - shuill .
Bait - stone for breaking shells etc . From soll ,
broken bait . faoise also means broken bait . [soll ,
Fr . Allan . ON sollr , swill . ]

clàd .
Wool comb . clàdan .
Little wool comb . From clàd ,
the burr with which the old people were wont to raise a lòinne ,
nap , upon the tweed . [Other way round ? ] The burr was called clàd , clàdan ,
and the working of it clàdaich ; clàdaich an clò ,
raise a nap on the tweed .

The name of the village , Clàidich , was possibly from clàd ,
wool comb . The place is mentioned in the pipe - tune ‘ Olc air mhath le Clann an t - Saoir ’ :

Olc air mhath le Clann an t - Saoir ,
Olc air mhath le Clann an t - Saoir ,
Olc air mhath le Clann an t - Saoir ,
Bha mi raoir an Clàidich .

cladach .
The higher portion of the shore , as opposed to tràigh ,
the lower strand . Hence feaman cladaich , faochag cladaich , bàirneach cladaich ,
shore seaweed , shore whelk , shore limpet , those being found on the upper shore ; but tràigh shìolag , tràigh mhuirsgean , tràigh shrùban , tràigh eisir , tràigh chreachann ,
sandeel strand , razor - fish strand , cockle strand , oyster strand , scallop - fish strand , the lower strand being the home of these . The sand - bank or sand - island sometimes left by the ebbing sea is oitir ,
and this is sometimes called oitir shrùban , oitir shìolag ,
cockle bank , sandeel bank , according to the shellfish prevailing on it .

cladhan .
A small trench , a channel ; hence what is transmitted by one ’ s ancestors , heredity ; atavism . Thus ’ ag earbsa a t ’ athair agus as do sheanair agus as do shinn - seanair agus a cladhan do shinnsireachd ,
you relying on your father and your grandfather and your great - grandfather and the hereditary qualities of your ancestors . Bu toigh liom mo chladhan fhìn ,
I would like mine own heredity , mine own creed . An cladhan againn fhéin , gleidhidh sinn e ,
our own heredity / creed we will keep .

claidheamh .
Sword . Swords were made on the island of Soay on the south - west of Skye in 1745 . They were made in a cave for concealment , brushwood being cut down to make into charcoal to temper them .

clàr càise .
A slice of cheese . See sgiath ime .

cleasachd .
See balachd .

cléireach .
See beòshlainte .

cleit ,
pl . cleiteachan .
A piece of land surrounded by the sea but accessible on foot at low water , a rock in the sea . cleit an ròin ,
the seal ’ s tidal island ; cleite feòra ,
rich pasture . See deise . [cleit ,
Fr . Allan . ON klettr , rock , crag . ]

cliab .
A span . cliabadaich .
A spanning . [cliabadaich ,
rough caressing , horse play , Fr . Allan . Cf . An coileach anns a ’ chliabadaich ,
MC , 284 . ]

cliabh .
See clogad ; nasg .

cliar .
Reeds bound together by cords and burnt by fishermen upon oidhche Fhéill Sheathain ,
St John ’ s Eve . The cliar was burnt generally upon the seashore , but sometimes in the boat at sea , while a rann ,
rune , was intoned to Rìgh na mara ,
King of the sea , to send fish . No word of this curious hymn is now obtainable . In Ireland the people practised the same rite .

cliath .
See Samhain .

clisgeadh .
See tapag .

cliumb .
Deformed . cliumbach . A deformed person , a person with a deformed or withered hand or foot .

clogad .
Helmet , literally bell - hat . Also the head of a still . clogad is cliabh [cliath] na staile ,
the head and the worm of the still . [an ceann and a ’ chliath ,
Dw , s . v . poit - dhubh . ]

clòinteach , clòimhnteach .
Brown down or fluff , brown mildew . clòimhnteach liath .
Grey or blue mould , as on jam kept too long . [clùindeach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cluaisean .
See buidhean .

cluan , cluanas .
Close friendship . [i , 82 , 210 ; iv , 40 ; v , 312 . ]

cluaran .
See crualan .

cluich / cluichd an fhéidh .
The deer ’ s play , name of a game .

clup , clupad , clupadadh .
See glup .

cluicheirean .
See clacharan .

cnamal .
Skeleton . [cnàmhal ? ]

cnap .
Lump , knob . A term applied to dough carried on the person in travelling on a journey — a simple effective mode of carrying food . [Cf . an ullag ,
dough of oatmeal ground in the quern — Lewis . See Dw . ]

cneapag .
The first thread put on the fearsaid ,
spindle ; it was in form a round ball ; thereafter the thread was put crosswise and called crosgag .
See crosgag . [cniabag ,
Fr . Allan , which suggests we read cnèapag . ]

cnèapan , cnèapal .
A ‘ creepie ’ , stool , a small low sitting place . [Cf . cnèapan ,
TGSI , xxii , 41 . ]

cnò .
Nut . The nuts which are washed up on the shores of the Western Isles , supposed to be carried from the Gulf of Mexico by the Gulf Stream , go under the general name of cnothan bàchain ,
sg . cnò bhàchain ,
‘ ocean nuts ’ . [Cf . cnò - bhachaill , cnò - bhàchair ,
Dw . ] They are of various sizes and colours . One of the largest is flattish and snuff - brown and in

days of snuff - taking was used as a snuff - box . Another flattish smaller nut has a white rim round it singularly like the silver eye of a horse . This is called cnò airgid ,
silver - rimmed nut . Another is round and dark - brown with two depressions at right angles across the middle . This is called cnò Mhoire , cnò Moire ,
nut of Mary , crois Moire , crois Mhoire ,
cross of Mary , and àrna Moire ,
kidney of Mary . This is mounted in silver and consecrated on the altar . It is used by nurses attending parturient women and pressed in the hand by women in labour to distract attention . Another nut is nearly round , larger than a bean and cream - coloured . It is called cnò odhar ,
dun nut , cnò Odhrain ,
St Oran ’ s nut . The cnò spuing ,
sponge nut , is the largest molucca bean cast on the western shores . Sometimes it is opened at one end , cleared of its kernel , and used as a snuffbox or mounted in silver as a match - box . [Another MS . version has it that the cnò Moire is cream - coloured , whereas the àrna Moire is the black nut , with the cross on it . See àirne Moire , cnò Moire ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cnò bhreac .
The speckled - shell snail . The snail in the shell was put in water and the water given to sufferers from jaundice . Pounded , it was applied as a poultice for sores and bruises , and to the forehead in lieu of leeches . The snail was also used as a bait in fishing . [cnò - bhreac ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cnò / cnù chaoich [chaoch ? ] .
A nut without a kernel ; also a shrine .

cnoc .
Knoll ; wisdom [see ii , 253 - 256] . cnocach .
Wise . See toradh .

Théid an crodh dh ’ an mhonadh ,
Té air thoiseach , té air dheireadh ,
Gille cruaidh cnocach rompa ,
Is gille cnocach cruaidh ’ nan deaghaidh .

cochair .
Gift , small gift , gift given with good grace . [cochair ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cochull - cinn .
See currac - rath .

coidhean / coidhein ( bleoghain ) .
Like the buidhean ( q . v . ) , this was made in size suitable to the crofters ’ cows . It was generally made of white and black staves ( clàr geal agus clàr dubh ) . There were twelve staves , the twelfth six inches or so higher and also thicker than all the rest . This was the handle . The condition of the coidhein indicated the good or ill condition of the bean - bhleoghain ,
milkmaid — if it was specially clean it showed she might be trusted to make butter and cheese and annlan of many kinds . If not , she was deposed from her high office . The staves should show their original colours and the hoops their whiteness . The noigean was the wooden cup , the small wooden vessel used in milking sheep and goats ; when full it was emptied into the coidhean or cuman . [Cf . E . Ir . coidiu , a standing - cup , Contrr . ]

coilchionn .
Short corn , as after a dry summer . [coilchinn ,
ii , 324 . Cf . caoilcin ,
a shrivelled person or animal , Dinn ? coilchean ,
Fr . Allan . ]

coill .
Light , faint light , dawn . coill , coilleagaich an latha ,
the first faint streaks of light . The various stages in the dawning of the day were : 1 . coill . 2 . glòmaich . 3 . camhanaich . 4 . glasadh . coilleachadh a ’ chlò ,
brightening the cloth , putting lustre on the cloth after the waulking . [But cf . coinnleachadh ,
winding of cloth on a stick in order to dress it , Dw ; coinneal ,
rolling up , Fr . Allan . ] Latha Coille ,
New Year ’ s Day , Day of Light ; Latha Féill Coill ,
Day of the Feast of the Circumcision . Hence coill ( e ) - bliana ( i ) n = teine mara = teine - sionn ( achain ) ,
phosphorescence on the sea . [coille - bionan ,
Dw ; caille - pianan , caille - bianain ,
Lewis ; coile - blianain , caora - blianain , goile - blianain , goile - Brianain , coinnlean - Brianain ,
Fr . Allan . The first element in these forms is probably an unstressed form of cainnle , coinnle ,
pl . of cainneal , coinneal ,
candle . See cailbeag - shìonain . In Latha Coill , Latha Féill Coill ,
the word is probably a syncopated genitive form ( Coiln ( e ) )
of Calainn ,
Lat . Calendae . Cf . Oidhche Choinnleadh ,
OL , 86 ; Chumadh a choinneal sa ’ Nollaig ,
Gill - easbuig Grannda , 153 . See coinneal . ]

coimhe , coimheach .
Protector . [Cf . E . Ir . coimde , safety , security . But perhaps it represents E . Ir . coimdiu , lord . ]

coineibh , coineibheadh , coineibhein , coineibhinn , coineibhinneadh , coineibheineadh .
‘ Extremis ’ , desperate distress , extreme tension , climax , the end of all things . Coineibheineadh a ’ bhàis ,
extremes of death .

Ann an coineibh mo bhàis ,
Ann an onaghail na h - anail ,
O ! a Mhic Mhoire nan gràs ,
Biodh do dhà làimh ma m ’ anam .

O Ìosa nan gràs ,
’ S Tu mo shlàinte gach uair ,
Ann an coineibhein mo bhàis
Biodh do dhà làimh ma m ’ chuart .

[coinbhein ,
Fr . Allan . ]

coinein - mara .
See magairle mór .

coingheall .
See leasacha làmha . [caineal ,
Fr . Allan , 257 ( better caingheall ) . ]

coinneal .
This is a rounded stick , thicker than a walking - stick , on which it is customary to roll the newly made tweed after it is waulked . The process must be carefully done . The end of the web is placed round the coinneal ;
it is evenly smoothed out ; the web is then evenly and tightly wound round and round till it is altogether rolled firmly . After the cloth is left thus for some time it has undergone a vast improvement in appearance . It is as if dressed by a siosdair [cf . sisteal ,
flaxcomb , Dw] .

’ Ga chur air choinnlean [MS . choillean] = dèanamh roillean dheth ,
making a roll of it . [coinneal ,
Fr . Allan . ]

coinneal - bhuaic .
A candle made by twisting round a piece of linen or cotton and dipping it in grease or tallow or fat of some kind and allowing it to cool . Sometimes this impromptu candle is dipped in cold water to cool and stiffen it . [buaic E . wick ? ]

coinneasg .
Emulation , rivalry , especially in reaping .

coinnleag .
Strife , striving , especially in the harvest field among reapers , who shall be first done reaping the corn . In Uist this is cailleach ,
in Skye gobhar bhacach .
This strife is farpais . [It would seem that coinnleag is really a name for the cailleach or gobhar bhacach ?
For origin one might compare coimhlig ,
Fr . Allan , caimhligeadh ,
N . Uist , competing in running , racing against somebody ; com - ling - . ]

coinnlean , coinnlein .
Nostril . [Also cuinnean , cuinnlein .
The word is not explained by MacBain . In Kirk ’ s Vocabulary the form is cuingiona na sron ,
the nostrils , SGS , v , 83 , which suggests it is from cumhang ,
narrow . ] Tha an leth - choinnlein aca druidte ,
one of their nostrils is closed , is said of the fairies .
còir . [Just , upright . ] Has the meanings ‘ good - tempered , hospitable , generous ; proud , uppish ’ ; duine còir may mean ‘ a man of pride arising from means and power . ’

Is duine còir fear dà bhó ,
Is duine ’ s còire fear a trì ,
Agus fear nan cóigeamh mart
Chan fhaigh còir no ceart bho fhear nan naoi .

[A satiric verse , with a pun on còir ,
just , etc . , and còir ,
justice . Cf . O ’ Rahilly , Dánfhocail , no . 37 ( p . 7 ) and p . 66 ; NGP , 229 ; Dialect of Donegal , 195 . ]

cois - cheum coilich .
A certain step , a certain measure . Tha cois - cheum coilich air là na bliadhn ’ ùir ,
there is a cock ’ s step upon the day of the New Year ( OS ) , a certain degree of lengthening . The cock took the hens a little farther afield that day . [The proverb cois - cheum coilich agus a sgròban làn ,
a cock ’ s pace with his crop full , suggests it is something gradual , slow and stately . ]

còisir .
See beulaiche .

coitilean .
A puny boat , an exceptionally small boat for waveless lakes and tarns . Dimin . of coit ( e ) . [Borrowed into Eng . as cot . coite ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . le coite beag an dà ràmhain ,
OL , 24 . See also ib . 1 , 38 , 56 , 57 , 77 coit ,
ferry - boat , T , 23 , 131 ; coit an dà ràimh ,
Duanaire , 33 ; coite bheag is dà ràmh oirr ’ ,
MC , 194 ; nam biodh agam coite bhiorach , / ’ S seisear ghillean air chùl ràmh ,
ib . 364 ; see also ib . 56 , 287 . ]

colpachd .
Young animals ’ rearing . [Cf . E . Ir . colpthach , a heifer , Contrr . ]

comachadh .
Commonty , produce of crop common to all the crofters of the townland . Generally a crop exposed and liable to damage . [E . Ir . com - buid , a being together , companionship , partnership ; com - buitecht , partnership , Contrr . ]

comain .
Companion , friend , bosom - friend , guide , guidance , guardian angel . An t - aingeal comaineach ,
the communing angel . Also an t - aingeal comachaidh , an t - aingeal coimheadaidh ,
the guardian angel [Michael ; cf . iii , 158] .

comhach , cumhach .
A guest . Tha e air chomhach ,
he is on ‘ guesting ’ . comhachd .
Hospitality . Duine còir comhachdach ,
a man generous and hospitable . [Ir . comhthach , a companion . ]

comhart coin . Dar a tha cù a ’ comhart gun adhbhar ,
when a dog barks for no reason . Tabhann , dar tha cù an sàs ann am beothach ,
tabhann is barking when a dog is pursuing animals . [Cf . TGSI , xli , 367 . Cha mhisde a ’ ghealach na coin a bhith comhartaich ( deileann ) rithe ,
the moon is none the worse of the dogs barking at her , NGP , 104 . deileann ( q . v . ) is another word for barking . ]

còmhla .
See leasgadan .

còmhlaiche [comhdhálaiche] .
A person ( or thing ) who meets another person on a journey either by accident or assignation . Some persons are lucky to meet and some unlucky — deagh chòmhlaiche and droch chòmhlaiche .
A man or woman of high moral character , a fair girl , a fair woman were good còmhlaichean .
The reverse were bad . A deformed person and a woman with brick - red hair were bad . [Cf . Scotland and Scotsmen , ii , 457 : ‘ Much of the success in any work or enterprise is believed to depend on the comhlaiche ,
or first person or creature that presents itself . Thus upon going to sport , it is reckoned lucky to meet a horse , but very unfortunate to see a hare if she escapes . And on meeting any person or animal whom repeated experience has pronounced an unlucky comhlaiche ,
it is deemed some remedy if a stone is rolled towards him or it . ’ See also Henderson , Survivals in Belief , 227 ; Superstitions of the Scottish Highlands , 253 - 254 . Còmh[dh]alaiche ,
Fr . Allan . ]

comhuil , comhail , comhaill .
Womb , chest , trunk , receptacle , store , treasure - house .

comraig .
See currac - rath .

comul , comal .
Assembly , gathering .

conadal . Bó chonadail , chonnadail ,
a strayed cow , a cow whose owner is not known . Bó chobhrach , bó chonadail ,
a strayed cow is a helpful cow . [The meaning of the latter is not clear . Perhaps cobhrach is not from cobhair ,
assistance , but from cobhar ,
froth , foam . ]

conachan .
A cross - tempered angry man . conachag .
A cross - tempered angry woman . conachair .
Wrathful . Na bi conachd ris ,
do not be quarrelling with him . Sin a chuir am breallach breac a thaigh a ’ chonachair ,
‘ that was what sent the surly to the surly ’ — an old proverb . A chrochaire ’ s a chonachaire !
Thou villain and thou rascal !

Chunna mi cath conachair triùir
A ’ comhrag dlùth mu chinn na mnè .
[Cf . v , 96 , where cath connachair is translated ‘ hound - loving battalion ’ . See Duan . Finn , iii , Glossary , s . v . conchar . ]

Cù conachair ,
the conachair dog , was a species of dog now never seen . It was not so big as the collie , but of finer form and firmer build and more lithe and active . The eye was large , prominent and intelligent , resembling that of the Arab horse . Its scent was very keen . The teeth were long and sharp and the roof of the mouth jet - black . The hair was short and dark , that under the tail about an inch long , and the tip of the tail white .

conail .
A form of conair ,
a rosary ; conail M ( h ) oire ,
rosary of Mary . [See ii , 256 . Cf . Ir . an choróin Mhuire , of which conair is a metathesized form . ]
Conan Corr = dreathan - donn ( q . v . ) , the wren . [See iv , 6 ; and cf . Waifs and Strays , v , 121 ; CR , vii , 371 ff . ]

conasg .
See càrn .

conn .
Bond , bind , binding , clasping , securing , clamping , keeping together . conn an iarna ,
the binding of the hank . conn a ’ mhairbh ,
the binding of the dead . conn dhaoine ,
the binding people . conn cuideachd ,
keeping society together . [Cf . conn ,
lease - band or water - band , dividing the cuts in a hank of yarn ; thread tying a hundred ( sic ) of yarn for weaving , base - bands , Dw . ]

contrachd .
See tapag .

còp .
To force to believe , ‘ to thriep ’ . Bha e còpadh orm ,
he was trying to make me believe .

copag Phàdraig , cuach Phàdraig .
Plantain ; but copag = docken . The leaf , like the deanntag ,
nettle , stops bleeding . [cuach - Phàdruig ,
Fr . Allan . ]

corc - eigidh [ - eagaidh ? ] .
A knife used by tinkers in cleaning the inside of a new spoon . Cf . leigeis .

corcach .
Short - eared . Bó chorcach ,
short - eared cow . Laogh corcach ,
short - eared calf . Of old such were believed to be a cross between the tarbh - uisge ,
water bull , and a land cow .

corr .
Opening in a creel . [cor[r] - oiseanan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

corran fiaclach .
See searran .

corr .
Heron . The heron is wary and hard to approach ; hence the saying in the Western Isles : Cha sealgair thu gu marbh thu corr is ròn is lachain ,
‘ thou art no hunter till thou hast killed heron , seal and duck ’ . The mainland saying is different : Cha sealgair thu gu marbh thu corra - ghritheach , fitheach agus fiadh ,
‘ thou art no hunter till thou hast killed heron , raven and stag ’ . Again : Aois sealgair , seachd corra - ghritheacha a mharbhadh ,
‘ a hunter ’ s lifetime ( time ) to kill seven herons ’ . Again : Ghoideadh tu

Gu bheil cuid de mhnathan ann
Dh ’ am bheil gean a ’ mhadaidh - ruaidh ;
Bheireadh iad as na corran car ,
Mhealladh iad fear an dara h - uair .

An tig na ’ n téid thu , chailleach ,
Na ’ n ith thu feòil corra - ghritheach ?

An tig thu na ’ n téid thu , chailleach ,
Na ’ n ith thu feòil curra ?
This called out through the keyhole of the door cured the sick person within . [But see EL , pp . 52 - 53 , for a different explanation . ]

corra - bheannach , - bhinneach , caora - bheannach , - bhinneach .
A horned sheep . See caora - bheannach .

Air a shlàinte , chorr - bhinneach ,
’ S ann dhut thug mi ’ n gràdh gun iris ,
Ma gheobh mi thu air làimh gun sireadh ,
Is inniseach mo spréidh - sa .
Thine health , corra - bhinneach , ’ tis to thee I gave the love without limit , should I get thee by the hand in asking [recte , without seeking it] meadow full of flocks were mine .

corracha - cìoch .
Small red insects in the strand .

corrachd .
The death oath . See mionn .

corrachd .
See talcas .

corra - chnàmh , corra - cnàmh .
When a milkmaid has no stool upon which to sit she bends her knees half forwards , and , placing her skirt upon her heels , she sits upon her heels while milking . Tha a ’ bhanachag air a corra - cnàmh ,
the milkmaid is sitting upon the backs of the legs , in a semi - sitting posture . [Shaw , Folksongs and Folklore of South Uist , 201 . Cf . corra - biod ,
tip - toe . ]

corra - chrosgag , corra - chrosdag , corra - chriosgag , corra - chriosdag .
A term applied in Uist to a woman who pretends to be good at calanas ,
wool - working .

Phòs an gille còir a ’ chorra - chrosgag agus chaidh e air taigheadas dha fhéin . Bha leòm gu leòr air m ’ a leòmaig agus e an dùil gur e fhéin a fhuair a ’ bhean - taighe . Ach cha b ’ fhada mar sin gun an robh gach aodach agus gach sgòd , gach anart , gach bròg agus osan a fhuair e bho mhàthair ’ nan riollagan agus ’ nam piollagan agus ’ nan criathar tholl . ‘ A Mhàiri , fiach an cuir thu an t - snàthad mhór an sàs , fiach an cuir thu greim anns a ’ bhrigis dhomh a thairrneas i ri chéile gus mo nàire a chomhdach dhomh , agus greim anns an stocaidh a chumas i gun mi ’ ga call . ’ ‘ A ghràidhean nan daoine , is niarachd dhut - sa , a ghaoil , gun aodach agus gun anart , gun bhrògan agus gun osain a bhith agad agus a liu ceairle mhór mhath agus crosgag mhìn bhlàth tha agam - sa ann an cùil an t - snàth a ’ feitheamh ort . ’ Agus reaghadh am boireannach a null agus bheireadh i a nall crosgag agus ceairle shnàth a fhuair i bho a màthair . Bheireadh i cromadh no dhà as a ’ cheairle agus thomhaiseadh i cas agus calp an duine air paidhir osan a dhèanamh dha . Thilgeadh i sin a ’ cheairle agus a ’ chrosgag air ais do chùil an t - snàth agus theireadh i , ‘ Seo , bitheadh sibhse sin gun an cuir mise feum oirbh , far a bheil gu leòr eile dha bhur seòrsa . ’ Mu dheireadh thall bhàsaich maolan bochd anns a ’ chladach fheamad leis an fhuachd agus rinn leòmag tuirim bhàis dha :

This occurred long ago , but the name of the corra - chrosgag is still remembered in Uist and still causes much merriment among the people . The machairs of Uist are singularly bare , bleak and cold in winter and spring , and to withstand the bitter blasts which sweep along these sandy seaside plains the people must be well clad . On this account when a man is seen walking rapidly along the machair it is not unusual to hear the remark , Is i a ’ chorra - chrosgag tha aig an fhear ud ,
‘ it is the corra - chrosgag that man has ( for wife ) ’ . Another saying of like import among the people is , Is luath fear na droch mhnatha air a ’ mhachair Uibhisteach ,
‘ swift is the man of the bad wife on the machair of Uist ’ . It is rarely that a man or woman is ill clad in Uist ; the Uist women , excellent and industrious at calanas ,
take pride in having their families comfortably clothed .

corra - ghille .
Long - legged lad . Ithidh an gearra - ghille uiread ris a ’ chorra - ghille ,
‘ the squat fellow will eat as much as the lank fellow ’ . [Cf . Co as an corra - ghiullan glas ?
HM , ii , 430 . ]

corra - ghleus .
The edge of a knife .

corra - liod .
Curlew .

corra - margaidh .
Hanger - on at a public place . [Cf . JMC , l . 1053 n . ]

corr - òinseach .
Some kind of bird ( ? ) . [Of a woman : Liuthad còrr oinnseach a thà / Faotainn ionad a ’ s áite féisteil ,
T , 11 . ]

corra - ruadh .
Crane ( bird ) .

corra - sgriach / sgritheach .
See tàsg .

corrail .
Cross , cross - tempered ; much the same as cas ,
short - tempered . corralach ( Uist , Skye ) , curralach ( Islay ) , uneasy , fretty . [cor - , cur - in MS . ]

corran - sacaidh .
Pack - saddle for burdens of straw etc . [Cf . curran shachdachaidh . ]

corr - bhleoghan .
The night - jar , goatsucker .

còs .
See tabhal .

cosda [ - ò - ? ] . Two neighbouring crofters ploughing together . [Cf . còmhstadh ,
accommodation , obligation ; loan ; favour , Dw ? ]

cosgairneach .
A brave , a hero . [ cosgair ,
slay ? ]

cràdach .
See àn .

cràidhean . Air na cràidhean seo fhéin ,
in this same neighbourhood . [See crath . ]

crà - leap .
See caiseil .

crannachan .
In Kintail crannachan means uachdar air a bhualadh ,
cream beaten or frothed , and this again is the same as fuarag ,
crowdie . crannachan Samhna = Hallowmas crowdie , ordinarily fuarag Shamhna .

crann - arain .
See faircill .

cranna - chealgail .
See Conan Corr .

crannag .
See bréid .

crann - gath ( sic ) . Spear pole , pole axe , a pole for sounding the depth of the sea . [Cf . Crann geatha ’ na ’ d laimh aodhairtach ,
E , 350 ; and see Fr . Allan , s . v . geadha , geamha . ]

crannghail .
See nasg .

cranna - ghlas .
Crane ( bird ) .

crannlach .
See Màrt - lacha .

crann - mheasan . Miosan , measan ,
a little dog , lapdog . Trod a ’ chranna - mhiosain ri cù crìon ,
the wrangling of the little dog with the old dog . [Cf . E . Ir . crann - chú , a lapdog ; mess , a fosterling , messán , a pet dog , lapdog . Cf . cranna - pheasan ,
RG , 45 ; probably a contamination product of cranna - mheasan . ]

crann - snàth .
See gual .

craobh .
See an eàrna dhearg .

craobh fo dhealt .
Sundew ( Kintail ) .

craoileag .
Creel . [craidhleag ,
Dw ; craidhleag ,
pron . kr ( oi ) l ' ag , Dieckhoff . ]

crath ,
pl . craithean [cràithean ? ] .
Farm road . An crath air an robh mi eòlach am òige ,
the road with which I was acquainted in my youth . Na craithean air an robh mi eòlach ,
the roads with which I was acquainted . An crath air a bheil an crodh = ùtraid ,
cattle road , by - road . [Cf . cràidhean . ]

cré = cridhe .
See caisneach .

creachann .
See cladach .

crì .
A form of cré ,
creed ; crì nan ostal ,
the Apostles ’ creed ( Kintail ) .

criann ( creann ? ) .
Drain gently , draw quietly ; water slowly percolating through porous soil ; stealing away quietly .

criathar .
See nasg .

crìonag .
See topan .

crionalach , criongalach .
Sufferer , one who suffers . Cringeallach was applied to a man who was hanged in Lismore . ‘ Có air bith an coirealach , is mise an crionalach ’ ,
‘ Whoever be the offender , I am the sufferer , ’ said James Stewart of the Glen when he heard of the murder of Colin Campbell of Glenure . [Ge b ’ e ’ n coireach , ’ s mis ’ an creanach ,
NGP , 193 . crìonglach ( misprinted crìodglach ) , creineach ,
Dw . Primarily creanalach ,

from the vb . crean ; creanaidh tu air ,
you will pay for it , you will suffer for it ; E . Ir . crenaid , buys . ]

crios .
Girdle . crios seunta ,
charmed girdle . crios croidhe na mnà - sìdh [no transln . ] . Diminutive criosan .

An criosan a thànaig o ’ n Bhòinne mhìn
Is truagh nach ann ri m ’ linn a bhà ,
dh ’ fhiosrachadh] A dh ’ ìsleachadh aigne nam ban bìth , [sìdh , loinn
A chrìonachadh fearg nam fear fàth . [bàn , fàr , blàr
The girdle that came from the gentle Boyne , pity it is that it came not in my time , to abate the minds of the silent women , to subdue the wrath of the angry men .

cris , crise , crisne .
Sacred , something sacred . Crise cridhe ,
sacred heart . Crise gràidh ,
sacred affection . Crisne rùin ,
sacred love . Crùn Chrìosda dha mo chrisne chridhe ,
the crown of Christ to the sacred one of my heart . Chrism , the sacred oil . [Cf . Ir . criosma . ]

Gheall mo leannan dhomhsa sgàthan
Anns am faicinn m ’ àilleachd féin ,
Is gheall mise crise dhà[ - san]
Ann an làthrachd cathair Dhé .

cris - crais , chris - chrais .
Criss - cross , confusion , upsetting . Chuir thu chris - chrais orm ,
thou hast upset me , confounded me . Chaidh a ’ chris - chrais orm an dé le dealain agus le torainn ,
the ‘ criss - cross ’ went upon me yesterday from lightning and thunder .

critheal .
A bank of gravel . [Cf . grioth ,
a gravel pit , pebble ; griothalach ,
gravel , McA . ]

cròcan .
A hook for lifting potatoes etc . ; a pothook . [Also crabhcan . Crabhcan was also 1 ) an implement for making rope ; 2 ) an ear - mark of a sheep , TGSI , xxxvii , 23 . cròcan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

crò - charbad , crò - leaba .
See caiseil .

crochaire .
See conachan .

crois .
See cnò .

cromach .
A bent person , bent man or woman , but not from age .

crom - mheur .
The brow antler of a stag . Hence crom - mheurach ,
a deer , a stag . The old people made use of every part of the deer . The deer was considered specially wholesome — dà mhiarach dhiag làn suill agus saill agus smior bho bharr a chabair gu sàil a luighein ,
the twelve - branched full of fat and of suet and of marrow from the tips of his horns to the heels of his hooves . The horns were crushed and boiled into jelly , candied sugar and honey added , the result resembling calf ’ s foot jelly .

crom - riabhach , croman - riabhach , crom - lòin , croman - riabhach an lòin .
Snipe . Also meannan - oidhche , q . v .

croma - ritheachan .
A skua .

crom - sgian , croma - sgian [cromsgian] .
A cooper ’ s knife . [Cf . Rainig croma - sgian o ’ n aog orm ,
T , 131 . ]

cropaig .
See bonnach gropaig .

crosadh .
See lach le linn .

crosan .
One of a set or band of players in a certain ancient game .

crosgag .
Crosswise , like a cross ; crosgag fhraoich ,
a certain length of rope made of heather arranged on the ground in the form of the figure eight ; crosgag shnàth ,
a certain amount of yarn arranged in the form of the figure eight ready for dyeing and for being wound up into balls . See corra - chrosgag ; cneapag .

crosgaileit , crosgalait .
Applied to a cap placed upon the heads of children at birth . Frequently the crosgaileit was kept upon a girl till she was confirmed . It was made of fine linen , with a cross , generally of red , embroidered on the forehead . [croisgileid ,
Dw . See barran . ]

crotal .
Lichen . crotal dearg ,
red or scarlet crotal , so called to distinguish it from crotal ruadh ,
red or russet crotal . It is somewhat rare . It is called ‘ the blood of the fairies ’ . [See fuil sìochaire . ] Women were wont to collect it and form it into small balls , about the size of golf - balls . These they sold to better - to - do neighbours , in Barra for sixpence , elsewhere for a shilling . Its dye is bright and beautiful and remains fast . sgreagag , sgreagag nan creag ,
is a hard kind of crotal .
There are four kinds of crotal in North Uist .

Cha b ’ e guirmean Dhùn Éideann
A bhiodh m ’ eudail - sa caitheamh ,
Ach an crotal ùr - fheannta
Bho cheanna nan carraig .

crothad .
Crowd . crothad chaorach . crothad arair ( ? ) . A ’ crothad mu ’ n teine .

cròthadh = geamhrachadh . [cròdhadh ,
housing of cattle in winter , Fr . Allan , 259 . ]

cruaidh .
See cailleach .

crualan .
A form of cluaran ,
thistle .

cruidhean cait .
See gadmann .

crùisgein .
See giuthas coinnil .

cruit .
A term of endearment ; mo chruit ,
my dear ; mo chruiteag ,
my darling .

cruth - bhainne , crutha - bhainne .
A wooden vessel shaped to the back for carrying home milk from the shieling . A band of leather , iris ,
attached to it at each side came round the upper part of the chest of the carrier . Sometimes it was plain and sometimes interlaced .

cuach fhraoich .
A heather couch , but more often a coil of heather rope ready to be made into a ball , ceairle . [cuach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

cuach Phàdraig .
See copag Phàdraig .

cuaille goirealaich .
See goirealach .

cuairt .
See faircill .

cual .
Fillet of linen , silk , etc . , starched with potatoes .

cudaig ruadh , sìol a ’ mhairt .
The young of the smalag ,
coalfish .

cudainn .
See gearra - breac .

cuibhreachan .
The cuibhreachan plant is used as a safeguard against spiriting away the toradh ,
substance , of the milk . It is placed under the milk - vessels . Any house that has it is safe against the wiles of witches and wizards . See caoibhreachan and caoireachan .

cuid .
See gaid .

cuideachd .
See conn .

cuigeal .
Distaff , consisting of a rod with three prongs at the end of the handle . It represents the Trianaid Naomh ,
Holy Trinity . It is banned to strike a boy or male beast with it [because this deprived them of their potency] , not so bad to strike a female . It was always in the hands of the women , in or out , at home or abroad . See topan .

cùil .
A stall in a byre . cùil - thaisg ,
pl . cùileagan - taisg ,
a recess or press in the wall of a house .

cùil .
See ciuthal .

cuilc .
Reed . It is now being used to thatch the houses of the paupers . So much do they detest it that some are giving up their relief rather than have the cuilc over them ; a great sacrifice , when the pittance they get , half a crown a month , is barely enough to keep soul and body together .

cùileag . Càin a ’ ghobha , toilleadh a ’ mhuilleir , cùileagan an fhigheadair .
These were three burdens or sgaid on tenants on Highland estates . The blacksmith , miller and weaver were , by unwritten law , provided for on every estate . The smith got so much from every man who had land , the miller got his multure and the weaver got a yearly present — butter , cheese or the like . For weaving he had , of course , a regular charge besides this . The word cùileagan is still known in Argyll and Skye . See mulchag bheirteachaidh ; sgaid . [In Lewis the weaver ’ s burden was bonntais a ’ bhreabadair ; bunndaist ,
HSD . Cf . càin , toinneamh , bunndaist ,
TGSI , xii , 366 . A stanza of the old version of ‘ Màiri Laghach ’ suggests that the joiner , tailor and tinsmith had also to be recompensed and that payment was due at Martinmas :

Ach ’ s iomad gnothach cruaidh
A th ’ air an tuathanach fhéin ,
’ N uair thig an Fhéill Màrtainn
Bidh a làn ’ na dhéidh :
Figheadair is tàillear
’ G iarraidh màil dhoibh féin ,
Saor is gobha ’ s ceàrd
A ’ togail càin a réis .
— cf . Poems and Songs , Rev . Duncan MacCallum ; Inverness , 1821 ; p . 176 . ]

cuilechion , cuilechionn , cuilchionn , cuilecheann .
Crooked , crafty ; cunning , guile , tricks . Two tribes of MacDonalds waged internecine war against one another for the possession of North Uist . One tribe was known as Sìolachadh Ghoraidh ,
the seed of Godfrey , and the other as Sìolachadh Mhurchaidh ,
the seed of Murdoch . A piper of the Godfrey MacDonalds composed a tune reflecting on the Murdoch MacDonalds :

Gu tràigh , gu tràigh Sìolachadh Mhurchaidh ,
Gu tràigh , gu tràigh Sìolachadh Mhurchaidh ,
Gu tràigh , gu tràigh Sìolachadh Mhurchaidh ,
Sìol dubh nan car ,
Sìol dubh nan car ,
Sìol dubh nan car ,
Sìol nan cuilechion .

[Assonance with Mhurchaidh shows that the word should be spelled cuilcheann ;
two syllables , with svarabhakti . ]

cuilidh .
Treasure , hoard , riches . Cuilidh Mhoire ,
the treasury of Mary , a kenning applied in Barra to the Western Ocean . A good woman in Berneray , Barra , was in sore distress over the impending famine among her people . As she lay awake wondering what she would do to mitigate the privations of her people , the form of a good woman who had died recently in Miu ’ alaidh appeared beside her bed , clothed in glory and light . Thubhairt an té a bha marbh ris an té a bha beò : ‘ Na bitheadh cùram ort , a ghràdhag nam ban , mu dheighinn cor do dhaoine ; is farsainn Cuilidh Mhoire . ’
( The one who was dead said to the one who was living : ‘ Let there be no anxiety upon thee , thou dear one among women . Wide is Mary ’ s Treasury . ’ ) That year there was an excellent fishing and there was no famine .

A large open bay below Baile nan Cailleach , Benbecula , is called Cuilidh from the abundance of seaweed for manuring the ground that lodges there . [cuile , cuile - Mhoire , cuilidh ,
Fr . Allan . E . Ir . cuile , a store - house , cellar , Contrr . Cf . Tha mo chuile gun ghràn innt ’ ,
MC , 358 ; Gur e cuille fridh nam beann ,
Gill - easbuig Grannda , 50 ; Cha ’ n eil ian a dhiath ma cuile ,
DMcL , 127 ; ’ S fasgach do chuilidh ’ s gur fiarach ,
G , 239 ; Chromadh a cheann sìos dha ’ n chuilidh ,
OL , 22 ; Cha ’ n ’ eil an cùil na ’ n cuilidh nach fhaic sùil a ’ Mhuilich ,
NGP , 110 ; ’ S pàirt de chuilidh na frìth ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 12 . ]

cuilig [cùilig ? ] .
On two opposite sides of the sorrag there is a stone of some size , and resting on these stones is the maide - sùirn across the sòrn of the kiln . Resting upon the horizontal bar are some sticks , the lower ends of which are resting on the sòrn .
These sticks are called cuiligean ,
pl . of cuilig .
Over this frame straw is laid . The construction looks like the flattish roof of a house . On this semi - roof the grain is laid to dry . See brat ; sorrag ; tarran . [See stiligean ,
Dw . ]

cuilm .
Hurry , quick rage , pricking . [Cf . culm ,
energy , push , liveliness , TGSI , xxii , 36 . ]

cuineal ( cuinneal ? ) .
Stem , straw . [Cf . cuinnlein . ]

cuing ( a ’ chuing ) .
See sac .

cuinnlein [MS . cuillein] .
Stubble .

Is math a dh ’ fhuineas bean a ’ mhuilleir ,
Is math a dh ’ fhaodas — ’ s math a cuinnlein .

[cuinnlein ,
stalk , Fr . Allan . Ruith a ’ chorrain air a ’ chuinnlein ,
OL , 108 . Singulative of E . Ir . connall , stubble . ]

cuisle , cuisleach , cuiseach .
A musical instrument , a pipe , small pipes . [Cf . E . Ir . cuisle , flute , Contrr . ]

cuit .
A disease ; cuit bhràghad ,
scrofula . [Ir . ( Donegal ) cuit bràghad , king ’ s evil , Dinn . ( s . v . easbaidh ) . ]

culan - coin .
Dog ’ s hiding , the bone or food that a dog buries for future reference . [Is this cùlan ?
Twice spelt culan in MS . and followed by cùl - cinn ,
outrun . ]

cùlanach .
See éiseanach ; màrnaich .

cùlcheallach ,
pl . cùlcheallaichean .
The wooden hinge of a door . [ cùl + ceangal , cùl + ceanglaichean ;
still used in Lewis . ]

cùl - cinn .
Outrun . [cùl - cinn ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . claigeann . ]

cuman .
Cogue , milking vessel . See binneal ; coidhean ; imdeal .

cumar .
Narrow . [A narrow , a strait ? i . e . cumar , comar .
Dr Carmichael says erroneously ‘ a form of cumhann , cumhang ’ . ]

cupall .
See biast - mhaol .

cùrainn .
See seòl .

currac - rath .
‘ Auspicious cap ’ , the caul or membrane occasionally born with a child ; also lìon - rath , q . v . It was much prized . In Tiree it is called léine shona ,
lucky shirt . Other names were currac comraig ,
enshrining [protecting ? ] cap , currac comhnaidh ,
protecting [assisting ? ] cap , cochull cinn ,
head cowl . [currachd - rath ,
Fr . Allan . ]

curran peatrais .
Rock carrot ; it grows in North Uist , where the writer has found it in the walls of an old house at Griminish . [curran phetruis ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Martin Martin : ‘ There is a large root grows among the rocks of this island lately discovered , the natives call it Curran - Petris , of a whitish colour , and upwards of two feet in length , where the ground is deep , and in shape and size like a large carrot ; where the ground is not so deep it grows much thicker , but shorter : the top of it is like that of a carrot . ’ ( 1934 ed . , p . 160 . ) ]

curran shachdachaidh .
A crate for horseback to convey seaweed etc . , with a lid below to let out contents . [Cf . corran sacaidh . ]

cusgartach . [sic ; read cù sgartach ? ] = cù fuadaich ,
driving dog . [ sgairt ,
loud cry , activity , bustle ? ]

cuthag .
Cuckoo . Ma tha aon dh ’ an teaghlach a ’ cadal ann an cùltaigh

no ann an sobhal agus gun tig a ’ chuthag agus gun téid no gun cluinnear i eadar an cùltaigh agus an taigh - comhnaidh anns a ’ mhadainn mhoich , tha sgarachdainn gu dol anns an teaghlach , is dòcha le fuath no le feirg no le fanabhas .
— If one of the household is sleeping in a back - house or in a barn and the cuckoo goes or is heard between the back - house and the dwelling - house in the early morning , a separation is to occur in the household , most likely by hate or by anger or by ‘ mild death ’ . [Rather , by sudden death ; fanabhas an + bàs ,
with prosthetic f . ]

daile .
Fear , confusion arising from fear .

dais ( e ) .
A heap or bank of corn , peats etc . ; daiseadh ( Uist ) , stacking hay ; ( Lismore ) banking corn in the straw in the end of the barn . [E . Ir . daiss , a heap , rick , stack , esp . of corn , RIA Dict . Cf . ON des , hayrick . ]

daiteach , daitheatach .
Regrettable . [Rather unsatisfactory spellings of doimheadach ,
in North Uist pronounced de ’ eadach , initial d non - palatal and the following e nasalised . In the MacNicol MS . doimheadas ,
spelt doideas ,
is found riming with roimhe so , coimhaoisean ; see Henderson ( who did not recognise the word ) , TGSI , xxvii , 387 . doimheadas ,
vexation , Fr . Allan . ]

dallaran deòir .
One blinded by tears .

damhan - alla , damhan - ealla , tamhan - eallaich = damhan - allaidh ,
a spider . [Many forms are found for ‘ spider ’ : doman - eallaich , trimean - eallaich ( Benbecula ) ; duman - eallaich , druman - eallaich ( S . Uist ) ; damhan - eallaidh , tarman - eallaich , draman - allach ( Harris ) ; poca salainn ( Loch Carron , Gairloch ) ; breabadair - ladhrach ( Lewis ) ; figheadair - fodair ( Glen Lyon ) . A large kind of spider found in sandy ground is carran - mìg ( S . Uist ) , cailleach a ’ mhìg ( Benbecula ) . ( Some of those listed above , e . g . poca salainn ,
may be of this variety ) . Somewhat similar are names for the dragon - fly : tarbhan - allaidh , tarbhan - arach ( Lewis ) ; daran - narach ( Harris ) . Fr Allan lists the following forms : damhan - eallaich [toman - eallaich] ; dreamhan - eallaich , daimhan - eallaich .
See Gaidoz , Le Nom de l ’ Araignée en Irlande , ZCP , vii , 450 . Cf carran - midhg . ]

daobh .
See saothair .

daobhaidh .
See tur .

daochaidh .
See tur .

daoine .
See conn .

daoirne .
Satiety . [Cf . gaoirne . ]

dao - reotha .
See famh .

daormann .
See frìd .

darag .
See slioc .

dealan .
Lightning . In a storm of lightning the people make the tongs red - hot in the fire and then hang them on the slabhraidh ,
pot - chain . It is supposed that the lightning strikes the hot iron and goes harmlessly up the chimney . In a violent storm of lightning and thunder a woman in

dealbh na beatha .
See gob na speireige .

dealg fionndrain .
A bronze pin , such as is found in the sandbanks in Uist . [Cf . Bha ursainnean ris do ’ n òr , / ’ S còmhlan do ’ n Iondrain ,
Waifs and Strays , iv , 105 ; Ochd ciad mion[n] do ionndrainn ,
id . , 155 ; Prìne fionndrainn ,
id . , 157 . This is E . Ir . findruine , some whitish metal , an earlier form of which appears to have been findbruine ; see O ’ Brien , Ériu , xi , 170 . ]

dealgan - feairt [feairste] .
Distaff . [feairste is a genitive form of fearsaid , q . v . ]

dealt - drùis , - rùis , - gréine .
See gadmann .

deannag .
See tapag .

deanntag .
See neanntag .

deàrnagan .
A small cake made on the hollow of the hand ( deàrna ) . [Cf . bonnach - boise . ]

deàrrais .
A keen disputation . [dìorras , diarras ,
Dw . diorrais ,
perpetual work , bustle , TGSI , xxiii , 86 . E . Ir . dígrais , fervour , zeal , earnestness . ]

deibleid [déibleid ? ] .
Untidy woman , dirty woman , slattern .

O ’ s tu féin an deibleid shalach ,
Chan fhacas ri m ’ ré té do choimeis
An Alba na ’ n Eire , Wales na Sasainn ,
Ach seana cheangal ballain air òcrach .

[Cf . geibleid ,
sloven , slattern , drabbish female , Dw ; déibhleid ,
feeble , awkward , unhandy person , id . ]

deighean , digheanach ( sic ) , deighidh .
Iceberg . [ eigh ,
ice . ]

deileann .
Noise , as barking of dogs ; deileann nan con ,
spontaneous and persistent barking of dogs , e . g . nach ann air na coin a tha an deileann .
Also the continued scolding of a scold : nach ann air an té ud a tha an deileann . Deileis ,
persistent arguing : cha chluinnim thu ach a ’ deileis ri cuideigin ,
I but hear you constantly arguing with somebody . Comhart nan con is deileann nam ban , dà rud nach b ’ airidh air diù ,
the barking of dogs and the scolding of women , two things not worthy of attention . See comhart . [Cf . ’ S olc a thrù nach tug an aire / Ma ’ n raibh thu cho labhara , dhàna ; / Nach è ’ n cù is cruaidhe dealunn , / Is doimhne a ghearras a nàmhaid ,
E , 318 . ]

deirbhlein .
Orphans . [See Scottish Studies , iv , 208 - 209 . In addition to the suggestions made there , the influence of deirbhéile ,
sorrow , on this form might be considered . deirilean ,
Fr . Allan . ]
deirein = season ? = grass growing in corn .

deise .
Dress . An deise , an t - aodach , an t - eudach , an t - earradh , an trusgan , an t - éideadh :
to the old people these terms denoted the kilt , the dress or

clothing par excellence ; any other clothing might be called anything . Bha an deis orm , bha an t - aodach orm ,
I was wearing the kilt .

Tuilleadh ’ s mo chean air an fhleasgach ,
Fhir dh ’ a math dh ’ an tig an deise ;
’ S tric bha mise ’ s tu a ’ beadradh
Ann an cleitean beinn a ’ cheò . [cleitich
I more than love the gallant , thou whom the kilt well becomes ; oft was I and thou dallying amid the rocks [reading cleitean] of the mountain of mist .

deiseal .
Sunwise . Even now the young Highlanders , in deference to the feelings of the old , carry the body of the dead sunwise round the place of burial before committing the body to the grave . [Cf . dolluid desel relci , Aislinge Meic Conglinne , 11 , 2 . ] In leaving the shore the boat is turned sunwise , not withershins . It was usual to go round a chief or a person of rank in order to show him respect . [Cf . the reception accorded to Sir James MacDonald of Islay , after his escape from Edinburgh Castle in 1615 , by Colkitto and his followers . They went round him for half an hour firing volleys . — HP , iii , 254 . ] When the Lewis people land on the Flannan Isles they walk sunwise round the temple of the saint singing Ora Fhlannain , Flannan ’ s prayer . [Cf . Martin Martin , 97 . ]

deislean .
Whitlow .

deòghlachan , deòghlan .
See gadmann .

dé - un , dè - unn = di - leum ( Dwelly ) , shackle , horse - shackle . [Cf . deabhunn ; deigheann ,
Dw ; deubhann ,
Fr . Allan , 259 ; ge ’ eann ,
Lewis ; E . Ir . gébend , a fetter , a bond . For di - leum cf . dìleum ,
Fr . Allan , 260 , fiollag - dìleum ,
id . , 261 . ( Dw says that in di - leum the stress is on leum ;
and assonance shows that this is so in UB , 187 . ) ]

dialtag .
See tur ; ialstarag .

diasadh .
Picking off the ears of corn ; from dias ,
an ear .

Di - Domhnaich Tùirneis / na Tùirneis .
See tùirneis .

dil .
Persistent . [dil ,
diligent , persevering , zealous , McA . ]

dil .
Bottom , lower depth . Cladhaich an uaigh as a dil = as a grunnd .

dìmeas .
See talcas .

diochd .
See carran .

dìocladh .
Abatement , as of rain . Tha dìocladh air an latha ,
the day is clearing up .

diogad , diogada .
Group . diogada teaghlaich ,
family group . diogada Domhnaich ,
Sunday group , congregation . diogada taighe ,
house group , household .

diogalan , diogalus , dioglachan .
See gadmann .

dìoghlum .
See dòman ; iunntachd ; tiumachd .

dioglach , dioglanach .
Fighting away with a thing .

dìol . Thug e dìol as fhéin ,
he took it out of himself , he took trouble . [Cf . Lewis thug e earraig as fhéin ,
he overstrained himself . ]

dìol - féin .
Suicide .

Bhathas a ’ tìodhlacadh neach a rinn dìol - féin taobh a muigh a ’ chlaidh ann an cladh dhaibh fhéin far nach ruigeadh dubhar gile na dubhar gréine na dubhar reul nan tràth . Bhathas ’ gan cur fo ’ n talamh eadar laighe agus éirigh ghréine , mar bu trice ri marbh - thràth na h - oidhche , eadar meadhon oidhche agus gairm choileach .
See also buil - féin . [Cf . TGSI , xxvi , 284 - 285 , 296 - 297 . ]

diong .
To fit , to match . Two silly persons were getting married in Uist . The woman was helping the man to dress before the ceremony , but she could not fit the collar to the shirt . In despair she cried , ‘ Is fuathasach an rud a th ’ ann , a Dhunnchaidh ! Diongaidh an coileir amhach Dhunnchaidh ach cha diong an coileir amhach léine Dhunnchaidh . ’
‘ A terrible thing it is , Duncan ! The collar will fit Duncan ’ s neck , but the collar will not fit Duncan ’ s shirt ’ s neck . ’

diong .
See carran .

diorcall , diorcaill .
See faircill .

dìosgan , dìosgaire , dìosganach .
Stirks , ‘ wasters ’ . [dìosganach ( dìosg ,
dry , to run dry ) was the term used for dipsomaniacs boarded out in the Isles , ‘ remittance men ’ — they were at one time fairly common . ]

di - reotha .
See famh .
diùbadaidh , tiùbadaidh [or diùbadaigh , tiùbadaigh] . Chief , owner , possessor .

Clann Ùb is Clann Annain
Tiùbadaidh Arainn .

[Cf . díobtha , díobaithe , díopa ,
very great ; unyielding , harsh , severe ,

O ’ Rahilly , Ériu , xiii , 205 - 206 ? Clann Annain ( ’ annain )
stands for Clann Bhannain .
This name is still known for them in Skye and Lewis , but in English they use the surname Buchanan . ]

diucadan , diucal .
See leasgadan ; liucadan .

diun .
To matter . cha diun e ,
it won ’ t matter . cha diunadh e ,
it mattered not . This word is current in Morvern . See duin , dionn . [Cf . diong ? ]
dleasach = eye .

dloidhidh = cas ma sheach ,
a tangle ; arbhar dloidhidh = boitean cas ma sheach ,
corn entangled . [It looks as if this might come from dlò ,
in which case the meaning should be the opposite ; cf . dlòth ,
Fr . Allan . ]

dò - bhliadhnach .
See isean .

doimheadach .
See daiteach .

doitheamh .
See dreathan - donn .

dolbh .
Witchcraft , sorcery . [E . Ir . dolb , sorcery , illusion , mystery , RIA Contrr . ]

do - léin .
See loch - bhléin .

dòman ( m . ) , dòmag ( f . ) . A gleaner . dòmanachd .
Gleaning , surreptitious gleaning . It is used to indicate gleaning done without the consent of the owner of the field where it is done . It is a discreditable form of dìoghlum .
The word is in use in Benderloch and has been heard in Uist applied to the work of children plucking ears of standing corn to eat the seed . See dìoghlum ; iunntachd ; tiumachd .

Domhnach Tùirneis / na Tùirneis .
See tùirneis .

donnach .
Large cockle - shell . [See donnach ,
Fr . Allan . donnag ,
Dw . ]

donnag .
Sand - eel .

dorn gulban . [The full phrase was troigh is dorn gulban and was a balancing feat . For an account of it see Éigse , viii , 251 - 252 . See also Maclennan , s . v . gulbann and troigh ,
where the explanations vary somewhat . ]

dos an daoi .
See tapag .

dosgaidh .
See ceus - chrann ; iubhar .
dothag [ - ò - ? ] . A draw or blast of the pipe .

dreapail [draipeil] .
In a hurry , busy . [A variant of dripeil .
See dreap ,
Fr . Allan . ]

dreathan - donn .
A wren . Also dreoll [dreòlan] .
See Conan Corr .

Aon eun aig a ’ chorr
Is e gu doitheamh doirbh ;
’ S dà eun deug aig an dreoll
Is iad gu soitheamh soirbh .

dréig .
Nag . See stèin . [dreug ,
f . , mare , old and done , Dw . ]

dreolladh , driolladh = drola ,
pot - handle ( Uist ) . [Ir . drolamh . ]

dreollag .
A swing . [Cf . dreallag , greallag . ]

dripeil .
See dreapail ; cathail .

droll .
Door bar . [droll ,
Fr . Allan , 260 . Cf . Cha bhiodh droll air do chomhlainn / Mu thràth - nòine ’ ga dùnadh ,
BGh , l . 5472 . ]
droll . [Back . ]

Is gàrlach thu bho d ’ bharr gu d ’ bhonn ,
Is moisean thu bho d ’ ghnos gu d ’ dhroll ,
Is blianach thu bho d ’ bhian gu d ’ chonn ,
Is crom an com o ’ n tànaig .

[Here droll is probably a variant of dronn = back , rump . See droll ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Luchd thogail na moltrach / ’ S an droll ris an làr ,
MC , 107 . ]

drong .

druim .
Keel of a boat .

Dar bhios trì traighean ’ san druim
Biodh traigh is corr ’ san tobhta - chroinn .

dualas = droch shìde ,
bad weather . [dualas = duathalas ,
from duathail ( duadhamhail ) .
See Fr . Allan , duathail ,

AD , 152 ; An toiseach na h - an - shid ’ s an duathalais ,

id . , 92 ; Thig crìoch ri ùine air gach dual , / Théid fuadach air gach bròn ,
DSG , 10 . ]

duaras .
Unpleasant , unpleasantness . [Presumably a noun only , and not an adj . duathar ,
obscurity ? ]

dubhach .
See lògais .

dubh - chas , ruadh - chas .
A species of flax , with stems black or red . [dubhchasach ,
Fr . Allan ( stress on dubh ) . ]

dubh - chas , ruadh - chas .
See sionnach .

an dubh thuill .
Black flux .

dubh - chaile .
A servant - girl , one employed at out - work . [dubh - chaile ,
scullion , trollop ; girl of the lowest rank of peasantry , Dw . ]

dubh - chonnadh .
‘ Black fuel ’ , thin peat on top of rock . It is dry and lasting , and gives as much heat as the best coal . The women at the shieling used this for cooking . [dubhchonnadh ,
Fr . Allan ( stress on dubh ) . ]

dubh - léin .
See loch - bhléin .

dubh - reotha , dubh - reothaich , ur - reotha .
Mole ( Perthshire ) . See famh . [C . M . Robertson , TGSI , xxii , 37 , gives the Perthshire forms as dubh - reabha , dubh - reabhgan ,
and considers it to be based on dubh - threabhadh .
Cf . uir - reath ,
Kirk ’ s Vocabulary , SGS , v , 93 . ]

dùcan .
Small swellings below the toes . [Cf . dùcan ,
a heap , TGSI , xxii , 37 . See dùcan , dùcan - faimh , dùcan - uir - faimh ,
Dw . ]

duchrach , duchrachd = droch bheòshlainte ,
evil life ; an evil way of living , as by thieving or worse . [ dubh - charach , dubh - charachd ? ]

dudadh , dudanadh .
See Conan Corr .

dùdan .
See cambar .

duibheanach .
See langaidh .

duille dhà lionn .
‘ Leaf of two liquids ’ ( air and water ) . duilleag eadar dhà lionn ,
‘ leaf between two liquids ’ , name of the water - lily . The root of the white variety of water - lily , when heated to a high temperature , yields a beautiful black dye which is much in use . Women sometimes lose their lives in getting the plant . [Hence the other name : an duilleag bhàidhte . ] It is common throughout the Isles . [The second form is probably the correct one . The first , if genuine , must be a shortened form , for lionn can hardly be applied to ‘ air ’ . ]

duin , dionn .
To matter , to effect . Cha duin e ,
it matters not . [Cf . diun . dionn indicates that it is a form of diong . ]

dunaidh , dunach .
See tapag .

durc .
A short piece of stick , rope , iron etc . [See O ’ Rahilly , Ériu , xiii , 212 , on the etymology of the English dirk . Cf . Duirceach do chuirc Mhórthirich , / da bheil an ròibein liath , / duirceall dubh gun fhaobhar / ’ n am taobhsainn ris a ’ bhiadh ,
T , 341 ; durc de cheann cabair ,
Waifs and Strays , iii , 136 . ]

durraran , durran , turraran , turran .
Nightjar .

dusrach , dusrachd .
Cloudy , cloud . As dusrachd na dàmhair ,
‘ the cloudiness of the rutting ’ , a week or ten days of cloudy weather supervening at rutting time .

eabhnadh .
Mighty deed . [This is from eangnamh ,
prowess . It appears in various forms in the traditional tales and poems . See Éigse , viii , 249 - 250 . ]

eacar , eacarra , eachdran .
A pound for horses ; a kind of corral or fank wherein to secure horses when horses were running loose . A place at the north end of Lòn Mór in Lismore is called Eachdran .
By development eachdarra ,
a lair in a churchyard , an enclosure . Eachdarra Chlainn na Cearda ,
the Enclosure of the Sinclairs , their burial place in Cladh Chuiril ( Chaorail ) , Muckairn . [See SGS , i , 34 . ]

each - ursann .
Heriot horse . When a crofter died the proprietor or the sub - proprietor of whom he had held his croft took possession of the best horse the widow possessed . This exaction pressed heavily upon the poor widow and the often helpless children , and caused bitter feeling against those engaged in it . The conscience of the people revolted against it , and in both North and South Uist there were cases of its being withstood . The forfeited horse was called the each - ursann ,
door - post horse , because he stood at ursann an dorais ,
the door - post . [each ursainn ,
Fr . Allan . ]

eachlais , eachlaisg , eachlaig .
A clumsy woman , a masculine woman , a horse - like woman . [See MWHT , i , 494 . ]

eachrais ùrlair .
A stand whereon pine is placed and lit to light the room = pierman ( Lismore ) . [In the folktales the eachrais ùrlair is a sort of witch . For a full account of the various forms and their development see MWHT , i , 492 - 499 . ]

eadra , eadradh .
Milking - time , whether at morning , noon or night . [For the etymology see Celtica , iii , 300 . ]

Ged thug thu bhó bhàinionn uam , [ ? bhainne ( : eadraidh )
Cha tug thu ’ n cadal eadraidh dhìom .
Though thou tookest the white [ ? milch - ] cow from me , thou hast not taken the noon sleep from me .

Ged thug thu Blàrag ghràdhach dhìom ,
Cha tug thu tràigh bhàn Bhàrasdail .

The ill laird of Barasdal then sent his men and horses to plough up the white strand of Barasdal , which they did so effectively that although once full of many kinds of shellfish it has had none since . The shellfish beds were turned up with the plough and allowed to rot in the sun . ‘ Whatsoever a man soweth , that shall he also reap ’ ; the ill laird of Barasdal ’ s death was early and unlamented . His fame rests upon an instrument of torture which he invented and to which he gave his name . [This was Colla Bàn , second of Barisdale ; see TGSI , xiii , 85 ff . ; Clan Donald , iii , 337 - 342 . ]

eala .
See màthair tala .

ealachadh .
Grain pounded in the pollag and ground in the quern , the ealachadh making the grinding easy . Mas ealachadh e faigh dhomh màm . [Cf . ma ’ s ealachadh a th ’ agad , no gradan ; / Ma ’ s earraradh e , fair dhomh màm ,
Duanaire , 116 . ]

ealaire .
See alaire .

ealpag , fealpag ( Perthshire ) . A knob or catch . In Uist and Argyll it is sgroigean ,
a knob or catch for metal , wood etc . , to afford a hold or catch . [Cf . E . Ir . alp , a lump , Contrr ; ulpag ( chloiche ) ,
a large stone , Lewis ; ulpan ,
a man of great strength , TGSI , xxxvii , 45 . For sgroigean cf . sgroig ,
the projecting knobs of the prow and stern stems of a boat , Fr . Allan . As the vowel is nasalised , a better spelling would appear to be sgnoig , sgnoigean . Ri scruig thoisich ,
DMcL , 152 . ]

ealtrap , ealtrapadh .
See altrap . Also ealtradh ,
s . v . iubhar .

eang .
See triubhas .

earaire = falaire ,
steed , palfrey .

earc .
Cow , heifer . In some places earc is applied to a filly in foal , in some to any filly . [E . Ir . erc , a spotted or red - eared cow ; a cow . ]

earc .
Lizard . [Also earc - luachrach , dearc - luachrach .
E . Ir . erc , erc sléibhe ( also arc , etc . ) . ]

an eàrna dhearg , an eàrnaid dhearg ,
the red murrain , and an eàrnaid ghlas ,
the grey murrain , diseases of cattle caused by heat and dryness .

To cure it give the animal sùgh pronn na sùgh càtha thig as a ’ mhin ,
the bree of sids or of the husks that come off the meal ( this from Catherine Maclean , crofter , Naast , Gairloch ) . The disease is easily recognised . The urine passed by the animal leaves a craobh ,
bell , on the ground long after it has itself disappeared . See bun dearg ,
ii , 238 .

earr - thalmhainn .
Yarrow . It is good for consumption . If going on a journey , kneel on the ground with your right hand on the plant , and say , ‘ In name of Father and Son and Spirit ’ ; your journey will be blessed , everyone will be pleasant to you , and pleasantness will be in your face . [Also carr - thalmhainn ( see carr ) ; athair - thalmhainn ; cathair - thalmhainn .
E . Ir . athair talman , Contrr . ar[r] - thalmhanna ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . ’ S gun ghearr mi ’ n ear - thalmhainn do bhri mo sceil ,
G , 127 . ]

earraid .
Mental trouble . Of similar meaning is earrachlach = dragh , cùram , uallach inntinn . [For earraid cf . E . Ir . erráit , straying , error . Earrachlach is no doubt originally the state of mind produced by earchall ,
loss of cattle . earchaill ,
Fr . Allan . ]

earraradh .
See fuirireadh .

easan .
See carran ; liasag .

easan - mara .
Sea - pheasant , i . e . lacha - stiùrach ,
long - tailed duck .

éasga .
The moon . éasga dhubh ,
dark moon . éasga gheal ,
bright moon . Oidhche gun reul gun rionnag gun éasga ,
a night without star or planet or moon . [E . Ir . ésca ( e ) , éisce . ]

easgal .
Noise . easgal mara ,
tumult of sea . [E . Ir . esgal , noise , roar ( of water ) ; storm , commotion , RIA Dict . ]

easpach , iospach .
A hasp for a door . [easbach , ìosp ,
Dw . easpach ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . ON hespa . ]

éigir , héigir .
Dwarf , ill - grown child , ill - grown man or woman , miserably clad person . ùrnaigh éigir ,
dwarf prayer , miserable petition . Cha tugainn éigir ort ,
I would not give an éigir for thee . Leac a / o h - Éigir is on the west coast of South Uist . [ii , 281 - 284 . éigear ,
Fr . Allan . ]

eirmisg .
See tonn .

éiseach .
Withes tied to wooden crupper and pack - saddle . [eisleach ( leg . éisleach ) , Dw . Cf . ’ S tric thu teann air na h - éibhlean , / Bhreac do shuimeir gu t ’ éislich ,
DB , ll . 1345 - 6 . eibhsichean , eillsichean , éisichean ,
Fr . Allan . ]

éiseanach .
A high [following] wave . A Uist woman emigrating , asked what she would do when the storm came , said : ‘ Nach bi sinn am fasgadh nan éiseanach , a ghràidh ? ’
‘ Shall we not be in the shelter of the big waves , my dear ? ’ See cùlanach ; màrnaich .

eisir .
See cladach .

éiteag .
See riollag .

eiteach [MS . eiteal ? ] .
Gruel , thin gruel .

eiteineach .
Wood fuel , as bog pine , heather roots , withered trees . Cum thus ’ eiteineach air an teine dhomhsa agus cumaidh mise sgialachd dhusa ,
keep thou wood fuel on the fire for me and I will keep story to thee . ‘ Cum thusa eiteineach riumsa agus cumaidh mise sgialachd riu ’ sa ’ , ars an tàillear ris a ’

ghiullan ,
‘ Keep thou wood fuel to me and I will keep story to thee ’ , said the tailor to the boy . This was when tailors went about from house to house working and when , as often happened , heather roots on the fire or bog pine on the wall was all the light they had to work by . [ eitean ,
E . Ir . etne , kernel ? ]

éitich .
See tapag .

eoch , eocha .
Strong , powerful , effective ; shield , defence . [ iach ,
gen . of eó ,
salmon ? ]

eòrnach .
Debris , collection of stones . eòrnach chlach ,
heap of stones . eòrnach mór chlach ,
large collection of stones , boulder stone . [ orda ,
pl . òirnean ,
piece , fragment . Cf . Ir . oirdneach , oirneach , pieces , fragments . See Éigse , vi , 268 . ]

eugnairc , agnairc , euganairc .
Prayer , pleading , litany , death prayer . [E . Ir . écndairc , an intercessory prayer , prayer for the absent or for the dead , requiem , RIA Dict . ]

fabhdach .
Deceitful , treacherous , perilous . [Cf . i , 328 ; v , 306 , 308 , 310 . Sc . faut ? But occurs in Ir . , see Cnósach Focal ó Bhaile Bhúirne , p . 111 . ]

faidhbh , faoidh[bh] [MS . faòibh , faòigh] .
Cast - offs ; dead men ’ s clothes . [E . Ir . fodb , fadb , exuviae , spoils , clothing or equipment taken from the dead , sometimes booty in general . ]

faileach .
See aileach .

failinn .
A pot - lid . [Cf . failcin , failceann ,
McB ? also faircill ? ]

fàine , fàin , fàn .
Light , dawn . See àine , àn . [fàin ,
Fr . Allan . ]

faircill , fairceall .
A musical instrument , a lyre ; a bread - toaster ; a drinking vessel .

The musical instrument is also called faircill ciùil or ceòil .
The bread - toaster is also called faircill arain and crann arain ,
bread - beam or wooden bread - holder . It is in the shape of a curve , about a third of a circle , and stands on three legs or feet ; the bread stands against it to be toasted at the round fire on the floor .

The drinking vessel , faircill òil ,
was also called stòp faircill .
The stoup was used at any function where many people were present . It was a round stoup of wood with two tall handles opposite one another . The bottom was flush with the sides , while the handles had a graceful inward curve . [Judging by the drawing the handles extended above the top of the vessel , and the vessel was waisted above the base . ] It held beer , mead and other liquids . It was handed round the sreath or cuairt ,
rank or circle , each person taking a srùbag or balgam ,
sip or mouthful , and passing the vessel to his neighbour . The faircill used in a chief ’ s house was large , heavy and of a standard capacity . The bodyguard of the Lord of the Isles was selected from the best families and from the strongest youths within their extensive territories . The men had many

privileges , and great strength , dexterity and valour was required of them . They were called fir mhóra , fir taighe , luchd taighe , teaghlach , galloglaich ,
great men , house - men , house - troop , household , armed band [gallow - glasses] , and by other names . They had special rules for the management of the faircill .
Each balanced the full vessel on the palm of his hand , drank from it , and handed it on ; the fingers were spread apart to allow the next man to place his fingers between them . One hand only was used , the other holding the weapons . All this required a strong arm and a dexterous hand , and the man who failed was not admitted into the feat of the faircill .
A cup similar to this , and similarly used , was the meadar ;
the handles of this , however , were straight . [farch , farch - chiùil , fairchil ,
ii , 289 . ] Faircioll , faircill in the Outer Isles corresponded to diorcall , diorcaill in the Inner Isles . [See Waifs and Strays , v , 41 , where the vessel used by the Lord of the Isles ’ bodyguard is called diorcal . ]

The food and drink given to Ùisdean Mór mac Ghilleasba Chléirich ,
Big Hugh son of Archibald the Clerk , when he was thrown into toll dubh Dhùn Tuilm ,
the black hole of Duntulm , was dà cheathramh chaorail dearg làn salainn agus dà stòp faircill loma - làn leanna ,
two quarters of red sheep - flesh full of salt and two large stoups brimful of ale — one of which , however , had a false bottom .

From the use of sreath referred to above come such phrases as Cha bhuin thu dh ’ an t - sreath ,
‘ thou wilt not attain [dost not belong to] the circle ’ ; òl lit feuch am faigh thu dh ’ an t - sreath ,
‘ sup porridge to see whether thou wilt attain the circle ’ . These were inducements held out to children to stimulate their appetites . The sreath represented strength and dexterity , and both young men and maidens practised gymnastic exercises to attain it .

Stòl faircill was a crescent - shaped stool . [The stool the story of which is told in the following note , and which is mentioned by Mrs Mary Mackellar in her paper on ‘ The Sheiling ’ , TGSI , xiv , 152 ff . , seems exactly to correspond to the description of the stòl faircill .
It was in the possession of the late Professor J . Carmichael Watson . ]

The writer has a small primitive stool on which Prince Charlie sat in a summer shieling in North Uist during his wanderings after Culloden . When he came into the shieling , three girls were busily at work , all merrily singing the while . Bha té ri fuine , té ri muidhe , agus té ri càise — one was baking , one was churning , and one was making cheese . The girls had no English and the Prince but little Gaelic , but they gave him the best entertainment they had , which the people always do to strangers . When the Prince had gone and the girls came to know who their visitor had been , a friendly struggle took place among them for the possession of the stool on which he had sat . In this struggle the stool came against the face of one of the girls , knocking out a tooth . On seeing this mishap her companions generously handed the girl the stool , one of them

facetiously saying to her , ‘ As you have got so disfigured in the cause of the Prince ( an adhbhar a ’ Phrionnsa ) , you will need a tochar ,
