dowry , to set you up ! ’ [According to North Uist tradition , this incident took place at Ardmaddy , and the three girls were the daughters of Ewen Macpherson . ]

A descendant of this girl , a respectable woman in the island of Boreray , North Uist , gave me the stool some twelve years ago . It is a small rude thing , the seat of which is a crescent - shaped tree - root ; one end of the crescent curves downwards , forming a natural leg ; pegs are inserted into holes in the seat to form legs at the other end and at the centre of the crescent . [Its present height is about eight inches , and it is a rather uneasy and precarious seat . The legs , however , were at one time longer . Some vandal has used it as axe - block , and it also bears marks of fire . — Note by J . Carmichael Watson . ]

The people spoke and sang of the Prince as Am Buachaille Bàn , Am Buachaille Buidhe ,
‘ the fair - haired herdsman ’ , ‘ the yellow - haired herdsman ’ . The allusion was understood without their committing themselves .

Am faca sibh tighinn am Buachaille Bàn ?
Am faca sibh tighinn am Buachaille Bàn ?
Am faca sibh tighinn fear mhealladh nan ighean ,
Am fear thogadh mo chridhe , am Buachaille Bàn ?
[For faircill etc . cf . E . Ir . forcle ( far - , foir - , fair - ) , top - surface ; a top , cover , lid ? ]

fairil .
Tongs to hold the hair when putting it up in a queue .

fairleum .
The part of the tackle next the hook .

fairtheadh . Is fearr am fairtheadh na an gràiseach [grainnseach] .
( The fairtheadh is the càin ,
wages paid in kind , to a servant . grài[nn]seach is the grange or grain farm ) . So said [John] Mac[Donald] of Grimi[ni]sh [Iain mac Ùisdein] when Clanranald ’ s daughter left him and he was dependent on his illegitimate son , Do ’ all Breac . [far - thagh , foireagh ,
ii , 289 . Cf . farradh ,
crop raised by a married farm - servant [or tacksman ’ s sub - tenant] for his own use . Strictly speaking , it means the tilling done by the wife , while the husband is attending to the gràithseach ,
the master ’ s [or tacksman ’ s] crop . Occasionally a very active woman might get through more work than her less active husband , in which case it would be said , is mó am farradh na ’ ghràithseach ,
the servant ’ s crop is bigger than the master ’ s . — Dw . Cf . E . Ir . fairthe ,
preparation , provision , entertainment , or forrath ,
additional stock ? forradh ,
Fr . Allan , a developed meaning of this ? ]

faisich . Cha b ’ e faisich e = cha robh sin furasda ,
it was not easy . [Cha b ’ e fasadh ,
N . Uist . ]

faladh , faladha .
Tricky , treacherous , deceitful , unreliable . Probably akin to feall ,
false .

falaire .
See earaire .

an fhalcag bhiorach .
The guillemot .

falcair , falcaire .
Pimpernel . falcaire fiadhain ,
wild pimpernel . The falcaire fuail or falcadair fuail was much prized for its medicinal properties .

famh , amh , lamh , labh , fathan , fath - thalmhainn , di - reotha , dao - reotha .
Earth - mole . See dubh - reotha . [The vowel of famh seems to be long , judging by Iain Gobha ’ s lines : Thilg e mach chum nam fàmh iad / S ghleidh e Rāchel dha féin ,
DIG , i , 186 . Cf . Lhuyd ’ s spelling fadhbh ,
Archaeologia Britannica , 356 . The vowel would , of course , be shortened in a compound like famh - thalmhainn . ]

fanabhas .
See cuthag .

fanadh [better fannadh] . Gentle rowing when fishing with rods or bait from a boat . [ON andœfa , to keep pulling against wind and tide so as to prevent a boat from drifting astern ; andóf , paddling with the oars , so as to keep a boat from drifting . aandowin ’ , Shetland . For other forms see SGS , i , 103 . fanadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

faobh - bhleoghan .
See saobh - bhleoghan .

faochag .
Whelk . Beathaichidh faochag neach gus am fàs e cho duibhe ris an sgeith aice fhéin ,
whelks will keep a man alive until he grows as black as the whelk ’ s own excretion . [sgeith should be sgéith ,
dat . of sgiath :
‘ as black as its own valve ’ . See faochag ,
Fr . Allan . ] See cladach .
faoideach [better faighdeach] . Canal , ditch . [In N . Uist also a mill - lade . ]

faoideag .
A curved shell . [faighdeag ,
v , 258 , 266 . See faoiteag ; maighdeag ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Gann urad maighdeige tràthad ,
E , 320 , where it is glossed ‘ A very small kind of Wilk without any meat in it ’ . ]

faoilinn , faoileann .
Level raised beach , not high above the sea , not necessarily grassless , of fair extent , e . g . at least eighty to a hundred yards long . In some parts a sandy spit , a sandy part of the shore where rocks abound on either side . [Cf . TGSI , xxxvii , 24 . ]

faoise .
See clach - shuill .

faol .
Wild . duine faol ,
a wild man , a man going wild , in a wild state .

faotharsach , faorsach ? faonach ? faorach ?
Flippant , simple ; mean , miserly , small , miserable , penurious . [faonach , faonbhach ,
mild , meek , Dw . ]

farachrann .
A small bannock .

farachrann .
Anything like a handle and a big head [noted immediately below simid = beetle for clothes] . Dar a dh ’ fhairtlicheas air a ’ chaillich am feur a chumail fodha , tilgidh i am farachan / farachrann am bun na craoibhe cuilinn ,
when the hag fails to keep the grass under she throws the farachrann at the root of the holly tree . [Meaning ? ] [For farchan ,
mallet , see Fr . Allan ; also foireiche ,
p . 261 . AMD ( 1751 Gloss . ) : Fairche ,
a beettle ( sic ) or hammer . Cf . Farachan cruinn do mhaide ’ n tarruing air do chūl ,
BTh , 210 . E . Ir . forcha , farcha , a beetle , mallet . ]
faradh . [Hen - roost , loft . See further Dw , s . v . ] . See suimir .

fara - dhàir .
See raidhne .

far - bhleoghan .
See saobh - bhleoghan .

fargadh , fairigeadh .
Bathing . [Cf . Thug thu fairige fairge / Do luchd nam falluinne dearga ,
G , 76 . E . Ir . fothrucud . ]

far - ghuilbneach .
‘ False curlew ’ , whimbrel , also ruid - ghuilbneach and ian Bealltain .
Though it is quite a different bird from the long - tailed duck it is sometimes called by one of the latter ’ s names , ian bùchainn . [See lach , ii , 312 . ]

farch .
Harp . [The pl . farchaichean and farchain appear in some notes taken down from a man in Stoer , possibly meaning ‘ harpers ’ and ‘ harps ’ . ]

fàrlas .
See laomachan .

farpais .
See coinnleag .

fàrsair . Falbh air fàrsair ,
too much occupied in one object . [Cf . fàrsan ,
wandering ? An sin trēigeamaid am fàrsan , / ’ S gu ’ m b ’ fhearr na bhi air chuairt ,
S , 167 ; Shiubhail mi fearann nan Gael , / ’ S earain de Bhreatain air fàrsan ,
id . , 185 . ]

farta .
A form of feart ,
grave .

farus duine .
A man in middle age . [In Lewis called braisiche . ]

fasgnadh .
See càthadh .

fàth .
Land , province .

fàth , fathann , fathaman [last letter doubtful] . A gentle breeze , light wind . [fathan ,
light wind , Dw . ]

fathan , fath - thalmhainn .
See famh .

feachaire .
Mocker , satirist , lampooner . feachaireachd .
Mocking , satirising , ill manners . [feachaireachd : Latha na Feachaireachd ,
All Fools ’ Day , Fr . Allan . ]

feairtean .
See fuirireadh .

feall .
See peall .

feallag [MS . fealag] .
A cheat , trick , quirk . Thug mi feallag dheth ,
I took something off him . Fhuair e feallag orm oidhche Shamhna .

fealpag .
See ealpag .

feaman .
See cladach .

feaman .
Tail . See iubhar .

feannag .
Grey crow . When the grey crow migrated from the sea - shore to the hill - ground and went to live in Coireacha Bàn in Rannoch she was asked by the native birds , ‘ Dé thug a seo thu ? ’
‘ What brought you here ? ’ ‘ Is mór an t - suthain an t - sàmhchair , ’ ars an fheannag . ’
‘ Great is the joy of peace , ’ said the grey crow .

feanntag .
See neanntag .

fear - baile .
The fir - baile ,
tacksmen or middlemen , throughout the Highlands were always a scourge to the people . The fear - baile was generally related more or less closely to the proprietor . He took land , often of

Ge dona cor croitear fir - fearainn , [tighearna
Tha ’ n donas dubh an cor croitear fir - baile .

Ge dona an t - uachdaran [dubh
Tha an truaigh air fear a ’ bhaile .

fear na Féill Pàraig .
‘ The fellow of St Patrick ’ s Feast ’ , the wheatear .

fearsaid .
See cneapag ; dealgan - feairt .

feart .
See farta .

feisteag .
See fisteag .

féith mhór chùl chas , féith mhór chùl na coise .
The Achilles tendon . When a cattle - dog was not to be restrained from chasing the cows too harshly this tendon was cut to curb his violence .

feuchainnt .
Hot argument .

feur gurt .
See gadmann .

feursann .
See péarsaid .

fiacal goibhre .
A buck tooth . Also fiacal buic , stòr - fhiacal . [According to Dwelly another meaning is a man who holds out against his neighbours ( cf . Celtic Scotland , iii , 391 ) . Still another meaning in AMD ( 1751 ) , 27 : ’ S gheibh u fioclan - goir ’ / Agus cóson int ’
( of a tree ) . ]

fialtag = spearrach ,
a fetter for animals . [leg . fialltag iall ? spearrach ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . ’ S gur e ’ m bàs a chuir spearrach ort ,
LG , 79 . ]

fiar - fà .
A grass in ditches . It is applied to at - cìche ,
swelling of the breast . [An leg . fiar - fàil ? ]

fiasgag nan creag .
Rock lichen . It is good for renewing the skin on a sore .

fiath nan ian , fian ian .
‘ The calm of the birds ’ , an expression often used at sea in a dead calm , a flat calm . It is said to mean the time between Samhain ,
Hallowtide , and Féill Màrtain ,
Martinmas . During this period the birds are silent unless the previous fortnight has been bad and the present fortnight good . Should this be so , the birds will sing but with difficulty , their song lacking melody and their hearts willingness . [fiath - nan - ian ,
Fr . Allan , 261 . In Dh ’ aithnichinn do cheann air cladach agus t ’ fhead ri fèath nan eun fionn ,
RG , 95 , the phrase is , exceptionally , a euphemism for a hurricane . ]

fiathlan .
Quit money . Chan fhaca mi fiathlan . [ fiach + làn ? ]

fide , fideach , fidean .
Grassy land covered by the sea at specially high tides . As , Fideach Thrùmaisgearraidh , Fideach Chnoc Cuithein , Fideach an Ìochdair etc . It is the equivalent of the mainland mormhoich ,

morrach , morthach [mor + magh ,
sea plain] , land now and then overflowed by the sea . [Cf . TGSI , xxxvii , 23 . ON fit , meadow - land on the banks of a lake or river ; see Henderson , NICS , 170 . ]

filleag , filleadh .
See guailleach .

fìneag .
Cheese mite . A Uist servant lad complained of his fare in these quaint terms :

Dar chunna mi na fìneagan
’ Gan càramh air na trìnnsearan ,
Is màglach dhe na grìleagan
Is mìr de dh ’ aran càthadh .

[fìneagan ,
Fr . Allan . For màglach cf . smàglach ,
a handful , id . Cf . Poc ’ a dh ’ fhianagan lachdunn ,
UB , 184 . It also means ‘ a miser ’ ; cf . ’ S līonmhor fīneag a tha beirteach ,
G , 59 ; Na fīonag dhripail gheur - chuiseach ,
S , 171 . ]

fìon . Wine . Wine is so often mentioned in the literature of the people that it must have been at least fairly plentiful . Probably much of the wine consumed was made at home from native fruits which the people seem to have had in abundance . The Church undoubtedly fostered farming and horticulture among the people . Among the ruined homes it is touching to find still the outlines of the gardens , even after long possession by the sheep , the deer and the wealthy stranger . The writer has traced these gardens and seen remains of various shrubs and plants in hundreds of places , and he confesses that he was much moved at the mistaken policy , the inhuman barbarity , the dreadful arrogance , with which his beloved people have been treated .

fionnd , fionnda .
Blue , the blue sky .

fionndach , feanndach .
A fair woman , a fair - haired or fair - skinned woman . fionndach bhoireannaich . [Follows the stanza given in v , 144 , but for the last two lines the reading is : Dar a theann a nall / An fheanndach ghasda . ]

fionndarlach .
See uanallach .

fionnluchan , fionnlugan .
Grass mouse , dormouse . The cat will neither kill nor eat the dormouse . [See luch - fheòir ,
ii , 322 . fiolagan ,
field mouse , Dw . luch - fheòir ,
Fr . Allan . ]

fionntrain , fionndrain .
See dealg fionndrain .

fios fithich .
Raven ’ s knowledge , preternatural knowledge .

Trì subhailcean a ’ bhaird ,
Cìocras air gu sàsadh bhrann ,
Fios fithich a ’ ruith gu ròic ,
Tart mór gu òladh dhram . [leg . gu òl a dhram
The three virtues of the bard , sharp hunger for filling of belly , raven ’ s knowledge at running to feast , mighty thirst for drinking of drams . [his dram

[Cf . NGR , 64 ( tart frith - fhir ,
should be tart frithir ,
‘ a raging thirst ’ ) ; NGP , 372 . See s . v . fitheach ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . fitheachas . ]

fir mhóra , fir taighe .
See faircill .

fisteag , feisteag .
Snowball ; the meal or flour adhering to the bag after the bag is emptied out . A stone is put into the bag and the bag is heaved up and down till all the meal or flour in the cloth has fallen to the bottom of the bag . This is then taken out and placed in clean cold water , whence it is taken and rolled into a ball , rubbed over with butter and toasted before the fire . This ball is called fisteag , feisteag ,
and is considered a great luxury .

fitheach .
Raven . The raven ’ s proverbial wisdom is nowhere more strikingly shown than in its provision for its young . It is the earliest bird in the Highlands to breed [cf . the verses at i , 172 f . ] and provides for this early hungry season in a most marvellous manner . Constructing its nest of sticks , twigs and tangle , it thoroughly covers this framework down to the floor with layer upon layer of slimy mud full of maggots and other small life . Not only does this make the nest warm , but when the raven is sitting on its nest the warmth of its body brings the torpid maggots to life and these are eaten by the young chicks when no other food is available . This other food includes tender lambs from distant flocks , the raven being too prudent to spoil his home reputation and thus endanger his life . Ravens will not nest near each other . A raven established in a given spot will fight furiously with and chase away an intruder . [See also ii , 291 ff . ]

Nì bheil slad an nead an fhithich
Nach bheil an cridhe Dhòmhaill .

Briagaidh am bith - iodh
Am fitheach o ’ n chrìbh .
The [seed of corn ? ] will beguile the raven from the tree .

A tribe of men in Benbecula are called na Fithich ,
a highly apposite name . The tribe left Lewis for the good of Lewis . They are called in Benbecula na Grùdairean ,
the brewers , but whether they were brewers to MacKenzie before leaving Lewis or brewers to Clanranald after coming to Benbecula is not now remembered . They are a plausible people , but unreliable in character . This is in their blood .

fitheachas .
Divining , after the manner of the raven . Có rinn duit am fitheachas [nach robh mi ann an tìr nam beò] ?
‘ Who made to thee the ‘ raven knowledge ’ [that I was not in the land of the living] ? ’ [Cf . fios fithich . ]

flaigeas .
A bunch of eels .

Flannan .
See deiseal .

fleasg .
See pleasg .

fliodh Moire .
Marsh chickweed . This grows in pools and puddles and is closely akin to the true water - cress . The plant is heated on a flat stone facing the fire ; a person with a festering hand or foot places the hand or foot on the stone and the heated plant over the sore . [See s . v . lus mór . fliodh Moire ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Chaidh iad fo ’ n fhliodh / mar na cearcan ,
OL , 62 ; Na Gaidheil ’ s an ceann fo fhliodh ,
AD , 29 . ]

foich .
Little plain . foichilean .
Very small plain . [Cf . faithche , faiche . ]

foighim , faighim .
A veiled word , an obscure word , hidden meaning . Sin an fhoighim a thug mise as an rud ,
that is the meaning I took out of it . [Cf . foidheam ,
Dw ; oigheam ogham ,
McB . ]

foirinn .
Gentle , delicate , quiet , slow , as chaidh e foirinn ,
he went quietly .

fòlach .
Sustenance .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: [Cf . E . Ir . fogla , fruit , produce ? ]

fòlach .
See òlach .

for .
Lost , neglected . Leig iad for air an fhidhill ,
they allowed the fiddle to go lost , to be neglected . [Cf . cha robh for air ,
there was no word of it . for ,
trace or sign . Chan ’ eil for agam air ,
I have no trace of it , TGSI , xxxvii , 33 ; air for ,
lost , Applecross ; Gun fhàrdal le for ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 128 . See for ,
Fr . Allan . ]

frasach .
See praiseach .

frìd [frighid] , frìdeag , frìdein , frìdim .
Fleshworm , tetter , animalcule , pimple . Is lugha na frìde màthair na mìothlachd ,
smaller than mite is the mother of anger . Frìdein daltaidh daormainn ,
mite , foster - mother of niggard . Guireag dhubh dhona màthair - ghoimh lianntrachd ,
little black evil pimple , painful mother of ulceration . Frìdein beadaidh màthair - cheilidh an uilc ,
petted little tetter , the concealing mother of evil . Frìdein fionn gur an lionn ,
fair mite hatching in rheum . Grigein fionn àlach lionn ,
fair mite , hatchling of serum .
[E . Ir . frige , gen . friged . ]

fridealach .
Fretty . duine fridealach ,
short - tempered man . [friotach , friotalach ,
fretful , angry , ill - natured , hasty , Dw . ]

frigh , frighig .
Fry of fish ; frighig fionn ,
white fry , herring fry . [ E . frying . ]

fuarag .
See crannachan ; graothaich .

fuath .
See gàdag .

fuil - bhràthrachd .
See càrnach .

fuil sìochaire .
‘ Fairy ’ s blood ’ , a substance found on the shores . [See crotal , supra . Cf . Campbell , Superstitions of the Scottish Highlands , 26 , 200 . fuil - sìofraith ,
pumice - stone ; fuil - nan - sluagh ,
red crotal of the

rocks melted by frost . In Argyllshire , the saying when one sees red crotal is , thug na daoine beaga cath an raoir ,
the little men ( fairies ) fought a battle last night , Dw . ]

fùileach .
Sheepskin covering on the mouth of a churn . [See Campbell , Witchcraft and Second Sight , 12 ; fuirleach ,
Dw ; gan ùirlich ,
AMD , Nat . Lib . MS . 63 ; SGS , iv , 192 . ]

fuirireadh ,
elsewhere earraradh .
Corn set on fire in the sheaf . Gradan = corn dried in the pot after falling from the sheaf in the fuirireadh or earraradh . Min thuiriridh ( sic ) : Bha i air a gradanadh air tarran . Tarran :
a frame of network [Dealbh] for drying corn . The ropes across the tarran are called feairtean and are about three inches apart . [eararadh , uirearadh ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . B ’ annsa leam na dùrdan bodaich / Os cionn lice ag eararadh sìl ,
BGh , ll . 6687 - 8 . ]

gà .
Murmur ; heavy rain . Cf . gàth ,
infra . [Cf . ga aibhne ,
iii , 154 ; gó , sea , RIA Contrr . ]

gad - tarrach .
Belly - band . [Cf . Waifs and Strays , v , 25 . ]

gàdag .
A rope of rushes , of fixed length , two fathoms and two hands , for measuring hay , straw , corn or rushes , as gàdag feòir ,
a gàdag ( - ful ) of hay ; gàdag fodair ,
a g . of straw ; gàdag arbhair ,
a g . of corn ; gàdag canndail ,
a g . of rushes [see canndal] . The gàdag was made of beaten rushes with the pith extracted . The ends of the gàdag were well secured to prevent fraying ; hence the sayings gàdag le ceann sgaoilte or gàdag ’ s a ceann sgaoilte ,
‘ a gàdag with its end frayed ’ , applied to a frowsy woman , and gàdag ’ s a dà cheann sgaoilte ,
‘ a gàdag with both its ends frayed ’ , applied to a very frowsy woman , a very untidy girl , a slovenly person in general . A place in St Kilda is called Cleite Gàdaig . [Dwelly does not mark the vowel long , but it is long and is not , therefore , from gad ,
which in any case is mas . and forms dimin . goidean .
Cf . the St Kilda place - name Leac na Gàdaig ,
riming with ard oirr , G , 47 . Cf . also
’ S cha d ’ bhuail iad le gàdaig no taod mi ,
DIG , ii , 102 . ( The Glossary wrongly derives it from gad . ) ‘ Gàdag :
Rope made of three strands of finely spun sioman feòir .
The gàdag is used to carry corn or hay ’ ( TGSI , xxxvii , 23 ) . ]

The fuath ,
dreadful phantom , was an ill being who could assume the form of man or woman , bird or beast , as best suited his evil purpose , and could do , if necessary , the work of ten or twenty men . The fuath came to Dòmhall Odhar , Dun Donald , in Coll one day in autumn and asked for work , his payment to be a gàdag of corn at night . Dòmhall Odhar agreed to this and gave him a day ’ s work . The fuath worked and worked so well that the whole of Dòmhall Odhar ’ s corn was cut by nightfall . Dòmhall Odhar rejoiced and his wife prepared the harvest feast . The fuath began to fill his gàdag ,
and he was filling and filling his gàdag until he had the whole of Dòmhall Odhar ’ s corn - crop under his rope . Dòmhall Odhar was dismayed and sorely perplexed ; as a man of honour

he could not come an cois fhacail ,
against his word , and as a man of sense he could not lose his whole crop to this extraordinary man . When he recovered utterance he exclaimed in the bitterness of his heart :

Màrt a threabh mi ,
Màrt a chuir mi ,
Màrt a bhuain mi :
Fhir thug dhomh na trì Màirt , [Thus , a luaidh
Na leig mo bharr buileach [uile
Dh ’ an an aon ghàdaig ghuaille !

When the fuath heard the name of God implied , the gàdag of corn fell from his nerveless grasp , and he flew away like the black raven of the hill amidst clouds of flameless smoke , and never again returned to the island of Coll , ‘ no , never again , thou beloved ( a rùin ) ’ . [See this story in Waifs and Strays , iii , 216 - 221 . The gàdag is there called gad - cuail ,
a withy for tying a bundle . Màrt is explained , 298 - 299 , as the fit time for doing any particular part of agricultural work , as Màrt cuir ,
fit time of sowing ; Màrt fuine ,
fit time of baking , in August ; Màrt buana ,
fit time of reaping , in September . See also TGSI , xxvi , 272 - 275 . ]

gàdag .
Weed - clip , wooden tongs , in the form of nippers , for extracting thistles from among growing corn . The instrument is now obsolete , the soil being cleaner .

gadmann .
A small particle in a sunbeam on a bright day , a mote . The word occurs in the quatrain by MacDonald of Dùn Tuilm , who died in Edinburgh and whose ghost was seen in Dùn Tuilm the following night . The ghost said :

Bha mi ’ n Dùn Eideann an dé ,
Tha mi ’ m thalla féin a nochd ,
’ S meud a ’ ghadmainn anns a ’ ghréin
Chan ’ eil ann mo chreubh do sprochd .

[Sprochd appears to be , not sproc ( hd ) ,
dejection , but a variant of sprac ,
life , vigour , activity . In the version given by Campbell , Witchcraft and Second Sight , 213 , the word is neart ,
strength . The original may well have been thort .
Instead of gadmann ,
Campbell ’ s version has dadum ,
atom , mote . ]

gadmann .
Sundew , drosera rotundifolia . The plant is called gadmann [Lus a ’ Ghadmuinn ,
Fr . Allan] because from it was made a wash to cleanse the hair . [gadmann = a nit , insect . Cf . Air a ’ chùl a dh ’ fhàs neo - loinneil / Dh ’ fhàg na gadmuinn gartach greannach ,
G , 139 . ] It has many other names : deoghlachan , deoghlan ,
little sucker ; diogalan , diogalus , dioglachan ,
little

tickler ; meirbhein , mirbhin ,
digester ; feur gurt ,
famine grass ; lus gort ,
famine plant ; lus an acrais ,
hunger plant ; acrachan ,
little hungerer ; lus a ’ chruidhein [chruibhein] ,
plant of the paw ; cruidhean [cruibhean] cait ,
cat ’ s paw ; lus nan cuileag ,
plant of the flies ; lus nan cnàmhag ,
plant of the skeletons ; lus nan cnaimhseag ,
plant of the dregs ; lus na fala ,
blood plant ; lus na fearnaich [cf . earna , earnach] , murrain plant ; dealt rùis , dealt drùis ; dealt ghréine ,
sun - dew , etc . Its deadly nature would seem to have been familiar to the people long before it was scientifically shown by Darwin . The people dislike the plant and apply to it such terms as they apply to marten - cat , fox , hoodie , harrier and other birds and beasts of prey . They say it digests and corrodes the stomach of an animal .

gaid .
Luck , success — success more than one ’ s own share . Thuit a chuid ’ s a ghaid air an duine ,
his own share and his gaid fell to the man — more than his share fell to the man . [This meaning is doubtful . Cf . ’ S ann thuit mo dhud ’ s mo dhadann / ghadann dhiom ,
‘ my hope fell altogether from me ’ , v , 122 . Other forms : thuit an dud ’ s an dad ; thuit an gud ’ s an gad . ]

gailleag .
Snap , fillip , snap with the finger , cracking the fingers in dancing . Tha iad a ’ gailleagaich air an ùrlar ,
they are snapping on the floor , as much as to say , they are dancing on the floor . gailleag is akin to sgailleag , sgoilleag ,
a smack , a blow , generally with the open hand . Thug mi sgailleag dha ’ s a ’ chluais ,
I gave him a smack / slap in the ear . [Cf . goilleag ,
blow on the cheek , slap on the face , Dw . sgailleag ,
dimin . of sgal ,
slap on the face ( Lewis ) ? See sgailleag ,
s . v . sgailig ,
Fr . Allan . ]

gairbhean .
Meal ground in a quern . See garbhan .

gairm .
Otter .

gairmein .
See cairmein .

gàis .
A spear , point . As , gàis na sgeine , saighde , a ’ chlaidhe ,
point of the knife , arrow , sword ; gàis na gréine ,
the sun prickles in the eyes . gàis also = anything to hurt the feelings . [In Arran gàis = loathing , TGSI , xxi , 258 . ]

gaist .
House built all of stone , bee - hive shaped . [Called both in Lewis . ]

galar beinne .
‘ Hill sickness ’ , another name of am bun dearg . [See ii , 238 . galar dearg ,
Dw . ]

galar gorm .
‘ Blue disease ’ , spaul ? The disease is brought on by eating a certain plant commoner in some places than in others , which pigs , however , eat without harm .

galar tioram .
‘ Dry disease ’ , fardel . ‘ Slug slàinte , cnàimh t ’ anshocair gun teaghail ’ ,
‘ Swallow health , chew thine ailment without . … ’ So said a Benbecula woman when feeding her cow which had the galar tioram .

galbh .
Gad . galbhag .
Gadding girl . galbhagaich .
Gadding about . O a ghalghad bhochd , bidh tusa ri do ghalbhagaich fhéin ,
‘ Oh thou poor girl , thou wilt be doing thine own gadding . ’ [ falbh ? ]

gall .
A pillar , boundary - stone . [E . Ir . gall , a pillar stone , a standing stone . ]

galloglaich .
See faircill .

gamhain .
See bioran .

ganndach , gannadach .
Scrimpt , scanty , meagre , stunted , stingy .

Tha còta gann gannadach
Air aon nighean Dòmhaill Daraich ,
Tha còta gann gannadach
Air Annabal nighean Dòmhaill .
Air Annabal nighean Dòmhaill Daraich ,
Annabal nighean Dòmhaill ,
Air Annabal nighean Dòmhaill Daraich ,
’ S e gannadach mu ’ n tòin di .

Crann gann gannadach
An talamh tana teann ,
Eich gun rian ’ ga tharraing
Agus bean gun chiall ’ nan ceann .
Plough scant and scrimpy in ground thin and hard , horses lacking sense / training drawing it and a woman without wisdom guiding them . [Cf . TGSI , xx , 148 . ]

gànran .
Ill - mannered , ill - conditioned [person] ; gànra gille ,
an ill - mannered boy .

gaoirne , daoirne .
Satiation , repletion .

gaothar .
Disease . Is tu chuir an gaothar ann ,
it ’ s you who put the disease in him .
garbhan , gairbhean . [Rough meal . ] See lòban .

Lite garbhain is bainne meilgich [mailgich , bailgich
Is mairg an tealbh dha nach fóghnadh . [sealbh , teach

Porridge of coarse meal and milk of goat , pity the person they would not suffice . [tealbh ?
Cf . sealbhan ,
throat ? e . g . ’ S ceart cho math dhut fàladair / A chàradh ri do shealabhan ,
SO , 380b . ]

Is math gum fóghnadh brochan garbhain
Agus meala - bhainne ghobhar dh ’ an rìgh .

A place in Sleat , Skye , is called An Garbhan .
Its locality was famed for milk , butter , cheese and garbhan ,
and each of these is commemorated in a place - name :

Lian a ’ Bhainne , Loch an Ime , Cnoc a ’ Chàise agus Bràigh a ’ Gharbhain .
The Meadow of the Milk , The Lake of the Butter , the Knoll of the Cheese and the Brae of the Coarse Meal .

substance . His name was Beul - Craois ,
Mouth of Voracity . [Cf . lon - chraois ,
Fr . Allan , 264 . Is this a reminiscence of the lon craís ,
demon of gluttony , in the early Irish story Aislinge Meic Conglinne ? ]

garbh - fhrasach foghair .
Great floods in autumn .

garman - uchd .
The front beam of the loom . garman - eudaich .
The back beam . [In Lewis garmainn ,
TGSI , xxxvii , 37 ; fem . in Ness . E . Ir . garman ( also garma , - n ) , f . , a weaver ’ s beam . ]

gàrradh - altram .
Plant nursery .

garannach , garralach .
See uanallach .

gasgan .
A flat plaited rope made of straw , bent roots or hair . [gasgan ,
a piece of rope to tie up a sail with when furled , but not attached to the sail itself , Fr . Allan . It was , however , used of ropes attached to the sail , e . g . A fuasgladh ghasgan a seōl ,
BTh , 285 , and this suggests that E . gasket was assimilated to the native gasgan ,
tail , extremity . For the unassimilated form cf . ’ S tu ri teannachadh gasket / ’ N am na siùil bhi ’ gam pasgadh , DSG , 33 . Cf . Làmh dhianamh nan gasgan ,
LG , 133 . ]

gàth .
Heavy rain , pouring rain , rain falling from the thatch , slates , rocks etc . [cf . gà , supra] . gàth nan cruach ,
the ‘ pour ’ of the stacks . gàth nan taighean ,
the ‘ pour ’ of the houses . gais [gàis ? ] = pour down .

gàth .
Noise , sound , the scarcely audible sound of fluids . gàth na h - aibhne ,
the hardly audible sound of the river [cf . iii , 154] . [See gà , supra . A secondary meaning of the preceding ? ]

gath - balg .
The reciter said that the gath - balg was a feat of arms done in or upon the water . He said the feat was difficult and the details complicated , but he would try to remember them for me some day ; that day , however , never came . As I understood the reciter , the combatants were required to wade waist - deep into water to fight . [This is the famous gaí Bulga , gaí Bolga , ‘ the spear of Bulga ’ , explained by O ’ Rahilly , EIHM , as the lightning - weapon ; see especially pp . 61 ff . But see Pokorny , Celtica , v , 231 . ]

gealach an ruadhain .
The reddening moon , at the time when vegetables begin to get brown .

gealachan .
A moonstruck person , a lunatic ; also a man walking by moonlight .

gealag .
Whiteling . gealag bhùrn .
Water whiteling , water trout . gealag mhara .
Sea whiteling , grilse . So with bànag ,
whiteling : bànag bhùirn ,
water whiteling , white trout , a white grilse , white salmon . bànag bheinne ,
‘ hill whiteling ’ , is a ptarmigan ( like gealag bheinne ) . See tarmachan .

gealbhan .
Fire , glowing fire , specially applied to the fire of a kiln .

geamhais . [ ? Cf . geamh ,
compensation , Dw ; gèamh in Lewis . ] See seamhas .

geanag .
Female child . geanan .
Male child . geanag also = bean - ghlùin ,
midwife ( ? ) .

gearra - breac .
The lesser black - backed guillemot [ii , 299] . It is about the

size of a dove , with red feet , and feeds on cudainn ,
coalfish , and shellfish . It goes singly . See cearc - mhara .

geàrrach .
Flux . See seanntraigh .

gearrachu .
See mìolchu .

gearra - ghille .
See corra - ghille .

gearradh - maighich .
Hare - lip . Also milleadh - maighich .

gearraiste .
See luirgneachan .

gearraloman .
See cearrdubhan .

geaslag , geasrag .
A spell . Chuir a ’ bheanag geaslag ort ,
the little fairy woman has laid a spell on thee .

geibleid .
Thin ill - grown creature , man or beast , akin to dwarf ; akin to tàcharan in meaning . Nach tu a ’ gheibleid ,
art thou not the dwarf ! [gioblaid ,
North Uist . gioblait ,
person wearing a long ragged garment , Dw . Cf . giobal ,
rag , clout . ]

geodal , geodail .
Dialect language . [godail ,
jabbering , unintelligible jargon , North Uist . gòdail ( sic ) , Fr . Allan , 261 . Cf . E . Ir . got , stammering , lisping . ]

geòlach .
See tapag .

geop .
Gossip . geopach .
Gossipy . geopadh .
Gossiping , given to gossip . [Cf . ’ S ann aca bha ghip - gheop .
E . Ir . gib - gab , unintelligible gabbling , jargon ; also gic - goc . According to Kuno Meyer from Sc . and northern Eng . giff - gaff , meaning ‘ give and take ’ and then ‘ interchange of remarks , promiscuous talk ’ . Cf . giff - gaff in Canu Aneirin , ed . Ifor Williams , p . 323 . Cf . ON geip , idle talk , nonsense . geobadaich ,
Fr . Allan . ]

giadh coilich .
Goose - cock , male goose , gander . The formation of the term is like that of smeòrach coilich ,
cock - mavis , tunnag coilich ,
cock - duck , lacha coilich ,
the cock of the wild duck .

Tha mi mar ghiadh coilich air dùnan Shanndaig ;
Nam bithinn an Luing na ’ n Saoil na ’ n Sgarbaidh
Is ioma té churanta cheannard cheannaghlas
Thigeadh dham choimhead ’ s a leigeadh a teannaghlaodh .

giadh - gob , gobghiadh .
Raingoose . giadh - glas , glasghiadh .
Grey goose . [gèadh - gaob ,
Dw (
Alexander Carmichael ) . ]

gifeireachd , giuchailis .
Trifling . [giofaireachd , giofachd ,
officiousness , Dw ; githeilis ,
running to and fro on trifling errands , id . gifeilis ,
Fr . Allan . ]

gil .
Watercourse on a mountain - side , rift , narrow chasm . [ ON gil , ravine , gully . The existence of this word as a common noun in Gaelic
has been called in question by Professor Fraser , SGS , v , 177 , but it is well - known in Lewis . ]

gille .
Servant , lad , son . As a term of praise , is tu an gille ,
thou art the boy ! As opposed to a man :

Cha ghille tha uams ’
Ach fear gasda gun ghruaim ,
Làmh stiùireadh nan stuagh ,
I bhith deas no bhith tuath ,
Le soirbheas math cruaidh
Nach tilleadh sinn .

gille cas - fliuch .
One who carries the chief over rivers . gille ceann - each .
One who leads horses . gille chùl - chas .
Footman . gille ceann - uidhe .
One who leads . gille ceann - snaodh .
One who leads in a foray . gille - pleibir .
See pleibir .

gillir .
See magairle mór .

giod .
A prank , flightiness . giodan .
Flighty boy . giodag .
Flighty girl . giod ( a ) man .
Flighty person . giod ( a ) manachd .
Given to lightness of conduct , flightiness . [Cf . giodaman ,
perky fellow , McB . giodag ,
iv , 56 ; v , 388 . ]

gioganach .
Infirm man . [Cf . gigean ,
dwarf ; gigeanach ,
dwarfish , Dw . ]

giolcam - daoram .
Animalcule next in size to the one that frequents the mite ’ s ear . [Cf . Rev . John MacRury , TGSI , xx , 149 : ‘ … bha na Gàidheil a ’ creidsinn gu robh creutair ann a bha mìle uair na bu lugha na frìde . B ’ e sin an stiolcam - staodhram a bha ann am bacan na h - iosgaid aice . Mar a bha an fhrìde a ’ tighinn beò le bhith cnuasach ann an craiceann an duine , bha an stiolcam - staodhram mar an ceudna a ’ tighinn beò le bhith cnuasach ann an craiceann na frìde . ’
See also J . G . Campbell , Superstitions , 220 : ‘ The Giolcam - daoram ,
or Gigelorum , is the smallest of all animals . It makes its nest in the mite ’ s ear and that is all that is known about it . ’ giolcam - daobhram ,
HSD . ]
giolceam ? giolceann ( MS . giolcainn ? ) = meanbh = small , invisible to most men . [Cf . preceding . ]

giolpan .
Sic leg . , for siolpan , q . v . ?

giorrne .
See guairne .

giuchailis .
See gifeireachd .

giùd .
A mean , low , dirty person ; a person of mean , low , dirty , contemptible action . Ach , nach e an giùd e !
Ah ! is not he a low dog ! [giùdaire ,
a wily man of stealthy movements , TGSI , xxxvii , 40 . giùd ,
wile , stratagem , evil contrivance , deceit ; worthless fellow , Dw . ]

giullaichean = dearbhadh ,
proving , making sure . [Cf . geall ? ]

giùran , giughran .
Barnacle - goose . A lisping child of one of the famous Mac Mhuirich bards said :

Chunna mi mac giùrain air tràigh ,
Chunna mi strathair ’ na clàraibh sgaipte ,
Chunna mi lacha le linn air snàmh ,
Chunna mi cartan an spàg Cheistein .

The cartan [also gartan] is a small brown insect , common to Europe , Asia and Africa , which burrows beneath the skin and very specially beneath the toe - nails ; it causes great pain and is very difficult to eradicate .
[E . Ir . gigrann , giugrann , a wild goose , a barnacle goose . ]

giuthas coinnil , giuthas coinnle .
Before the introduction of paraffin into the Highlands the people were ill off for light and adopted many expedients to overcome their disadvantages . In the Isles and on the coasts the people , along with tallow candles , used fish oil , seal oil and whale oil [eòlan] . This oil was burnt in ordinary black crusies with the one point for light , but occasionally in a lamp with a circular body with three light points at equal distances . These lamps were sometimes of iron , sometimes of brass and sometimes of copper , and were pretty and effective . This style of lamp was called crùisgein trine ( ? )
, the ordinary black lamp being known as crùisgein dubh .
On the Mainland , along with tallow candles , the people used bog pine . The bog pine made good light but was not lasting . In some places when the bog pine was good and plentiful little else was used in the houses of the crofters .

Gleanna mìn Moireasan
Far nach ith na coin na coinnlean ,
Cha tugainn gaol na comain dhaibh
Gun solus na gun soillse .

giuthas crea[g] [creige ? ] .
Rock - fir , is a rock which burns like wax in the fire .

glagail .
Loquacious . [Loquacity ? ]

glaine nathair , glaine nan Druidh .
See clach nathrach .

glaistig .
See logaid .

glasad , glasod .
The top of the side wall of a house , probably from glas - fhàd , glas - fhòd ,
green sod placed on the wall . See glas - cheap .

glasadh .
See coill .

glas - cheap , glas - fhòd .
The turf laid on the top of the wall of a house . See glasad .

glas - chìodhlan .
Lock - jaw . [Also glas - charbad ( charbard ) .
Cf . No Duin ’ eir am bio ’ dh Glascharbaid ( glossed Jaw lock ) , G , 190 . cìodhlan ( or cìdhlean , cìbhlean ) , pl . of ciobhall , cidheall , ciothall ,
the jaw . cìbhlean ,
Fr . Allan . ]

glasghiadh .
See giadh glas .

glaslus , glasliath , liathlus .
Artemisia or wormwood . This plant was used by women in confinement . [liath - lus ,
Fr . Allan . ] See liathlus .

glidheach , glitheach .
Wrong , wrong course , wrong side , astray .

gliongag .
Door staple .

glogaich , glomhaich .
See glùn .

glòmaich .
See coill .

glug .
‘ Gluck ’ , a peculiar sound of liquids , a peculiar sound in the throat . An glug Eigeach ,
the Eigg ‘ gluck ’ — the people of the island of Eigg [and some adjacent districts] cannot pronounce the letter l [unlenited broad l] with ease , if at all [they approximate it to a w - sound] . Sometimes the phrase is an glug Eigeach ’ s an sgleog Uibhisteach ,
the Eigg ‘ gluck ’ and the Uist slaver . [Henderson , The Gaelic Dialects , ZCP , v , 93 ; C . M . Robertson , CR , iv , 74 ; Jackson , Notes on the Gaelic of Port Hood , Nova Scotia , SGS , vi , 92 . ]

glùn .
Knee ; mastery , domination . In wrestling the uppermost boy places his knee upon the chest of the undermost boy to show the mastery of the one and the subjection of the other . Chuir e glùn air ,
‘ he put knee on him ’ ; chuir an duine glùn air an t - saoghal ,
‘ the man put knee upon the world ’ , implying that he subjected the world to himself . Chuir an saoghal a ghlùn orm ,
‘ the world has placed its knee on me ’ , implying that the world has gone against the speaker . Chuir Mac Bhraiche glùn air Mac Ghaisge ,
‘ Mac Malt has put his knee upon Mac Hero ’ .

glùn .
Knee ; joint ; generation . Thig an seachdamh glùn gu glogaich / glomhaich ( ? ) ,
the seventh generation will come to stupidity / gluttony . [See RG , 290 . ]

glùn .
Knee . bean - ghlùin ,
midwife . Other terms for midwife are : bean - asaid , bean - chobhair , bean - chomain , bean - chomhnadh , bean - choimheadaidh , bean - chonganta ; bramach / bromach - inilt , brannach / bronnach - inilt .
See bean - bàireach .

Many terms of delicacy and significance are in common use in the Isles concerning pregnancy and childbirth . These terms are specially current among women , not so well - known among men : Gearan nam ban , coireall nam fear ,
the moan of women , the mirth - song of men . Tinneas nam ban , binneas nam fear ,
the malady of women , the melody of men . Acain nam ban , lasgan nam fear ,
the lament of women , the laughter - peal of men . Osnaich nam ban , brosnaich nam fear ,
the sigh of women , the solace of men . Cneadaich nam mnà , gàirich nam fear ,
the groaning of women , the laughter of men . Galar mnà air a glùn , galar mùirn gach té ,
the sickness of woman on her knee , the sickness that gladdens each woman . Chaidh mi trì turais air mo ghlùn dha mo dhuine gaolach ,
I went three times upon my knee to my beloved husband .

Among the crofters of the Isles a temporary bed of straw is made before the fire for the woman in labour . Hence a parturient woman is said in euphemism to be air na suip ,
‘ on the straws ’ .

glup , glupad , glupadadh ; clup , clupad , clupadadh .
A throat disease to which people and cattle alike are liable , especially people and cattle confined to marshy places . [Also glubadaich , plubadaich , plucadaich . ]

Ged a chuirim dhachaigh thu
Cha ghabh thu tùrn ;
Bios an dìnneir fadalach
A dh ’ aindeoin cùis ;
A ’ clupadaich ’ s a ’ casadaich ,
A ’ ruchdadaich ’ s a ’ rachdadaich
’ S a ’ tarrainn bhùrn ; [rùchd , bhrùchd
Guma h - olc dh ’ an chnatan
Nach do ghabh e thù !
Guma h - olc dh ’ an chlachan ( ? ) [dub . lect .
Nach do ghabh e thù !

gnìp [grìop ,
North Uist] . The people of Uist apply the word to the steep rocks along the east side of their island . Gnìpeach is the name of a farm on Loch Faochan , Argyll . [ ON gnípa , f . , peak , jutting pinnacle on a mountain . Cf . grìopa , gnìopa ,
‘ a high rocky shore , in Skye and Uist ’ , Henderson , NICS , 122 ; gnìoba , grìoba ,
id . , 210 . Place - names in Lewis and Skye . ]

gnos .
See droll .

gnùgail .
Surly weeping . [Cf . gnùgach ,
gloomy , Fr . Allan . E . Ir . grúc ( grúig ) , displeasure , anger , grudge . ]

gob na speireige .
‘ The hawk ’ s bill ’ , an emblem of life ( dealbh na beatha ) among folk of old . [Meaning ? ]

gobghiadh .
See giadh - gob .

gobha dubh nan allt .
Dipper ( bird ) . [gobha dubh an uillt ,
Fr . Allan . gobha uisge etc . , Dw . ]

gobhar ,
pl . gobhair .
A sheaf of hay kept for seed . [gobhar ,
sheaf of corn — Skye , Dw . ]

gobhar bhacach .
See coinnleag . [cailleach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

godanadh .
See Conan Corr .

gogaire , gògaire .
A gouk , a gawkerel , a silly person , a person sent ‘ a - gouking ’ on the first of April [Latha na Gogaireachd] , an April fool . gogaireachd , gògaireachd , gogmaireachd .
The work of a gouk , April fooling , mockery , teasing . [In Lewis gocaireachd ,
pronounced with close o . ] See feachaire .

goicin - cuaiche .
Cuckoo - pint . [gaoicín cúthaig , cuckoo - pint or wake - robin , Dinn . gocan - cubhaige ,
Dw , but in sense of titlark , little bird always following the cuckoo . gocan na cuthaige ,
Fr . Allan , in latter sense . ]

goigean .
A torch made of cloth tied on a stick dipped in tar and set fire to ( like the ‘ clavie ’ of the East Coast ) .

goilein , goillein .
Light . Cuir goillein ris an lamp ,
put light to the lamp . [goillean ,
Fr . Allan . ]

goillse .
Gleams of sun through rain , alternate sunshine and showers . Goillse agus cioraich [ciurach ,
North Uist ; cf . ciurach ,
adj . , MC , 116] a ’ treòrach a chéile ,
sunshine gleams and mistiness [drizzle] leading one another . Latha goillseach ,
a day of sunshine and showers , a condition of

weather much desired by farmers in spring and summer . Latha grianach gruamach goillseach ,
a day of sunshine , of surliness and of cloudiness . Latha goillseach gruamach gun a thuar a bhith air no dheth ,
a day of gloom and surliness , not appearing to be on nor off , a day of alternate darkness and brightness and showers and sunshine . Latha guanach goillseach chur aoibh anns an talamh ,
a bright and cloudy day for putting cheer in the ground .

Goillse agus gailleann
Is math dhuinn le chéil ’ iad ,
Am Fear a chuir oirnn iad
Chuir E ’ n òra ghréin oirnn .

goirealach , goirearlach .
An unmarried man , a bachelor , an old bachelor . A curious custom prevailed in Uist that the oldest unmarried man in the place must carry , on feastdays , Sundays and other public days , and at other times keep in a prominent place in his house , a staff so exceptionally long that , carried upright as it had to be , it towered above the bearer ’ s head . This staff was called cuaille / bata goirealaich ,
bachelor ’ s staff . Not every man could bear with equanimity the notoriety and jest thus occasioned , and its bearer usually seized the earliest opportunity to hand it to a successor . This he did in the marriage reel , for these two danced together in the first reel . An goirealach gòrach , am pòsach glic ,
the bachelor foolish , the marrier wise . [Cf . goireal ,
used apparently of a barren cow , MC , 300 . ]

golag .
See bonnach boise .

gòrag .
See topan .

górag .
Compass for measuring . [gobhrag , gobharag ,
compasses , Fr . Allan . Cf . gobhar ,
the sign Capricornus of the zodiac ; gobhraidh ,
compasses , callipers — Lewis , Dw . ]

gòthan = mì - dhùrachd ,
ill - will , ill - wish , trifling , idling , self - will . Is tu an gòthan ,
thou art the idle saunterer . [Cf . gòth ,
airy gait ; gòthan ,
airy youth ; gòthanach ,
envious , malicious , Dw . ]

gradan .
Meal expeditiously obtained from grain burnt off the stalk . From grad ,
quick . [Really from gread ,
burn , scorch . ] The grain end of the sheaf was placed over a flame and the grain was allowed to drop off on the floor . The form of the word in Islay is greadan ,
as : Bha greadan Phàra Speinnse / aig mnathan - seinnse Chille - rubha ,
the change - wives of Kilarrow had the greadan of Patrick Spens . gradan is also applied to home - made snuff . See fuirireadh . [gradanadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

grainnseach .
A grange or granary . The district of Trondairnis ,
Trotternish , in Skye , produces grain in abundance , and is therefore called Grainnseach Clàr Sgìth ,
the granary / grange of the land of Skye ; An Grainnseach Sgitheanach ,
the granary / grange of Skye ; Grainnseach Chlann Domhnaill ,
the granary / grange of Clan Donald . It is also known as Dùthaich nan Stapag , Clàr nan Stapag and An Clàr Stapagach ,
the country
or land of the ‘ stappacks ’ , stapag being a mixture of oatmeal and cold water . See fairtheadh ; mogan ; potag .
graothaich , graoich , graoin , gruain [also craothaich etc . ] . Meal mixed with cream , milk , whey or water and better known as fuarag and stapag .

greim - lòin .
See lus mór .

greim - siubhail . [A bite of food for the road , viaticum . Cf . AMD Voc . , p . 62 : biadh - siubhail ,
provision for a journey . One MS . adds
’ n uair a sgaoileas corp an duine ,
when man ’ s body dissolves , and so what is probably meant is the bread placed with the dead in the coffin to sustain the pilgrim on his journey to the otherworld . ]

griadach .
A female unbaptised child ; often a natural child .

’ Tis the griadach who has done for me , ’ tis the griadach who has harmed me ; ’ tis the griadach who has done for me and the black smith of the torments . The black smith of disasters , the black smith of torments , ’ tis the black smith of disasters to - day has wounded me .

[See i , 114 - 115 , and Maol Domhnaich , infra . Cf . Records of the Presbyteries of Inverness and Dingwall : Greadich nein ean vic Conchie Ryach , p . 151 , who seems to be the same as Christine neine ean vic Kenneth , p . 149 ; Greadach Munro , mentioned in A Treatise on the Second Sight , p . 11 , Miscellanea Scotica , Vol . iii . ]

griam , griaman .
The fronds ( ? ) hanging from the trees , especially birch trees . Tha e cho liath leis an iadach ri griaman nan craobh ,
he is as grey with jealousy as the griaman of the trees . Cf . gròm , infra . [griam ,
kind of lichen growing on stones and trees , Dw . ]

grianan .
A sunny bower . Grianan Gràinne ,
‘ the sun - bower of Gràinne ’ , Fionn ’ s wife who eloped with Diarmaid , is the name of a place in Islay .

Grianan gaolach aona chroinn
Air chùl gaoithe , air aodann gréine ,
Far am faiceadh i ’ n saoghal uile ,
Is far nach faiceadh fuidir a loinn .

[fùidir ,
fool , lout , clown , Dw (
Alexander Carmichael ) . The vowel seems to be short here . ] This is part of a poem on Deirdre . [For the sake of rime perhaps the first and second lines should be interchanged . ]

grianuisg .
‘ Sun - water ’ , a colourless person , a washed - out thing , place or person , anything bedraggled , silly person , ‘ skilpit ’ girl . A ghrianuisg thruagh , mo luaidh do leannan ! ,
‘ thou pitiable grianuisg , my love thy lover ! ’ A ghrianuisg ruadh , mo thruaigh do leannan ! ,
‘ thou red - haired grianuisg , pity thy lover ! ’ This is said by one person to another , generally by one girl to another girl , in a spirit of banter .

grigein .
See frìd .

grigne .
A group , a cluster , a number of things together , as grigne dhaoine ,
a band of men ; grigne chaorach ,
a collection of sheep ; grigne thaighean ( Lewis ) , the houses of a townland . In Uist the corresponding term is grunn ; grunnan thaighean ,
clusters of houses . Also gnige ; gnige ghruagach ,
a band of maidens . [grigne is known in Uist also . Cf . grigne ,
a small gathering huddled together , Fr . Allan , p . 261 . ]

grìleag .
See fìneag . [grìolagan ,
Fr . Allan . Also crileag , griuilleag ,
Dw . ]

grìs , grìse .
Heat , embers . grìs an casan an eich ,
heat in the feet of the horse . [E . Ir . grìs , heat , fire , embers , hot ashes . ]

grìs , grìsionn .
A cold , a shiver , a shivering cold , grue , gruey , gruesome , dread fear , trembling . Tha grìs fhuachd orm ,
a shiver of cold is upon me . Tha grìsionn cruaidh cnatain air an duine ,
there is a hard shiver of cold upon the man . [grìs ,
a shivering cold , TGSI , xxxvii , 45 . ]

groillean .
Short sword . [Cf . greidlean ,
bread - stick , pot - stick , scimitar ; groidlean ,
spirtle , pot - stick ; greillean ,
dagger , old rusty sword . — Dw . Cf . An am rùsgadh nan greidlean tana ,
BGh , l . 5751 ; ’ S ann bu choslach e ri greidlean ,
DB , l . 72 and n . ]

gròm .
The scurf of tiny shellfish growing on stones in the strand , also called sgreagag . gròm .
Grime , lichen growing on trees , also called griam , q . v . [Called sgum in Ness , Lewis . gròm ,
minute shellfish that cover tidal rocks and stones , TGSI , xxiv , 359 . gròtham ,
plankton , Fr . Allan . ]

gruaigean .
A sea - plant of the tangle species , called biadhag ,
food , and eaten under the name of gruaigean .
It is considered wholesome and palatable . [gruaigein ,
Fr . Allan . ]

gruain .
See graothaich .

grùd .
A contemptible man . [Cf . grùid ( grùig ,
Fr . Allan ) , also drùid ,
lees , dregs , grounds , sediment . E . grout , OE grút . ]

gruithim , grithim .
Curds , worked curds used as kitchen with no butter mixed — though the word is from gruth + ìm ,
no butter is mixed in the curds in Strath Carron , Wester Ross , now . [gruitheam ,
Fr . Allan , 262 . ]

guagach .
Thick - set . [See cuaigean ; guaigean ; guaigeanach ,
Dw . ]

guailleach , guailleachan .
A shoulder - cape or cloak . In some districts called tonnag ,
in others filleag or filleadh .
It was fastened under the chin with a cord of wool or of silk or of satin ribbon , and several inches lower down with a brooch of bronze , copper , silver or gold , according to the means of the wearer .

A nall dhomh e ’ .
‘ Where ’ s my cloak ? Hand me it . ’ They were married . guailleachan [guailleanach ,
Berneray , Harris] also means a friend , companion , confidant . See also tonnag .

gual .
The rope from the tackle of a loom for tightening the crann - snàth ,
yarn - beam .

gual .
Coal , char , charcoal . Metaphorically sorrow :

Tha do chuimhneachain àlainn [gràdhach
Air mo chnàmh ’ s air mo ghual , [sìor àrach mo
’ S tha do leaba gun chàradh
’ S thus a ghràidh anns an uaigh . [chuan

Air mo ghualadh ’ s air mo losgadh
Bhith dha faicinn air do thoisgeil .

guairne , giorrne .
The wood chaff , the wood dust made by the auger in boring wood ; sawdust . [guairne - mu - ghuairn , giùirne - mu - ghiùirn ,
auger - dust , Dw . Cf . Co dhiùbh ’ s fhusa bata dheanamh de ’ n ghuairne mu ghuairn , no cuaille de ’ n ghiùrne mu ghiùrn ?
‘ Whether is it easier to make a stick of the quill - pith , or a stake of the auger - dust ? ’ , NGP , 153 . giornanach ,
spiral , Dw (
Alexander Carmichael ) . Fr . Allan has giurne , guairne ,
of uncertain meaning . Possibly to be connected with guardal , guairdeán , guairneán ,
gyration , whirling , etc . , discussed by O ’ Rahilly , Celtica , i , 378 - 381 . ]

gudaboc .
Snipe in winter . naosg .
Snipe in summer . Cf . trìlleach . [gudaboc ,
also gudabochd , butagochd , udagoc , udacag ;
E . woodcock . ]

gudadh , gudanadh .
See Conan Corr .

guidseal , guidsealt = trod mòr ,
a great quarrel . [Probably same as cuidseal
E . cudgel . ]

guirmean .
See crotal .

guit .
A circular corn - fan . See beanntag ; fasgnag ; nasg .

gulm .
A speck , spot , cataract upon the eye . gulman .
Small speck . sùil ghuilm , sùil ghulmain ,
cataract eye . [gulm ,
iv , 222 , 224 , 236 , 246 ; gulman ,
iv , 222 , 226 ; culm ,
iv , 232 . gulman ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Bheathaicheadh air … gulam eòrna ,
MC , 378 . culm ,
atom , scum , a slight haze , TGSI , xxxvii , 13 . C . M . Robertson suggests culm ,
obscurity , haze about the moon , etc . , may be a variant of gulm ,
a frown , etc . , from E gloom , CR , iv , 279 . But cf . E culm , soot , smut , coal - dust ? ]

gulmag .
See trìlleach .

gur .
Hatching [see i , 284 ff . ] . The cearc bhreac ,
speckled hen , was selected to bring out the brood . She was thought to hatch closer than a hen of one colour — not so apt to leave the eggs . She was supposed to possess more natural heat than a black hen and to be hardier than a white hen . The eggs were placed in the clutch with the thumb and middle finger . They were set out on Là Chaluim Chille ,
St Columba ’ s Day , Thursday ,

and they were due to come out on the Friday three weeks after , being twenty - one clear days in hatching , if the hen sat regularly . Twelve is the proper linn ,
brood , for a hen , linn slàn , làn linn .
If above this the linn is linn mhór ,
big brood ; if below this it is linn bheag ,
small brood . If a hen is left to herself she will lay twelve eggs and then hatch . But if she is taken up and fed well and kept dry and warm she will go on laying till she has laid four or five times twelve eggs before she stops .

gurasgaich [leg . gurasglaich ? ] .
See bura - bhuachaill .

gurra - gù , gurra - gùg .
Pigeon .

Fhuair mi nead a ’ ghurra - gùg
Ann an cùil na mòine ,
Fhuair mi nead an fhithich ann
’ S a rithist nead na smeòraich .
I found the nest of the pigeon in the nook of the moor [recte , peat bin] , I found the nest of the raven there and again the nest of the mavis .

[guragug ,
ring - dove or wood pigeon , TGSI , xii , 56 . ]

iacaireachd .
Convenient [ ? ] .

ial .
Light , dim light , brightness , dawn ; ial na gealaich ,
the radiance of the moon ; ial an latha ,
gleam of day , dawn of day ; ial eadar dà fhras ,
light between two showers . [ial ,
iii , 158 , 292 ; iv , 84 ; ialaidh ,
iii , 248 . Cf . Thig ial an lath na dīle a ’ s mò ,
S , 536 . ialaichean teithe ,
gleams of sunlight on a dull or showery day , Applecross . ]

ial .
A temporary rest .

iall .
See stòp .

ialsatarg .
Bat ( animal ) . [Also ialtag , dialtag ( see tur ) . ] See sgiathan leathair . [E . Ir . íaltóc , dimin . of íatlu with metathesis . ]

ian bàn an t - sneachd .
See tarmachan .

ian Bealltain , ian bùchainn .
See far - ghuilbneach .

iarann .
Iron . Nails or spikes of iron used to be placed crosswise on the chest of a dead person . The spikes were left in the same position in the coffin and buried with the dead . The object was to avert evil influence , as evil spirits were repelled by iron .
iarmad . [Offspring , posterity , remnant , remainder . ]

Mo Dhia , mo Dhia , tha mi ag iarraidh ort
Gun m ’ fhàgail am pian gu sìorraidh an sloc ;
Na fàg mi an cian ’ s na fàg mi an sproc ,
Na fàg mi an iarmad , mo Chrìosd , a nochd .
Mo Dhia , mo Dhia , tha mi grìosad riut
Mo chridhe ’ s mo chiall ’ s mo bhriathra bhith dhut ,
Mo tharraing gu Crìosd , gu chriachd is gu fhuil , [chreuchd
’ S mo chomhnaidh gu sìor fo d ’ mhiann ’ s fo d ’ bhuil .
[bhith ’ na mhiann ’ s ’ na bhuil .
[E . Ir . íarmar , remnant , posterity , survivors . ]

iarna .
See conn .

iasg baintighearna .
‘ Lady ’ s fish ’ . So the liugha , liùgh ,
lythe , is called , from the tenderness of its flesh . It is in season in September .

ìcearnadh .
Placenta of women . [ ìc + teàrnadh ?
Cf . teàrnadh ,
the afterbirth , Fr . Allan . ]

idusg .
Restless . idusgeil , idusgean .
Restlessness . [A mistranscription ? Cf . iodraisg ; iodraisgeach ,
on tenterhooks , North Uist . ]

imdeal .
A vessel in which the milk was carried home from the shieling . It was sometimes slung on a pole shouldered between two persons and sometimes slung on horseback . The cord was used in tying the imdeal to the mouth of the cuman ,
the imdeal being in this case the bùilig of other places . [In the Isles the word usually means ‘ piece of sheep - skin tied securely round the mouth of a milk - pail ’ , e . g . when it is being carried in a creel ; see TGSI , xxxvi , 32 . Often spelled iomaideal , imideal ,
but the second vowel is svarabhakti . See imbhuideal ,
TGSI , xxiv , 359 , and Dw , s . v . If Robertson ’ s derivation of im + buideal is right , then the island meaning of ‘ dressed skin used as lid for keg ’ is the primary one , and ‘ wooden keg , pail , vessel ’ is a secondary meaning . ] See stòp .

innspe .
A knife used by tinkers in making horn spoons . [ìosp ,
tool used by tinkers for putting finishing touches on horn spoons , Dw . ]

insreadh .
Furniture . [innsreadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

iochd .
A ghost .

iola .
Fishing ground . Iolachan iasgaich ,
fishing banks off Barra . Iola Geòghamhna ,
near Pol - til , Skye . [From E . Ir . ailad , a tomb . From this word also comes ulaidh ,
a treasure , and an Ealaidh ,
the place where the dead were landed in Iona . See O ’ Rahilly , SGS , iii , 66 . ]

iolamanan .
Heddles of loom . [iomallan ( whence iolaman ,
by metathesis ) , see Dw , s . v . beart - fhigheadaireachd . ]

iolar .
Down , below , ‘ rest in a place ’ — Perthshire . [C . M . Robertson in his essay on Perthshire Gaelic says : ‘ Upwards and downwards are an aird and a bhàn ;
up and down ( rest ) are uthard and iolar ,
at Blair , h - uthard and h - iolar . Iolar is not a good spelling , the sound of io being short ao in one place and short û in another . The derivation seems to be an - làr . Uthard ,
in view of our tendency to retraction , might be for urad ,
and that , or rather thurad ,
is the form in Sutherlandshire ’ , TGSI , xxii , 33 . For urad ,
etc . , see Éigse , vi , 65 . ioras , uras , uireas are also found for iolar ( Dieckhoff , McB , HSD ) . ]

iomairt . [Cloth striped lengthwise only , Dw (
Alexander Carmichael ) . ] See tonnag .

ionndas .
Treasure .

Cha do chruinnich thu riamh a shalchar ( ? ) ,
Dh ’ òr no dh ’ airgead no dh ’ ionndas ,
Na ghabhar an éirig t ’ anama ,
Greas gun dearmad is gabh t ’ urnaigh .
( From ‘ Laoidh Dhùghaill Thàilleir , no Liosadair ’ )
[Also ionntas , iunndas , iunntas . ]

ionnrais .
Wind , high wind , storm . Also annraisd . Chan e an annraisd ach an aghaidh ,
it is not the storm but the headness / againstness . [iùnnrais ,
stormy sky , storm , tempest , Dw . Cf . Iunnrais analach nan speur ,
Sàr Òrain , p . 37 ; ’ S ma chì e an iunnrais ag éirigh ,
id . , p . 47 . ]

ioraisg .
Sickness , trouble , ill - health [ ? ] . [Rather ‘ a harum - scarum girl ’ ? ]

iorcachd .
Peevishness , crossgrainedness . A man in Heisgeir was called
an Iorcag
from his bad temper .

iospach .
See easpach .

irghinn .
Girl , daughter . This is the common word for a girl , a daughter , in Sutherland . It is considered vulgar in Perth , while caile ,
the usual Perth word , is deemed coarse in Sutherland . [irinn ,
Sutherland for inghean ,
daughter , Dw . iorainn ( Skye ) , Fr . Allan . ]

iris .
The carrying band of a creel , also called muicnis .
See corra - bheannach ; cruth - bhainne ; muicnis .

Tuitidh cliabh gun iris , ’ s théid a ’ bhuag ’ na h - ionad fhéin . [leg . bhriag ? ] [iris - mhuineil ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Is trom eallach gun iris ,
NGP , 293 ; Tuitidh cliabh gun iris , ’ s théid a ’ bhriag do h - ionad fhéin ,
id . , 374 . E . Ir . iris , a thong or strap ( from which a shield , bag , etc . , is suspended ) . ] See buag .

isean .
Chick , young [ii , 311] . In Harris isean an eich is applied to the foal till it is six months old ; thereafter it is spriodach till put into harness . In one end of Skye a filly or colt is called bionach or bionnach ,
in the other end biorach ;
in Uist and Barra it is loth whether male or female ; when six months old it is bliadhnach ,
later dò - bhliadhnach and trì - bhliadhnach [these are stressed on the first syllable : dòibhleannach , trìbhleannach] ,
and after that , each no làir ,
horse or mare . In Uist a horse is considered to be at its best at seven years and a mare at nine .

isean circ , isean eaglais .
See Maol Domhnaich .

iubhar .
Yew . iubhar beinne .
Mountain yew , juniper . iubhar uaine .
Green yew .

The yew was sacred in the Highlands and was used not only for making bows but for warding off witches , divining events and safe - guarding milk . Iubhar beinne and caorrann ,
mountain ash or rowan , were burnt on the doorstep of the byre on the first day of the quarter , on Beltane Day and Hallowmas . The byre lintel was sprinkled with wine , or , failing wine , with human urine . A rod of these or some other sacred wood was placed above the lintel . Tar was put behind the ear and below the feaman ,
tail , of the cows . This was done to safeguard the cattle bho dhosgaidh , bho ealtradh agus bho adhaircean a chéile ,
from mischance , mishap and each other ’ s horns . A cheese and a churning were made before sunrise to keep the fairies and all uncanny creatures away for the year or for the season . [iubhair beinne ,
Fr . Allan . ]

iuchar shamhraidh .
See am mìosachan .

iunntachd , iunntachas = dìoghlaim ,
gleaning of corn . See also dòman ; tiumachd .

labh .
See famh .

lach a ’ chinn rudhaich , lach a ’ chinn ruaidh .
‘ The duck of the ruddy or red head ’ , widgeon . Large flocks of these arrive in the Isles at the approach of winter . Also called lach - fead .

lach le linn .
A duck with a brood . It was crossed or forbidden ( air a chrosadh , air a thoirmeasg ) to take a duck with brood . It was impressed on boys that her brood was to a duck as her children are to a human mother , and the boy who took a duck with brood was denounced by his companions .

lacha liath , lachain liath .
Pin - tailed or long - tailed duck [ii , 312 f . ] . It frequents Port Eabaraig ( Eabairig ) , Hianais , Tiree , where it comes am bial bristidh ( where the waves begin to break on the shore ) , and sometimes inside that .

lacha Mhàrt .
See Màrt - lacha .

lacha riabhach , lacha mhór .
Mallard .

lacha stiùrach .
See easan mara .

lachdann .
See caora .

làd .
Pummel , belabour .

ladhragach .
See tur .

làgan .
See carran .

laighilt .
See laothadair . [laghaid , laghainn ,
Fr . Allan . ]

laimeist .
Thrash . laimeisteach .
Drubbing , bruising . laimeisteachadh .
Leathering . [
E . lambaste . ]

laimrig .
See tat .

lait , laic . Cha do rinn mi lait ( laic ) cadail = cha do rinn mi norra cadail ,
I did not have a wink of sleep . [More commonly lochd cadail ,
e . g . , ’ S cha d ’ fhuair mi lochd cadail / O ’ n a spad mi Cùl Chàirn ,
HS ’ 45 , 266 ; Cha ’ n fhaigh mi lochd chadail ,
WR , 63 , Folk Tales and Fairy Lore , 112 ; lochd cadail ,
Waifs and Strays , iv , 208 , 209 ; dimin . lochdan cadail ,
id . , ii , 354 , 356 ; iii , 47 ; luchdan cadail ,
WHT , ii , 222 . lochdadh ,
North Uist . Cha d ’ fhuair mi slaic chadail ,
Ness , Lewis . laic ,
Applecross . loc cadail ,
BTh , 221 . lochdadh and loiceadh ( p . 264 ) , Fr . Allan . E . Ir . loccad ( Hessen ) . ]

lamarach , lamrach = rud gun sùgh , rud gun bhlas ,
tasteless , ‘ wersh ’ . lamarachadh = parboiling . [Cf . lamaranta ,
soft , in a half - boiled or half - baked condition , Dw . ]

lamh .
See famh .

làmh .
A hand . Air làimh d ’ athar ’ s do sheanar ,
by the hand of thy father and thy grandfather . Air làimh d ’ athar ’ s do sheanar ’ s do shinn - seanar ,
by the hand of thy father and of thy grandfather and of thy great - grandfather . This form of asseveration was formerly common in Uist , the oath becoming more emphatic with each additional - father . It is not wholly obsolete , but it gives great offence to the person addressed . In the Isles of old they used to kiss the ground in emphasising their word , as they do still in parts of Ireland . See mionn . [See Éigse , viii , 247 - 248 . ]

langaidh .
Longbill . It has one sìolag ( viper - fish ) , and only one , in its bill for its chick . The duibheanach and the peata ruadh ( razorbill and puffin ) have each a dozen in their bills as they hurry home to their chicks . [langaidh ,
Fr . Allan . ON lang - vé , guillemot , sea - hen . ]

langais .
Side - fetter on an animal , running fore and aft . [ ON lang - festr ? ] Cf . urachal .

lann , lunn , lionn .
Film , fat , scum on the surface of liquids . lann air a ’ mhuir ,
sap upon the sea , the oil that comes to the surface from the fish in the sea . In summer there is a scum upon the sea . Tha lunn air uisge a ’ bhuntàta ,
there is film on the potato water . Tha lann air uisg an éisg ,
there is fat on the fish water . Tha lann air uisge an sgadain ,
there is scum on the herring water .

Also called mug , muga , mugaid , mungaid , mugaind . Chuir an rionnach mugaid air a ’ bhùrn ,
the mackerel put fat upon the water . Tha mugaid air bùrn nan sìolag ,
there is mould upon the water of the sandeels .

lann .
See leasgadan .

laob .
Drag through ( = Sc . harl ) .

laobhag .
A soft shoe , a soft - soled shoe , shoe made of calf leather , a shapeless shoe , a slipper . From laogh ,
calf . Incorrectly slaobag . laobhag , laoghan .
A soft person , a person lacking in backbone , a ‘ calf ’ . [Cf . laosbagan ,
Fr . Allan , 263 . slaofag ( with short - ao - sound ) , soft shoe or slipper , Applecross . ]

laom , laoman .
The whitish silvery hue arising from putrescence ; mould , mildew , a term applied to corn that has become mildewed whether on the ground or in the stack , anything musty or mouldy ; phosphor light , light or fire without heat . laom also means a moth , laoman ,
a little moth ; the Argyll form of the latter is laorman ,
as laorman olainn ,
a wool moth ; laorman feòir or laorman fuinn ,
a grass moth . laomadh .
The act of becoming mildewed , used of corn . The adjective laomach is used of anything tending to mildew , as coirce laomach ,
mildewed oats , whether on the ground or in the stack ; càise laomach ,
mildewed cheese , green cheese . From laom comes the following . [laom ,
of corn , usually means : to lodge , fall to the ground from exuberant growth ; of potatoes , to go to shaw or tops , Dw . leómann ,
moth , E . Ir . legam , is not to be connected . ]

laomachan .
‘ Little mouldy one ’ , was a rind of cheese used for divination . The cheese must be made on one of the four old festivals of the year : Bealltain ,
Beltane ; Lùnasd , Lùnasdal or Lùnasdain ,
Lammas ; Samhain ,
Hallowtide ; and Féill Brighde ,
the Feast of Brigit ; but on which of these is now uncertain . The milk used was that of a cow which had eaten the mòthan ,
pearlwort , for since the plant was sained the cheese was sained also . Twelve months after the cheese was made it was used . A small hole was made through the rind , and through this the diviner looked down through the fàrlas ,
smoke - vent of the house . The name of the first person thus seen through these two orifices was the name of the future spouse . When the laomachan was placed under the pillow , the

sleeper would in dreams see his future spouse coming towards him with gifts ; were the person seen receding , it indicated a parting . The laomachan safeguarded its wearer from the wiles of the fairies of the mound , from the venom of the hosts of the air , and from the misleading light of the teine mór or teine sionn ,
will o ’ the wisp . For naming , for dreaming and for safeguarding , the laomachan was effective only on the anniversary of the festival on which it was made , and only to those who had faith and sincerity of heart ; only to those who bowed to them were the names true . Many curious rites and ceremonies connected with the laomachan and its use are now but dimly to be descried through the darkness of ages .

laothadair [better laghadair] , laighilt .
Sets of moulds used by tinkers . [Also what bends the wood in boat - building . ] See bothaidh . [laghaid , laghainn ,
Fr . Allan . For laighilt cf . lathailt ,
McB , laipheid ,
MacL . ]

lasadh mara .
Sea - flame , phosphorescence .

lasag .
Land open to all cattle to trespass on . A bed on which children , be their feet clean or dirty , jump and roll and play , a free place with children as with cattle ; a common , common grazing land .

lasgaire .
See alladh .

Latha Coille , Latha Féill Coill .
See coill .

leac .
See ceap .

leagan .
A small stone placed under a big stone to steady it , a pinning under a stone in masonry . [Cf . leagan air gach leagan ,
v , 316 . Skimming a flat stone or pebble over smooth water is called in Lewis leum - leogain .
In Lewis the thin small stones used for packing or levelling the big stones were called painigean .
A leogan ,
if flat , was a painige (
Angus MacLeod ) . ( Cf . pannachan ,
anything crushed together to such an extent as to force its sides together , Bernera , Lewis , TGSI , xxxvii , 22 ) . ]

leagan , leagadh .
‘ Fall ’ , that which falls to the hunter in the hunt . Bithidh toradh mo leagain agam as an speill mhuc ,
I shall have the produce of my ‘ fall ’ from the drove of pigs . [MS . apparently speill ,
but the dictionary form is speil ,
and so Fr . Allan . E . Ir . speil , cattle , herd , flock ; L . spolium , O ’ Rahilly , SGS , ii , 26 . ]

leanabh .
See urra .

learga dhearg , learga dhubh .
See bura - bhuachaille .

learga ruadh . Is e comharra droch aimsir an uair a dh ’ éireas an learga ruadh dh ’ an adhar agus a ghabhas i lom agus dìreach roimpe a ’ sgreuchail cruaidh .
— It is a sign of bad weather when the red - throated diver ( ? ) rises into the air and flies straight on , screeching hard .

leasacha làmha .
Means much the same as luchd coinghill ,
helpers , loan workers , neighbours helping one another , servants .

leasgadan , diucal , diucadan , liucadan .
The concave half of the clam or scallop - shell . The flat half is am bord . leasgadan is probably leathsgoiltean [or leth + sgòdan ? ] , the half - slice , a term applied to anything

of the sort , as leathsgoiltean na còmhla ,
one leaf of a two - leaved door ; leathsgoiltean na muirsgean ,
half of the spout - fish or razor - fish . The castle of Ciosmal in Barra was slated with the leasgadan .
The shellfish is still plentiful around Barra , though not so plentiful as of old . liucadan also means lann air ceann na tarraing fuaigheil ,
a rove , concave on one side and convex on the other , used in clinching a rivet in boat - building . There was another kind of lann ,
rove , which was flat . See slige , slige chreachainn .

leathrachas = pòsadh ,
marriage . leobhrachas .
Booking for marriage .

leibideach , na leibidein .
See ròcas .

leid .
A temporary fireplace of three stones upon which to set a pot , etc .

leid , càrn , losgann .
A kind of cart or shaftless sledge .

leideis . Rud gun bhladh gun bhrìgh ,
a thing of nought , a thing of no value .

lèig .
A lakelet , a lagoon , a sheet of water smaller than a lake and larger than a pool . An Lèig ,
a place - name in Tiree , as an Lèig a Deas agus an Lèig a Tuath .
There is Lèig at Tangasdal , Barra , a lakelet , or nowadays rather a marsh , extending from Loch Tangasdal to the sea . [Cf . léig ,
a puddle , a marsh , sediment . Tha léig air màs a ’ bhotuill ,
TGSI , xxxvii , 44 . ]

leigeis .
A tool used by tinkers for cleaning the inside of a new spoon . Cf . corc eigidh , supra .

léine = sliochd ,
children .

léine bhàis .
See tarra / torra talmhan .

léine shona .
See currac - rath .

leobhrachas .
See leathrachas .

a leòra .
See mionn .

leòs = leus ,
a torch for losgadh na h - aibhne ,
‘ burning the river ’ . [Cf . Dh ’ fhuirich m ’ iasg anns an aigeal / Gun fhaicinn le leus ,
G , 54 ; Bi sùrd air leois gam pleòiteachadh ,
SO , 359a . Cf . PB , 270 ; GlenB , 147 . ’ S air huisge ’ s fior - bhras léus , / Ag oganachamh ríobhach , / Le morbha fior - chruaigh géur ,
AMD ( 1751 ) , 88 . Cf . ON ljós , a burning light ? ]

leth - chas [better leathchas ,
as the stress is on the first part] . A certain mode of working land in the Western Isles is called leth - chas , leth - chois = half - foot [really ‘ one of two feet ’ ] . The possessor of the land gives the ground and the seed , and the worker of the land gives half the produce to the possessor , retaining the other half in recompense for his services . [lethchas ,
métayage , Fr . Allan . See Clan Donald , iii , 139 . ]

letheadas .
Difference .

leum - roid .
Race leap , running leap . leum - seasaimh , - seasaidh , [cruinnleum , ] standing leap .

liabag .
Flounder . Thog an sgadan a cheann as a ’ mhuir agus thubhairt e , ‘ Is mise rìgh na mara ’ . Thog an liabag a ceann as a ’ pholl agus chuir i car cam ’ na bus agus thubhairt i , ‘ C ’ àit an d ’ fhàg thu mise ? ’ a ’ magadh air an sgadan . Tha an car cam am bial na liabaig riamh bho ’ n latha sin . O Mhoire , chan ’ eil am magadh gu math , is iomadh neach

dh ’ an do rinn e cron ! O bhìdh is aodaich , is iomadh neach sin !
— The herring raised his head out of the sea and said , ‘ I am the king of the sea ’ . The flounder raised her head out of the pool and put a wry twist in her snout and said , ‘ Where hast thou left me ? ’ mocking the herring . The wry twist is in the flounder ’ s mouth ever since that day . O Mary , mockery is not good , to many a one it has done harm ! O food and clothing , many a one ! — So said a dear old woman in Barra to me . [Cf . iv , 10 ; Leabhar Sheáin Í Chonaill , 416 . See braoisgean ; cama - chraosan . ] Rìgh gach iasg an sgadan ,
king of all fish is the herring . Rìgh gach iasg sgadan liath Loch Fìne ,
king of all fish is the grey herring of Loch Fyne . [Also lèabag , leóbag ;
Ir . leadhbóg . Cf . leòb ,
a piece , shred ; E . Ir . ledb . ]

liaghag .
Seaweed of the tangle species , visible at low tide .

Is ioma sgeir dhubh a shuath i
Agus bàirneach bhreac a bhuain i
Agus liaghag liath a ruaig i
Agus duileasg ciar a ghluais i [donn
Aig feabhas stiùraidh mac na h - uaisle .

[Cf . iv , 32 ; v , 312 . Sic leg . for liathag ,
iv , 17 . liaghag ; liaghain ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Agus liaghan ruith fo a gualainn ,
OL , 43 ; Gad a b ’ ann ’ s an liadhaig fheamann ,
id . , 107 ; Nuair a bhiodh do liaghain trāighte ,
BTh , 362 ; cf . id . , 400 . liagh ,
ladle , spoon , blade of oar . ]

liamh .
Broad , wide , expanding . liamhadh .
Broadening , widening , expanding . Duine liamhach ,
broad / broad - shouldered man . Liamhach mhór , ( sic ) mhnatha / bhoireannaich ,
a big broad woman . Bó liamhach ,
broad cow , usually of wide - spreading horns , sometimes of broad back . Liamh na sgeine ,
blade of the knife , broad of the knife . Liamh an ràimh ,
broad of the oar . Liamh and not liagh would seem to be the correct form for blade of knife , oar , etc . [liagh is certainly the correct form for blade of oar , and probably for blade of knife also . See preceding word . For liamh etc . cf . liamhach ,
iv , 167 ; liamhaidh ,
id . , 133 . lèabhach ( = liabhach ) ,
horns spreading wide apart as of cattle or sheep , TGSI , xxxvii , 41 ; Is casan fada liadhach / Mar shiaman de shlataibh mara ,
GlenB , 200 . ]

lianain , lìonaidh .
Supposed to be from lìon , lian . Leaba lianain , leabaidh lianaidh ,
linen bed , bed furnished with linen .

lianaraich , liaranaich .
Green water - herbs . [Other forms are : lìonaraich , lìonanaich , liaragaich , lìrean , lìreanach , lìreagach . lianaraich ,
Fr . Allan . ]

lianntrachd .
See frìd .

lias .
A speck ( = leus ) . [Cf . lias ,
a mole , beauty - spot , v , 200 , 226 , 232 . ball - losgaidh , lias - losgaidh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

liasag .
A thin gruel drink made for infants and invalids . Water is poured

over meal and allowed to stand . The water is then poured off and boiled , when the liquid thickens . liasag choirc ,
oat water ; liasag eòrna ,
barley water ; liasag sheagail ,
rye water . liasag is akin to easan ,
but not the same . [ liath + easag ? ]
liath - dhealt [stressed on the first part] . Mildew .

liathlus . [Wormwood . ] Is good for liunnaidh .
See glaslus . [liath - lus ,
Fr . Allan . ]

libhinn .
Bathing , washing , lustrating . From li = water , liquid . [See Glossary under li , lighe , lìobhadh . ]

lighe .
Flood .

Tha mo chasan a ’ call an coiseachd ,
Tha mo cheuman a ’ fàs fann ,
Tha mo rasgan gu bras a ’ sileadh
Ceart co mirein ri ligheadh allt .

[Cf . the well - known song , Tha lighe ’ n diugh ’ san Alltan Dubh ; gàir na lighidh làin ,
S , 256 . E . Ir . lie , lia , flood . ]

lìme , lìmin , lìmeadh , lìmneadh .
To stroke , to press together soft substances as butter , dough and clay . Probably a side - form of slìm , slìmeadh ,
sleek . [In v , 342 , limeadh seems to have short - i - , riming with ime . ]

linn , linn slàn ( lànlinn ) , linn mhór , linn bheag .
See gur .

liobaid , liopaid .
Is used to indicate a scale or something which prevented one ’ s eye from seeing correctly . Mac Mhaighistir Alasdair met a woman once and they had some sharp passages of wit as they talked . One of her replies to him was , ‘ Tha liopaid air do shùil , a bhalaich ’ ,
‘ There is a scale on your eye , you clown ’ .

lioc .
Grave ( Uist ) . See slioc ; ploc .

lìon - anairt .
White cloth of the linen kind , not necessarily linen . The people speak of anart lìn ,
cloth of lint , and anart cotain ,
cloth of cotton .

lìon leathann làir or cama - lìon .
Ground - lint .

lìon - rath .
See currac - rath .

lionn .
Scum , oily film on the sea . See lann , lunn .

lionn - tàth .
A liquid cement made of aol shligean ,
the lime of the shells of shellfish . The wall was built , a few inches at a time , between the two walls of a frame , and the lionn was poured
’ na bheò - ghoil a sìos am broinn a ’ bhalla ,
down on this in a hot liquid condition . Then more wall was built and the lionn poured down as before . [lionn - tàth also = semen . Cf . ’ S ma chosg u riu do liun tāth ,
DMcL , 68 . liunn - tàth ,
Fr . Allan , 264 . ]

liopaid .
See liobaid .

an liosd Irteach .
The peculiar St Kilda lisp . [Martin Martin , in his account of a Voyage to St Kilda , mentions this lisp : “ Both sexes have a lisp , but more especially the women , neither of them pronouncing the letters d , g or r . ” — See Miscellanea Scotica , ii , 37 . The St Kilda pronunciation of r as l was well known . See Henderson , ZCP , v , 94 . ]

lite .
See carran .

litheag .
Grilse ( Argyll ) . [Correctly liathag ? ] See samhnachan ; òigh a ’ chuain .

liucadan ( Coll ) ; diucadan ( Barra ) . The flat side of the clam shell . [See leasgadan ,
where it is said to be the concave side . ]

liugha , liùgh .
See iasg baintighearna .

liumban .
A long trailing cord - like seaweed .

liunnaidh .
See liathlus ; lus mór

lòban .
A sack , a bag , a vessel made of straw , bent , rushes , grass roots or tràthach / tràghach .
When the pronn ,
crushed corn or ground grain was put through the sieve , the rough meal falling round the heap upon the skin was lifted and placed in a lòban .
This was called garbhan , min gharbhain ,
rough meal . The rest of the meal was put in another lòban .
This was called mìnleach , min mhìn ,
fine meal . The two kinds were known as lòban garbhain ,
rough lòban , and lòban mìnich ,
fine lòban . The garbhan was used in porridge , the mìneach in bread . [See lòban ,
Dw . ON laupr , basket ; see Henderson , NICS , 119 , 120 . lòban ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . lòban suathaidh ,
OL , 8 ; ’ S do chluasan urad ri lòban ,
id . , 42 . Called seic in Ness , Lewis ; smaller ones called sgeap . ]

lobht .
A loft . lobhtagan .
Terraces on the side of a hill ( Barra ) . [Also any floor of wood , whether upstairs or downstairs , TGSI , xxiv , 369 . lobhta ,
