Fr . Allan . Cf . ’ S nach danns air làr lom / Gun an lobhtaidh fo do bhonn ,
OL , 58 ; No mac rìgh le shìod ’ air lobhtaidh ,
id . , 119 ; fo lobhtaidh ,
‘ below deck ’ , AD , 192 ; danns air lobhtaichean ,
id . , 140 . ON lopt , loft , upper room . ]

loch - bhléin .
Flank of a horse or cow . Also loch - bhlian [loch - blian ,
Ness , Lewis] , loch - léin , do - léin , dubh - léin [dubh - bhléin] , lon - chléibh , lon - chliabh . [Cf . diuch - bhlian ,
the flank = dubh - chléin ( West Ross ) ; liuch - bhlian ( N . Gairloch ) , TGSI , xxiv , 357 ; loch - lèin ,
Leviticus , iii , 4 . dubh - liath , dubh - chléin , sùil liath ,
Fr . Allan . An dubh - liath cuid an amadain , ’ s a ’ sgamhan cuid na h - òinnsich ,
‘ the spleen the fool ’ s part , the lights the silly woman ’ s , ’ NGP , 381 ( cf . staoig an amadain ,
Fr . Allan ; probably , therefore , not the same as loch - bhléin etc . ) . E . Ir . loch blén ( bléine ) , groin ( Hessen ) . ]

lochd .
See lait , laic .

lòchraidh , lòch - chruidh .
Black cattle .

Fàs dha na càirdean ,
Bàs dha na sgagairean , [sgathairean , sgathaidhean
Laoigh dha na lòchraidh ,
Pòsadh dha na caileagan .

Bho na thug thu Muire leat
Is Màiri leat ,
Mo chrodh laoigh air mòintich ,
Mo lòchraidh uile ,
[lòchraidh , lòchruidh i , 210 , 264 ; iv , 156 . E . Ir . lóch , ‘ bright , radiant ’ , also used in the opposite sense of ‘ black ’ ; see O ’ Rahilly , EIHM , 477 - 478 . ]

logaid , loguid . [glogaid ,
North Uist . ] A clumsy person , a frowsy woman , a ghoul , a ghost . ‘ Tha am bodach a ’ tighinn , a mham ’ , ars an t - isean . ‘ Am bheil ann ach logaidean thaighean , a ghaoil ’ , ars a ’ Ghlaistig . Thànaig am bodach agus rug e air an isean agus thog e leis an t - isean air fras - mhullach a ghualainn . ‘ A sheann mhaol liath nam brioganan ( ? ) , feuch a nis an e logaidean seann taighean a bha ann ! ’ ars an t - isean agus e anns an rànaich ’ ga thoir air falbh .
— ‘ The carle is coming , mam , ’ said the youngling . ‘ It is only the ghouls of old houses , dear , ’ said the Glaistig . The carle came and carted away the youngling over his shoulders . ‘ Thou old bare - headed grey - headed of the cantrips , see now if it be the ghouls of old houses , ’ said the youngling roaring as he was being carried off . [loguid ,
a varlet , a rascal ; a soft , cowardly fellow ; a lean , starving cow , HSD ; also a ghost , Dw . Cf . gus an cuireadh mac - talla na h - oiche maoim fo na logaidean , agus crith air an creagan aosda ,
An Gàidheal , v , 50 . ]

logaidh .
See caora .

logaire , cairt - loch .
Water - lily .

logais .
A round foot , broad bauchle , a shapeless sandal , a squat woman , the leaf of the water - lily , the hoof of the foal . The contour of the leaf of the water - lily and that of the hoof of the foal are similar . logais bhròg ,
worn - out shoes . logais bhodaich ,
clumsy carle . logais bhoireannaich ,
clumsy , untidy woman .
The word occurs in a song of Skye with the chorus : Mo roghainn ’ s mo rùn a chunna mi ’ n dé / Gun taghainn dhomh fhéin gun stòras i :

Bha i fodha gu dà chruachainn
’ S i ri buain nan lògaisean . [lògairean

The root of the water - lily is used for dyeing jumpers . Fixed with alum or dubhach it gives a lustrous black . It grows in gnarled clusters , extremely tough and difficult to pluck , and , being in deep water , not infrequently women lose their lives securing it . [logais ,
old leather shoes , v , 254 . There appear to be at least two words here . logais ,
old

shoe , clumsy person etc . , has short - o - , but , judging by the verse quoted , logaisean ( logairean ) ,
water - lily , appears to have long - ò - . ]

lòine .
See clàd .

loinid .
See riamlach .

loireagach .
See tur .

loisid .
Horse , steed ; a proud steed , a prancing steed .

lomadh .
The act of baring or stripping , as lomadh eòrna ,
pounding bere or barley to take off the beard or awn . [See lomadh ,
6 , Dw . ]

lomhain .
Leash , cord tying dogs in leash .

Cù air lomhain ,
Each air thaoda ,
Bó air shùgan ,
Boc air aonach .

lonachan .
The rope round the waist ; to this is attached the lòn [lon ? ] ,
the rope for going down and coming up the precipice . The sùgan is a rope round the waist under which the man places the necks of the birds as he secures them . [Cf . A sheachd beannachd nan càirdean / ’ S a lon làdair na feuma ,
from a St Kilda song , S , 509 . Lon is glossed ‘ a rope of raw hides , used by the St Kildians ’ . Lomhain was also used for this in St Kilda , cf . CR , ii , 333 . The vowel of lon is probably short . The glossary to BGh has lòn ,
a rope of raw hide , from l . 6896 : suas le ’ n lònaibh ( riming with seòladh ) . But this is dat . pl . of lomhainn ,
with syncope and consequent lengthening of the vowel ( i . e . = lòmhnaibh ) . ]

Lorg an Fhir Mhillidh .
See Saothair an Daobh .

lòron .
Bird in the shell . Akin to lobhar ,
leper . [i . e . = lobhran ? stroban ,
the embryo in the egg , Fr . Allan , 267 . ]

losaid .
The wooden tray or vessel in which the potatoes are placed upon the table ( = sgeip , sgeap ) . The losaid is large or small , according to the family . Where wood is not procurable the same losaid is used throughout the generations . [losaid ,
Fr . Allan . E . Ir . lossat , a kneading trough . ]

losgadh na h - aibhne .
See leòs .

losgann .
See leid .

loth .
See isean .

lothan .
See tur .

luacharan , luachran .
A speckled bird which breeds about the strand and has four eggs . [Sandpiper ? ]

lubar , lubarag .
An untidy woman . [Cf . lobar ,
puddle , mud , Dw . ]

luchd coinghill .
See leasacha làmha .

luchd taighe .
See faircill .

ludagach .
See tur .

luibh an tataidh .
See lus an tàlaidh .

luibh bheag , luibh bheannaichte .
See mòthan .

luirgneachan .
The part of the tether nearest the animal . The gearraiste

is the part of the tether nearest the ciopan , cipean ,
fastener , tether - stake . The udalan ,
swivel , divides the two pieces . [cipean ,
overlooked by McB , is perhaps the dimin . of ceap ,
a block , L cippus . gearraiste is perhaps from gearr ,
short , and feist ,
a tether , ON festr , rope , cord , cable . ]

luistireadh , luistreadh , luisteadh , sluistreadh , sluisteadh .
Pulling cloth to and fro through water , in washing . A ’ sluistreadh ’ s a ’ slaistreadh a ’ chlò ,
dragging the cloth to and fro through water . [Also sloisreadh , sloistreadh . sloisir ,
Badenoch sleastair ,
McB takes from Sc . slaister ,
bedaub . Cf . luistreadh ,
v , 274 . ]

Lùnasdal .
See tuil .

lunn .
See lann .

lus a ’ bhainne .
See lòchraidh .

lus a ’ chruidhein .
See gadmann .

lus an tàlaidh ( Glen Elg ) ; lus / luibh an tataidh ( Skye ) . The enticing plant , enchanter ’ s nightshade . Girls were wont to bribe old women to procure them this plant , which was administered to a lover without his knowledge , in order to entice him . When put in water it is said to make the water bubble . [For enchantress ’ s nightshade Cameron gives fuinnseach ; lus na h - òighe .
For lus an tataidh cf . lus taghta ,
fragrant orchis , Cameron , 102 ? ]

lus Chù Chulainn nan càrn .
( Yellow bedstraw ? ) [lus Chù - chulainn ,
meadow sweet , Fr . Allan . ]

lus gort .
See gadmann .

lus mór .
Spearwort . Is good for liunnaidh and blistering . Applied as a plàsd ,
plaster , it is good for greim lòin ,
lumbago or rheumatism ; so is the fliodh Moire ( q . v . ) .

lus na fala ; lus na feàrnaich ; lus nan cnaimhseag ; lus nan cnàmhag ; lus nan cuileag .
See gadmann .

mac gun mhàthair . [Some plant ; the same as mac gun athair , lus gun mhàthair gun athair ,
lesser duckweed ? ] . Boil when full , then strain and mix with fresh butter . This ointment is good for sore eyes .

mac - làmhaich , mac - sglàmhaich .
Sea - devil , fishing - frog or sea - angler , called in Uist clab cìocharain .
It is believed that this creature appears twice a year , in spring and autumn . He is larger than any creature of the deep ; it would take an old man dà thràth ,
two watches , to walk around its stomach . In fact this is a fish which hides its huge clumsy bulk in the mud and sends out fleshy processes at which small fishes come to nibble . The fish then opens its vast mouth and engulfs them , after which it sets up its tackle as before . [Cf . satirical description of this fish , called mac - làthaich there , in MC , 310 - 311 ; Beul mhic - lāmhaich , ’ s fāileadh a bhruic ,
AMD ( 1751 ) , 191 ; ’ S tu bhiosd shiūbhlach ’ s tu mac -

glāimhein ,
DMcL , 247 ; No bhiast mhùgach sin mac lāmhaich ,
TGSI , xxii , 178 . ]

Mac Rìgh Breatann .
See plàsd sàiteas fiadhaich

Mac Sìridh .
A Mull surname , now officially Mackinnon [in Mull , but Maclean in Skye] . Taigh Mhic Sìridh ,
‘ Davy Jones ’ Locker ’ . [Cf . Agus nāmhaid mhic - sìrith ,
AD , 83 , where it is some animal ; the fox ? The name is E . Ir . Síchraidh
ON . Sigrøðr , Bidrag , p . 91 . ]

madadh mine .
‘ Meal mastiff ’ . [Meaning ? ]

madadh - ruadh , mada - ruadh .
Fox . There are innumerable proverbs about the fox . Tha guth a ’ mhadaidh - ruaidh ’ na cheann , na teirig teann air an duine .
The voice of the fox is in his head , do not go near the fellow . Tha còt a ’ mhadaidh - ruaidh air , fan is fuirich uaidhe .
The coat of the fox is upon him , keep away and stay away from him .

madagan .
A raised tableland in a valley , top , ridge , crown ; madagan a ’ mhunaidh ,
the crest of the hill ; Madagan na Mòine ,
the Moor of Rannoch .

magail .
Whim . [Cf . magaid ,
a notion , a fancy . magail in form suggests an adj . Cf . ’ S na d ’ mholadh magoil bá ,
AMD ( 1751 ) , 26 . ]

magairle mór , magairle ( margairle mór etc . ) .
A sea - urchin ( Loch Broom ) ; elsewhere gillir , coinein - mara . [conan - mara ,
Fr . Allan . ]

màglach .
See fìneag . [ màg ,
paw . smàglach ; màglach ,
Fr . Allan , pp . 125 , 223 . ]

maide beul - faraidh .
The partition beam .

maide bolla - lìn .
Fishing - net buoy .

maide - sùirn .
See brat ; cùilig .

maide - sùsd .
Stick laid across a horse ’ s tail serving as a crupper . [maide - séisd ,
the pack - saddle stick ( that passes under the tail ) , MacL ; maide séisd ,
RD , 172 . Cf . maide - tòn - an - eich ,
stick placed under the tail of a horse when rigged in the pack - saddle , Dw . bod - chrann , botrachan ,
crupper , Dw . ]

maighdeag .
See faoideag .

mainnir .
See Samhain .

manadh .
See tàchran . [manadh ,
premonition , Fr . Allan . E . Ir . mana , an omen , portent ; a sign , indication . ]

mann , mannadh .
Prediction , apparition . [Same as preceding ? ]

mànran .
Melody , tuneful humming , pleasant speech .

Mànran o bheul gu beul
Mar ianan o gheug gu geug .
[See s . v . mòn etc . ]

[mànran and bànran ,
soft loving talk , Fr . Allan . mànran ,
AD , 37 , 38 , 55 , 82 , 105 , 112 , 159 , 169 ; Gill . Caimbeul , 69 ; MC , 138 , 141 , 190 , 350 , 368 , 392 ; mànranach ,
AD , 60 , 75 , 126 ; bànran ,
OL , 22 , 85 , 91 . ]

maogh .
See minghe ( ? ) .

maoiseach , mìseach .
Forms of maoilseach ,
roe , doe ; improperly applied to a goat , especially one in milk . Maoiseach ,
a clumsy woman , a soft

woman , not well knit together in mind or body , a clownish woman ; maoiseach bhog bhoireannaich ,
a soft dowdy woman ; maoiseach mhór bhoireannaich ,
a great clumsy woman . [Two or more words are confused here : maoiseach ,
also maoisleach ,
by metathesis from maoilseach ,
roe , doe , ‘ the hornless one ’ ( maol + sech ) ; and mìseach ,
a young she - goat , from minnseach ( menn + sech ) .
Maoiseach ,
a clumsy woman , etc . , may be from maois ,
a large basket or hamper . Cf . ON meiss , wooden box , basket ? ]

maoislinn .
Corn pulp , preparation of unripe corn . See mìslin , infra .

maol .
See caora .

maol - conain .
Mushroom applied as a poultice to sores . [maol - conain ,
Fr . Allan . ]

Maol Domhnaich .
‘ The tonsured one of the Lord ’ , was the name by which a male child not yet baptised was known . Griadach ( q . v . ) was the name by which a female child not yet baptised was known [see i , 115] . When the child was baptised and recognised by the Church this temporary name ceased . For a natural child , however , baptism was not always to be got , in which case the temporary name remained , occasionally for life . When the father of the child failed to provide for it and the mother was poor , the woman got a dole from the Church funds . In this case the luckless child was called Isean Eaglaise ,
‘ Church chick ’ . In Caithness and Sutherland he was called Isean Circ ( Circe ) ,
‘ Kirk chick ’ , and generally received in English the surname Kirk or Kirke . In Skye and Argyll a natural child raised by doles from the Church was called in English ‘ Ludovic ’ . [Ludovick was the general equation in English for the name Maol Domhnaich . In Lewis it has now been reduced to Louis . ]

maor - ceairt .
In the Isles the man who regulated grazing rights .

maor - chearc .
See cearc - fearainn .

maorach Moire .
Shellfish of Mary . This is the Uist name of the pecten , closely akin to the common cockle but smaller , flatter , whiter , and shallower in the ribbing . [maorach Moire ,
Fr . Allan . ]

maosach .
Thin sowens thickened with meal .

mar : naoi naonar mar sheachd ,
nine times nine persons by seven . [This use of mar is overlooked by Dwelly . Cf . Is binne an tathaich sud mar cheud ,
BGh , l . 1273 ; B ’ fhearr leam uam e mar cheud ,
T , 45 . ]

màrag , màrrag = bothan , bothan àirigh ,
a shieling bothy . This is the name in Arran . [Cf . màrrach ,
which represents Ir . mannrach , an enclosure , pen , sheepfold , derived from mainnir ,
one of whose meanings , according to Dwelly , is booth ; see O ’ Rahilly , SGS , i , 35 . ]

maraich . [Scurvy - grass ? ] Is good for taking away water from the eyes . [maraiche ,
Fr . Allan . ]

marbh .
See conn .

Marbhadh na Béiste Duibhe no Togarradh ( Togharradh ) an Dóbhrain Duinn .
‘ The killing of the black beast ( otter ) ’ or ‘ The desire of the water - dog ( otter ) ’ . This was a dance containing much acting and much dancing and much wild otter hunting and probably more . [Elsewhere in the MSS . said to be a play rather than a dance . ]

marbhair .
Carp fish . [= carbhanach ,
Dw . ]

marbhalach .
See marbharnach ; uanallach .

marbharnach .
Wool of killed sheep , as distinct from the wool of the sheep that died from disease . [Cf . marbhalach (
marbh + ollach ; olann ,
wool ) , s . v . uanallach . Cf . clòimh marbhanaich , s . v . marbhanach ,
Fr . Allan . marbhanach ; marbhchann , marchann ,
Dw . Cf . ’ S tabann mìne gheal marachan ,
E , 294 ; ’ S tapan min - gheal marachuinn ,
GB , ii , 21 . ]

marclann .
See Samhain .

màrnaich .
Huge waves . = éiseanach = cùlanach .

Màrt .
The word is rendered March ; but Màrt came twice a year , as Màrt earraich ( or Màrt cur an t - sìl ,
the Màrt of sowing ) , the Màrt of Spring ; and Màrt foghair ( or Màrt buain / buana ,
the Màrt of reaping ) , the Màrt of

Autumn . In the same way Céitean is rendered May ; but there were both Céitean earraich ,
the Céitean of Spring , and Céitean samhraidh ,
the Céitean of Summer . See gàdag . [Cf . Waifs and Strays , iii , 298 - 299 ; v , 124 . ]

Màrt - lacha , lacha Mhàrt .
A duck which comes in March . Ian cruinn cnapach na ’ s mutha na chrannlach , riabhach , agus ceann liath oirre .
A round stocky bird larger than the teal , brindled , with a grey head .

màthair - ghoimh .
See frìd .

màthair - tala , màthair - talam , màthair - talamh .
Earth - mother , a symbolic mother . The old informant said : Nar am bheil e ceart am fodar a thoir dh ’ an bhrùid air mullach creagain eagal gun tig am [sic] màthair - tala agus gun cuir i bho chnàmh a chìr [sic] a ’ bhrùid bhochd . Is còir am fodar a thoir dh ’ an bheothach air a ’ bhlianaig bhig bhòidhich , bonn a ’ chreagain . An sin gabhaidh am màthair - tala eala ris a ’ chreutair bhrònach agus théid i seachad gun chron gun choire dhèanamh dha .
— It is not right to give the fodder to the beast on the summit of the little crag for fear that the ‘ earth - mother ’ may come and put the poor beast off chewing the cud . It is right to give the fodder to the animal on the pretty little green dell at the foot of the little crag . Then the ‘ earth - mother ’ will have naught to do with the poor creature and she will pass by without hurting or harming him .

meacan .
See Conan Corr .

meadar .
See carran ; faircill .

mealan - tràghad .
Sea - lice on salmon newly run . They fasten on salmon in the sea and drive them to the fresh water . [mealan is the pre - tonic form of mìolan . ]

meannan - oidhche .
See crom - riabhach .

mearan , mirean .
Madness .

Tha ’ n Camaranach dubh air a mhealladh ,
Cha mh ’ athair a chuir fuil ’ sa ’ fhrìth , [MS . shrith
Ach buachaille monaidh fo mhearan
A dh ’ eirmis a mhala gu grinn .

The black Cameron is mistaken , it was not my father who drew blood in the hill , but a mountain herd gone berserk who chanced to hit his fine forehead [recte , who skilfully found the mark in his forehead] .

[meirein ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Chuaidh mo shlàinte gu mearan ,
E , 135 ; Mur robh meirein ort air tuineadh ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 284 ; mearan ,
id . , 306 ; mearan ,
MC , 397 . ]

measan , miosan .
See crann - mheasan .

meath .
See mith .

meilcheart .
Grease in the hocks and heels of horses , and sometimes in the feet and ankles of human beings ; it is tenacious and difficult to cure . Hives , rash , irritating heat in the skin , also called a ’ bhreac shìdh . [meilcheart ,
chilblain , Dw , Dieckhoff ; meille - chartan ,
chilblain , itching in

the sole of the foot , Dw ; meileartan ,
flesh - mites , generally under the toes , McA ; míl - cheárd , míl - cheartán ,
flesh - worm , Dinn . ]

meilgeach .
See garbhan .

meillich .
A kind of seaweed .

meirbhein , mirbhin .
See gadmann .

meirgheal = ceann na cas - chrom . [meirgeal ,
part of crann - nan - gad ,
see Dw , p . 263 , no . 20 . ]

mial - mullaich .
Fox , wolf .

mian , mianan , miananaich , mèananaich , meunanaich , mianaich .
See mòn .

miann .
A birth - mark , strawberry mark . The cure for this is to place the first finger of the right hand of a dead person upon the mark ; it will then disappear in a few days . The writer has come across several cases where this cure is said to have been successfully practised .

mille - chù .
Probably the fox , possibly the bear [ ? ] .

milleadh .
Spoiling , destroying ; in the Western Isles commonly connotes drowning . Chaidh a mhilleadh ’ san fhadhail ,
he was drowned in the ford . An aire ! no bithidh sinn air ar milleadh ,
take care ! or we shall be drowned . [mill ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Gad a rinneadh do mhilleadh / Bu tu sgiobair a ’ bhàta ,
OL , 54 . ]

milleadh - maighich .
See gearradh - maighich .

min gharbhain , min mhìn .
See lòban .

mìneach .
See lòban .

mìneag .
A soft gentle girl or woman ; a fay , a fairy woman . Mìnealas na mnà - sìdh , fìnealas na mnà Greug .

miniceir , mionaicir .
See caorrann .

mìnleach .
See lòban .

miola - mhàg , mola - mhàg , mola - mhàgan , muile - mhàg , murra - mhàg , murra - mhàgag .
Frog [or toad] . The last is the form in Loch Carron . See an t - sonasag , an té ruadh .

mìolchu .
Greyhound . Miolachu , Gearrachu agus Madadh nan Seachd Cas is the name of a wild sgialachd ,
tale : Greyhound , Wolfhound and the Mastiff of the Seven Legs .

mionan , mionan min [mìn ? mion ? ] .
See snàthadag . [leg . mionnan
meann ? mionntan , miontan ,
Dw . ]

mionn .
Oath . There were many forms of asseveration among the old Highlanders . A common phrase in conversation is a leòra tha , a leòra chan ’ eil ,
by the Book it is , by the Book it is not , from leabhar ,
book . [See leabhar ,
Fr . Allan . ] A common asseveration in Uist is air a làimh ,
by thine hand . [See làmh ,
supra . ] Swearing by the hand of the chief was a common form of asseveration , as air làimh Mhic Dhomhnaill ,
by the hand of MacDonald ; air làimh Mhic Leòid ,
by the hand of MacLeod ; air làimh Mhic Cailein ,
by the hand of Mac Cailein ( Duke of Argyll ) . The most sacred oath was called corrachd ,
the death oath . [See corrachd ,

ii , 257 . In Lewis corachd . corachd ,
death - entreaty , Henderson , DIG , i , Introd . xiv . ] Oaths on the Bible were often taken [cf . a leòra] ;

Bheir mi mionnan air a ’ Bhìobull
Gur i ’ n fhìrinn atà ’ nam bheul ,
Nach téid mi sìos ann an leabhar sgìre
Le té gu dìlinn ach thu fhéin .

am mìosachan . [Purging - flax . ] Is used as vomaitear agus purgaid ,
emetic and purgative . As much as fills the fork between thumb and forefinger is pulled and then dried ; it is pulled in the iuchair shamhraidh ,
summer dog - days . So said John Beaton .

mìr .
A bit , a bite , a piece , a piece of bread and butter ; often applied to bits of food given to children . mìr madainn ,
morning bite ; mìr mochaire [i . e . mocheirigh] ,
early bite .

mìr .
A heap of corn . mìreadh .
The act of heaping up corn in a barn , also called càrnadh . [mìr ,
mow , built - up pile of hay , corn , straw , peats etc ; section of a mow , Dw . mìr mòna ,
a sub - division of a peat - stack , McA . ]

mìslin , maoislin , maoislinn .
Unripe grain , corn pulp , grain still in a milky state , a preparation of unripe corn . Maoislin is sweet and palatable to the taste , if wasteful of corn . [= mìlsean
milis ? ]

mith .
To decay , to rot , to go to naught . [mioth ,
Fr . Allan . A form of meath .
E . Ir . meth , decay , blight , wasting , failure . ]

modagan . Bho mullach mhodagan mo chinn gu ìochdar odagan mo bhonn . [modagan , cf . madagan ,
supra . odagan
ordagan ? ]

mogan , mogais .
A footless stocking . The district of Duirinish in Skye is known [to the inhabitants of Trotternish] as Dùthaich nam Mogan , Clàr nam Mogan and Clàr Moganach ,
‘ the country or land of the footless stockings ’ . This is MacLeod country , and Trotternish MacDonald country . These two powerful clans being sometimes at feud , sometimes at war with one another , they bestowed belittling names on each other ’ s homelands . See grainnseach . [mogaisean ,
home - made gloves , Fr . Allan . ]

mogan [MS . mògan ,
but the vowel is short] . Spirits distilled from oats . [Cf . Bi na bodaich ri mogan , / ’ S cha bhi sogan ’ ga dheanamh ,
UB , 184 , where it is said to be the name for home - distilled spirits . See JMC , 210 . ]

moighe .
See minghe ( ? ) .

mòine bheannach .
Peat worked and shaped , for drying .

Moire .
See biolair , cnò , cuilidh , fliodh , maorach .

mola - mhàg .
See miola - mhàg .

mòn , mònan , mònanaich .
The same as mian , mianan , miananaich , mèananaich , meunanaich , mianaich .
A yawn , a little yawn , yawning . [Cf . iv , 160 . ]

The proverb regarding yawning takes different forms in different districts . In Uist , where there are no trees , it is : Miananaich o bhial gu bial mar iananaich o shliabh gu sliabh ,
yawning from mouth to mouth like birds flying ( ? ) from hill to hill . In Morar , where trees are abundant , they say : Meunanaich bho thé gu té mar eunanaich bho gheug gu geug ,
yawning from woman to woman like birds flying ( ? ) from branch to branch . Another form is : Miananaich bho neach gu neach mar ian bho phreas gu preas ,
yawning from one person to another like a bird from bush to bush . [Cf . Holmer , Studies on Argyllshire Gaelic , p . 190 : théid am mèananaich o dhuine gu duine mar a théid an t - eun o dhuilleag gu duilleag .
For Irish versions see Éigse , i , 307 - 8 ; ii , 149 : fé mar ritheann an mhéanfadhach ó dhuine gu duine ; tá tú dham thóirt ó bhile go bile mar théigheanns an méanfadhach ó dhuine go duine ; téidheann an méanfach ó dhuine go duine mar théid an t - éan ó bhile go bile . ] See mànran .

[miaran , miaranaich ,
Fr . Allan . mianan ,
NGP , 311 , where two versions of the proverb are given . E . Ir . mén , a mouth ; an opening in a coast , a gulf ; ménfadach , f . , the act of yawning . ]

monabar = brunndail ,
muttering , gossiping , scandal - talking . [monmhar , monmhur , monaghar , monaghair , munmhor , munmhur ,
Dw . monothur ,
Fr . Allan , 264 . E . Ir . monmar ( monbar ) , murmuring , complaining , grumbling . Some of Dwelly ’ s forms represent E . Ir . mongar , a loud continuous noise , din , boom , roaring , and so does Fr Allan ’ s form which means ‘ loud rumbling report ’ . ]

monadh .
See tonn .

mong , mung .
Hair , mane . mung mnà ,
woman ’ s hair ; mung eich ,
horse ’ s mane . mongach , mungach , muinneach .
With plentiful hair or mane . muinne , muinneach .
A woman with plentiful hair . mongag , mungag , muinneag , muinigeag .
A girl or woman with plentiful hair .

Bean bheag mhongach is fear mór maol
A sìos ’ s a nìos an Rongan is macan mear r ’ an taobh .

mòrlanachd .
See bòrlanachd .

morthach , maorach . [mormhach ,
sea - plain , low country by the sea . ] Land now and then covered by the tide : in Argyll , land now and then overflowed by sea , lake or river . Land sometimes covered by the tide is considered healthy grazing , and animals fed on it are sweet in flesh . The word also means the sandy shore of a lake ; the sandy ground of an arm of the sea which becomes dry at ebb ; a sandy ford on a river . Loch na Morthach is a sandy - shored loch in North Uist . [Cf . A ’ Mhormhoich .
On the forms murmag and murbach see Watson , SGS , iii , 208 . ]

mot , mod . mod e = suath e ,
a term applied in making porridge to stirring the pot . Perhaps from maid ( e ) ,
stick .

mothal .
The fish and seed of various corns given to cattle . [mothal ,
refuse , particularly of fish ; mothal iasg ,
Dw . ]

mòthan . [Pearlwort . ] Wives have the mòthan to guard the milk . [See ii , 110 - 114 , 329 ; iv , 78 , 132 - 134 . ] Described as luibh bheag bheag , luibh bheannaichte ,
a small small plant , a blessed plant . ‘ Chan urra dhomh an t - saighead a thilgeil air agus bainne beannaichte na bó bàth a dh ’ ith am mòthan gràidh ’ na bhroinn ’ . Is e seo thubhairt an dara bean - shìdh ris a ’ bhean - shìdh eile mu dheighinn a ’ ghille a dhiùlt a pòsadh agus an gille ’ na shuain chadail taobh an tolmain ghuirm .
‘ I cannot cast the arrow at him when the blessed milk of the innocent cow that ate the beloved mòthan is in his belly ’ . This is what the one fairy woman said to the other fairy woman about the youth who refused to marry her , the youth being asleep on the green knoll ’ s side . See laomachan .

mousgaid , mousgaideach , mousgaidean . Duine mousgaideach ,
a stupid man , forgetful man , negligent man . [mobhsgaid ,
Fr . Allan . The pronunciation could point , perhaps , to an original mollsgaid .
In Nat . Lib . Gaelic MS . 63 Alexander MacDonald spells the word mousgaid and rimes it with Loudon ; SGS , iv , 185 . ]
muca buailte ( Harris ) . Whales driven ashore and stranded .

muc - bearraidh [muc - bhearraidh ? ] .
Round - headed porpoise . [Cf . muc - bhiorach ,
Dw . ]

muc - fheòir .
A very large hay - rick . [Cf . muc - ghaineamh , muc - shneachda . ]

mucan siùil .
Whales with sail - like fins , of which the writer saw a school of several hundreds going out south - west of Seilley , North Uist , 12th August 1902 .

mug , muga , mugaid , mungaid , mugaind .
See lann .

mùchadh larrais .
Concealing a thing , passing no remark . [labhrais ? ]

muicnis .
See iris . [The rope which ties a basket on a porter ’ s back , Dw . ]

muile - mhàg .
See miola - mhàg .

muinne , muinneach , muinneag , muinigeag .
See mong .

muir - tiachd .
Jellyfish . [tiachd = E . Ir . técht , congealed , frozen ; Muir Técht , the Arctic Ocean ( ? ) ]

muirsgean .
See cladach ; leasgadan .

mulchag - bheirteachaidh .
Every woman took a mulchag - bheirteachaidh to the weaver when she took the yarn . The weaver got paid only for his weaving , while he lost a day in the beirteachadh ( placing the yarn in the loom ) . The mulchag might be a cheese , a plate of butter , a ceathramh muiltfheoil ( leg of mutton ) , or a peic mhine ( peck of meal ) , and this was supposed to pay the beirteachadh .
See cùileag ; sgaid . [bonntais in Lewis . ]

mung .
See mong .

muracaire .
Anything cast on the shore ( Barra ) . murrag ( see below ) , Uist . [murracaire ,
Fr . Allan . mur - thurchairthe ; turchairthe ,
valuables cast up by the sea , wrack , flotsam and jetsam . ]

murghan .
Sulks , anger .

murrag .
Sea - marks on the shore . [Properly the same as muracaire above . Cf . ’ S ann aca bha na murragan ( ’ nuair a bhiodh tòrr de rud math aig daoine ) ,
Ness , Lewis ; No ’ g iarraidh na muraig / Ri tuinne na cròic ,
MC , 368 ; murrag maidne , murrag mara ,
v , 278 . ]

murra - mhàg .
See miola - mhàg .

mùtag .
A knapsack ; a case or cover ; a small bag ; any small place for carrying things . [mùdag ,
a wickerwork little creel all closed in , but one little opening on side to admit the hand , used for keeping teased wool , Fr . Allan . mùdag ,
an egg - shaped wicker receptacle for holding teased wool , TGSI , xxiv , 360 . Cf . mùdan ,
covering . Eagal drùchd bha mùdan craicinn / Cumail fasgaidh air mo chéile ,
DB , ll . 2188 / 9 ; mùtan de thrusdar casaig ,
BGh , l . 3033 . ]

muthail , maoil .
To die ; death .

nàmhag .
A canoe , coracle , small boat . [naomhóg , a small boat , a canoe , Dinn ; E . Ir . nó , nau , etc . , a small boat . ]

naosg .
See gudaboc .

nasg .
A wooden tie round a cow ’ s neck in the stall . If the tie be not of wood it is called ceangal ,
tie . nasg is also used for a frame , framework , as : nasg criathair ,
frame of a sieve ; nasg taighe ,
frame of a house ; nasg cléibhe ,
frame of a creel ; nasg bàta ,
frame of a boat , also called crannghail ; nasg guite ,
frame of a corn - fan .

neanntag , feanntag , deanntag .
Nettle . For medicine , nettles are taken three times [daily] first , and gradually less often . [feanntag ,
Fr . Allan . Other forms are eanntag , ionntag ,
CR , ii , 36 . E . Ir . nenaid , a nettle ; early Mod . Ir . nentóg . ]

niarachd .
See balc ; corra - chrosgag . [niarachd ,
lucky , happy , Fr . Allan . Cf . ’ S i mo nearac a gheabh thu ,
G , 12 ; Gur niarachd tè da ’ n gair ’ ir è ,
E , 98 ; ’ S niarachd fer bheir geill dhiat ,
id . , 267 ; Gur niarrachd air ’ n do chasadh thu ,
AD , 66 ; ’ S niarachd drèam do ’ m beil mar cheannard ,
Duanaire , 158 ; ’ S niarachd té o ’ n chléir gheibh còir ort ,
id . , 167 ; Bu niarachd cinneadh dha ’ n ainmichear thu ,
MC , 95 ; Is niarachd fear gheibh ort cōir ,
BTh , 286 ; Is niarachd do ’ n gealladh tu ’ chroich ,
NGP , 282 . ]

nighean Imhir ( Ìomhair ) .
The serpent . [i , 169 ; ii , 334 ; nimhir ,
i , 169 ; ii , 326 , 334 . ] ‘ I always hear nighean Niamhair or nighean Iamhair ,
never nighean Nimhir or Imhir .
We may be prejudiced in favour of the form Nimhir as we connect the whole thing with the serpent and we connect the serpent with neimh ,
venom ’ . ( From a letter from Father Allan MacDonald , dated Dalibrog , 21st December 1898 . ) [nighean Iamhair ,
Fr . Allan . nighean Ìomhair ,
Ness , Lewis . ]

niosgag .
A term used in Cóigeach , Ross , for a cow . [Sometimes used as a proper name for a cow . neasgag
nasgag :
nasg ( q . v . ) ? ]

noigean .
See coidhean .

norra .
See lait .

nostaidh [ - ò - ? ] . Puerile , imbecile ; a foolish person , a man or woman given to quarrelling . [Cf . nòisteanach ,
fastidious , stand - offish , TGSI , xxxvii , 41 ? ]

nuadal .
Gossip . nuadalaich .
Gossiping .

obair - là .
Bar from which hangs the pot - chain .

odagan .
See modagan .

odhar .
See cnò .

ódhrag .
‘ Little dun one ’ , the young of the sgarbh mór or sgarbh buill ,
cormorant . [odhrag ,
Fr . Allan . ]

Odhran .
See cnò .

oglaidh .
Giddy , light - headed ; passionate ; easily upset , easily angered .

[oglaidh ,
of changeable moods , of uneven temper , Fr . Allan . ogluidheachd ( from Birlinn Chlann Raghnaill ) , ‘ gloom , awe - inspiring aspect ’ , Sàr Orain , p . 100 . E . Ir . ocla , readily incensed , irritable , imperious ? ]

Oidhche Fhéill Sheathain .
See cliar .

òigh a ’ chuain .
The female grilse , which is said to be the most beautiful fish in the sea — iasg as bòidhche ’ s a ’ mhuir ,
and is hence called ‘ the virgin of the sea ’ .

Dar ’ s e ’ n ròn as tòir ’ san ruaig
Cha dùth do dh ’ òigh a ’ chuain dhol as .

[See ii , 299 , s . v . gearr . ] A point of connection between the grilse and the hare is that the latter is said to come back for the night to the place where she was born , as the salmon returns in season to the place where it was spawned . See bànag ; litheag ; samhnachan .

oiteag sluaigh .
Eddy wind [wind of the ( ? fairy ) host] .

oitir .
See cladach .

ola dhòrn ( dhùrn ) mhart .
Neat ’ s foot oil . This was specially prized by the old people as a specific for many diseases . It was supposed that the constant friction to which the knees and knuckles of the animal are subjected in his moving about , lying down and getting up , refined the oil and rendered it more efficacious . For a like reason the skin of the knees and knuckles was much in demand for cuarain agus mogais ,
sandals and mocassins , for the friction caused to the skin of these joints made it tough and durable . See bualan boireann . [Ola dhòrn mart was made in Lewis by boiling cows ’ feet for a long time until the oil could be taken off the top with a saucer . It was good for sore throat , applied internally or externally . ola dhùrn mhart ,
iv , 250 . ]

òlach , fòlach .
Noble , of noble birth ; gentle , of gentle birth .

ollabhòlais ( t ) .
Bauble .

òmar .
Amber . Amber was common among the people . It was kept in households for removing motes from the eye and for other purposes the nature of which is not now known to the people . The writer has seen many strings of amber beads which had been handed down from remote ancestors .

Gur math a thig fleasg òmair
Mad ’ mhuineal bòidheach glégheal ;
’ S e gaol do phòg a rinn mo leòn
’ S a dh ’ fhàg mi breòit ’ gun spéirid .

[E . Ir . omra , later ómra . For fleasg ,
cf . pleasg ,
necklace , Applecross . ]

omhan .
Whisked whey . It is palatable and satisfying , but delusive and unsubstantial . A Kintail man said :

Braidean ! braidean ! braidean !
Braidean breugach easan !
Bheireadh breugan / braidean mi dh ’ an bheinn
’ S cha toireadh breugan / braidean dhachaigh mi .
[E . Ir . úan , foam , froth . See Oon , Martin Martin , 242 . ]

onaghail .
See coineibh .

òrais [better òrrais] . Squeamishness . Tha thu cur òrais orm ,
thou art making me squeamish . [In North Uist òrrais ,
with initial vowel nasalised . Ir . orghnás ( also ornás , orráis , oirnéis ) , nausea , disgust , squeamishness , Dinn . orrais ( leg . òrrais ) ; also òraisg ,
v . n . , vomit ( Arran ) , Dw . ]

òrais .
Moving , fumbling , fumbling noise . [Cf . òrais ,
tumultuous noise , Dw . ]

orrach .
See urracag .
òrthan = òra [a hymn , petition] . See deiseal .

ostal .
See crì .

òthan .
A green elevation in wet ground . [Cf . othan ,
f . , a word of obscure meaning , found in poetic and cryptic language , perh . stone ( ? clay , soil ) or burial - chamber , grave ? RIA . Contrr . ]

Pàdraig .
See copag ; cuach ; fear na Féill Pàraig .

paiteach .
A generic name for a young animal . [pait ,
young of any animal , Dw . ]

pàl .
A poor lean codfish . Cha snòdaich [snòtaich ,
Ness , Lewis] am pàl fhéin e ,
the thing is so poor and worthless that the pàl itself will not deign to sniff it . [pàl ,
old fish or one in poor condition ; pàl truisg ,
a poor cod , Dw . ]

pala , palla .
A shelf in a cliff ; a plot in a cliff to which the snìomh ( q . v . )
leads — much the same as uiridh ( q . v . ) . [ON pallr , m . ( 1 ) step ; ( 2 ) the raised floor along the sides of the hall ; ( 3 ) a cross dais at the upper end of the hall . ]

palt , plàt .
A bag made of bent , rushes or of long grass . [plàda ,
Fr . Allan . plàt ,
a corn bag made of plaits of straw , TGSI , xxiii , 87 . plàtach ,
a mat of plaited straw for putting on a horse ’ s back under the crook saddle , TGSI , xxiv , 260 .

Bu tu ’ n t - àilleagan fo ’ n phlàta / N uair a chàirt an t - srathar ort ,
LG , 81 ; Is ann an sin a thathas ’ g a chaitheamh , eadar an t - srathair ’ s am plàta ,
NGP , 214 ; Bha do phlàt ’ air a calcadh gu teann ,
MC , 319 ; Cha ’ n fhaic muil[l]eir mo phlàta ,
id . , 358 . ]

pasgart .
Corn holder made of thick straw rope . [pasgart ,
basket , pannier , Dw . ]

péarsaid , péarsaidean .
Bots , worm in skin of kine . [feursan ,
warble fly , Fr . Allan . Mo leathar cha ’ n eil feum ann , / Air tolladh leis na feursnaibh ,
T , 373 ; Capull salach an fheursaidh ,
RD , 114 ; Is ghabh na h - eich am feursaidh ,
id . , 391 . ]

peata ruadh .
See langaidh .

peidir , peidireach ,
pl . peidirich .
Stormy petrel . [peadaireach ; pàraidh ( Lewis ) , Dw . Various other names , AF , 319 . ]

peinnteal .
See beinnteal .

pill . O phill gu pill ,
from covert to covert . [ peall . ]

piliostar [pealastair ,
North Uist] . See bilisteir .

piocach .
Measles . [Usually a ’ ghriuthach , a ’ ghriùrach . ]

piocach .
Saith . See céitean .

piocach .
A small ill - fed boy , ill - grown man ; dwarf ( Sutherland ) . [ piocach ,
saith ? ]

piollag .
See tapag .

placaid .
Flask . [Cf . placaid ,
wooden dish ; close timber vessel ; fat broad good - natured female ; plaichead ,
flagon , Dw ; McB derives , through Sc . ( ? ) , Fr . plaquette , plaque , a plate . ]
pladaidh = plod , plodach ( q . v . ) , a burial lair .

plàsd .
See lus mór ; plod .

plàsd sàiteas fiadhaich , plàsd a ’ chinn .
A plaster of wild sage , good for sore head ; [the plaster or the herb is also called Mac Rìgh Breatann ( q . v . ) ] .

plàt ( a ) .
See càthadh ; palt .

plath , plathadh .
Stench , as of putrid fish or fish - offal . [ plath ,
puff of wind . ]

pleasg = fleasg ,
a garland , wreath . [Cf . fleasg òmair ,
s . v . òmar . pleasg ,
a necklace , Applecross . ]

pleibir , gille pleibir .
A useless fellow . [gille - plibir ,
a flunkey , North Uist . ]

pliucantach , pliucaich , pliucraich .
Smuggling . [Also called cùl - mhùtaireachd . ]

pliut .
Paw , splay foot , seal ’ s flipper ; adj . pliutach .

A bhusain ronnaich , [bhusaire IL
Fhir nam pliutchasa croma ,
Tha na cuspan air lomadh
Gu bonnaibh do shàil . [Cf . IL , 42 . ]

pliutan .
A young male seal . pliutach .
A grown male seal . pliutag .
A young female seal , applied in derision to a woman lacking neatness of hands or feet , a clumsy woman . [Cf . Na biastan adharcach , iongach , / Pliutach , lorcach ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 396 . spliut ,
a large foot , Applecross . ]

ploc .
A grave ( Mull ) = lioc ( Uist ) , q . v .

ploc buntàta .
See simid .

plod .
A lair , a burying - place . plodach , pladaidh .
Burying - ground , a lair in a churchyard . [pladaidh occurs in an elegy to] the Rev . Neil Macpherson , Inveraray :

Aig ìochdar Dhùn Chuaich , mu bhruaich na pladaidh ,
Na bha talmhaidh dhe ’ n laoch , fuidheall aois na bh ’ againn ;
An Cill - a - Mhàillidh nan crann , ìochdar gleann Mhic Cailein ,
’ S gach aonan ag ràdh : gu bràth cha tig coimeas . [pobull

pobal .
Butter burr . [pubal beannach ,
Fr . Allan . See puball - beannach ,
DB , l . 5990 n . ]

poinneag , puinneag [puinteag ,
North Uist] . See sealbhag . [puinneag ,
Fr . Allan . ]

polca sùl .
‘ Eye - polka ’ , was a dance once known in Kintail . It was danced there by a woman called Caitir , who when dancing it would claw and scratch the faces of those within reach , saying : ‘ Nì bheil lagh no binn ann am polca sùl ’ ,
‘ There is neither law nor sentence in an eye - polka ’ .

pollag .
See ealachadh .

pollag .
Riches , as : pollag airgid ,
p . of silver ; pollag òir ,
p . of gold ; pollag ime ,
p . of butter ; pollag mhine ,
p . of meal ; pollag chàise ,
p . of cheese . Nach ann air a thuit a ’ phollag ,
is it not upon him that fell the p . !

pollair [pollaire ,
i , 527] . The small bag suspended from the neck and resting on the breast in which the Celtic missionaries carried the manuscripts of the Gospel . Angus Gunn , Ness , Lewis , said that the people of Ness had been a wild wicked people , the men quarrelling about

anything and the women quarrelling about nothing , so that the good St Ronan could not say his prayers in peace because of their clamour . He prayed to be removed , he cared not where , if so be that he were away from the wild people of Ness . While he was still praying a messenger came to tell him that a fish was waiting at the laimrig ,
landing place , to carry him away . The good Ronan hurried down , taking with him nothing but his pollair ,
manuscript - bag , and there , sure enough , was the fish at the laimrig ;
and such a fish ! The fish , with the good Ronan sitting on its back , swished over the sea and in no time reached Rona . Angus Gunn described the scene as graphically as if he had been an eye - witness of the whole .

[Cf . E . Ir . polaire , generally translated ‘ writing - tablet ( s ) ’ , (
L pugillare ) , but it may have come to mean ‘ book - satchel ’ ; see RIA Contrr . ]

pollan .
Repetition , anything often repeated . Bhiodh am pollan ’ na bheul ,
the repetition would be in his mouth ; bhiodh an aon phollan am beul an duine dhona ,
the same repetition would be in the mouth of the ill man .

potag .
Oatmeal dough . potag bhùirn / uisge ,
dough of meal and water ; potag uisge - bheatha ,
dough of oatmeal and whisky . The potag was portable and sustaining and was much used in travelling . Trotternish in Skye is known as Grainnseach nan Domhnallach ,
the grange of the MacDonalds ; Sgiobal Chlann Domhnaill ,
the granary of the Clan Donald . The people themselves were known as potagan Chille Mhoire ,
the ‘ doughs ’ of Kilmuir , as well as stapagan Chille Mhoire ,
the ‘ stappacks ’ of Kilmuir , and na stapagaich ,
the people of the meal and water . Their land was Dùthaich nan Stapag ,
the country of the ‘ stappacks ’ . See grainnseach .

prac .
A tax , teind ; a rent in kind , as cows , sheep , horses , grain , meal , cheese , butter and poultry ; prac a ’ mhinisteir ,
the tithes of the minister ; prac na h - eaglais ,
the tithes of the Church . A factor in Lewis was dismissed because of his oppressions . His successor was a man of bad repute and this led John Morrison of Bragar to say :

Chuireadh Dùghall bho ’ n a ’ phraca [phrac
Mar nach glacadh e bho neach i riamh , [dèanadh e olc
Agus mas e Mac Amhlaidh as cearta [ ’ s ceart
Chì gach neach sin le ghniamh . [le / ’ na
Dugall was dismissed from the tithes as if he never had exacted tithes before ( had done ill ) , but if MacAulay is more just the world shall see that by his actions .

John Morrison , Bragar , was a descendant of the famous Britheamh Leódhasach ,
the judge , ‘ brieve ’ , of Lewis , and was a man of much acuteness of mind and terse expression of language . [Cf . Chionn ’ s gu maitheadh tu ’ m bliadhna dhomh ’ m prac ,
RD , 95 . Pracadair ,
‘ tithe - collector ’ , RD , 435 , 447 . ]

L praesepe , manger , C . M . Robertson , SGS , i , 103 . frasach ,
Fr . Allan . Chuir thu an cruineachd geal na fhrasaich ,
OL , 89 . ]

prat .
See cearc - fearainn .

preaslann .
Hedge .

preis .
Hysteria , hysteric fits . [Cf . breislich ? ]

preis .
Pot , cooking pot . [So North Uist ; Lewis prais . ]

procadair .
Interpreter . [procadair ,
advocate , procurator , man of business , Dw . There is also pracadair ,
collector of the prac ;
see s . v . prac . ]

proillean .
See broillean .

proitseach .
See broitseach .

pronn .
See lòban .

propaig .
See bonnach gropaidh .

propaireachd .
To invade the desert ( toir a mach an fhàsaich ) . [Meaning ? A game ? Cf . propataireachd ,
Dw ? ]

pudhar . [hurt , harm . pùdhar ,
Gloss . to S ; pùr ( North Uist ) . ’ S e siod nach cuir am pùr orm ,
that will not hurt me ( trad . port - a - beul ) . ]

puicean .
See buigean .

puinneag .
See poinneag .

pùnan [leg . punnan ( n ) , bunnan ( n ) ? ] , bùirean , bùran .
Bittern . [Ir . bonnán , bunnán . ]

purgaid .
See mìosachan .

purrag = talamh - toll ,
earth - hole . [Misreading of surrag , turrag ? ]

puthag .
See buthag .

puthail ( t ) ; buthail ( t ) .
Recess in the wall of a dwelling ; in England a well cupboard . [ E well . puthaid ,
Dw . buthailtean ,
RD , 95 , 259 . ]

rac .
The ring round the mast of a boat , fixed to the slat - shiùil ,
yard , keeping the sail to the mast while the sail is being raised or lowered . See biast - mhaol . [ ON rakki , parrel , the ‘ traveller ’ . ]

rac - an - fheòir .
See treòn .

rachd .
Intense desire ; rachd armaid [cf . rachd fharmaid ,
ii , 68 ; iv , 190] , the intense desire of the heart . [rachd ,
Fr . Allan . For reachd ;
cf . E . Ir . recht , a paroxysm , outburst ( of anger , passion , etc . ) . Cf . Le làn reachd agus àrdan ,
RD , 125 ; làn reachd agus bròin ,
id . , 279 . ]

Ràghall agus Cairistìne .
‘ Ranald and Christina ’ , name of a dance . Other dances were : Buailim anns a ’ cheann thu ,
‘ I strike thee in the head ’ ; Goileam Gòraig ,
‘ the gyrations [chattering ? ] of the silly female ’ . [For Ràghall agus Cairistìne see MB , 52 b ; OT , 57 - 61 . ]

raidhne , roidhne , roinne .
Cow , fat cow , farrow cow , cow that calved once but , becoming over - fat , could not calve again .

Thig teas dàir air roidhne
Trì tràthaidh diag ’ s a ’ bhliadhna ,
Ris a chuile làn soluis ,
Ris a chuile làn gealaich . [riaraich

Fara - dhàir roidhne air bralain ,
rud gun bhrabh gun bhuaidh . [gun stàth deleted
The semi - copulation of roidhne with bralain ( q . v . ) , a thing without gain , without fruit . [ ‘ use ’ deleted

[Cf . raoine ,
Gloss . to JMC ; reidhneach ( rimes with oighre ) , RD , 342 , 450 . ]

raothan .
Rushes , reeds .

ràs .
Trail , fish trail . [ràs ,
trail of person in wet grass , or a trail of straws of person carrying corn ; John Maclean , Raasay . Cf . sràbh . stràbh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

ràsan .
Trailing mark . ràsan a ’ bhradain ,
the ripple raised by a salmon moving near the surface .

ràsan .
A constant noise , more or less rasping , as ràsan uillt ,
the murmur of a stream ; ràsan ,
brooklet , purling stream ; ràsan teallaich ,
chronic fireside wrangling ; cha toir mi gu bràth dhut ràsan teallaich ,
Donnchadh Bàn . [The word , however , in Donnchadh Bàn ’ s Oran do Chéile is dranndan teallaich .
Cf . Gus an tilleadh tu ’ n ràsan nan sròin ,
DMcL , 168 ; Gus do chasg ’ nuair dh ’ éireas tu ’ s ràs ort ,
‘ fury ’ , DIG , i , 109 ; Chasg a rāis riut s a chaoich ,
id . , 189 ; ’ S bithidh mnathan ri ràsan cumant ,
Kenneth MacKenzie , 120 . ]

ràth .
A burying - ground ( Lewis ) . [Also rath - thìodhlaic in Lewis ; rath - thìodhlaicidh ,
Applecross . In Lewis this means rather a burying lair . ]

rathadach , rathaideil .
Cunning , wise , enterprising .

rathum .
Green - herbs .

reachd .
See rachd .

riadach , ritheadach .
See àn .

riamlach .
The head of the loinid ,
churn - plunger , with the hairs sticking out from the rope . [Cf . driamlach .
E . Ir . riamnach , rúaimnech , a long hair ( esp . horse - hair ) ; a fishing - line . ]

rian .
Mode , method , order , system , regularity , patience . The difference between rian and ciall is shown in : Is e rian a thogas teine , ach is e ciall a chuireas as e ,
it is patience that kindles a fire but it is sense that puts it out . [Cf . eich gun rian ,
s . v . gannadach . as a rian ,
out of his mind , demented . ]

riap .
Rope . [Cf . ON reip , rope ? ]

riasladh .
See alladh .

riaslais , riaslaisg , riaslaig .
A woman who is always in disorder , always in difficulties , because of her untidy habits and unmethodical ways ; an unkempt unwashed slovenly woman . A riaslaig thruagh , mo luaidh do leannan . [See grianuisg . ]

riollagan .
Rags . See corra - chrosgag .

riollag , riollaig , riollaisg , rioll .
Star .

Rìoghainn nan reul / rioll ,
Éiteag na h - oidhche !
[E . Ir . rétglu , Mid . Ir . rétlu , rétla , a star . ]

rionnag . rionnag an rìgh ,
star of the king ; rionnag na maidne ,
star of the morning ; rionnag an iasgair ,
star of the fisherman ; rionnag a ’ bhuachaille ,
star of the shepherd . [E . Ir . rind , a constellation , star . ]

riostalach .
Lank .

rocan .
A link in clòth ,
tweed or cloth , caused by careless waulking . [From roc ,
wrinkle ; ON hrukka , wrinkle ; cf . TGSI , xxiii , 87 . roc ,
a wrinkle , Fr . Allan . ]

ròcas .
Rook [also crow] . Late in autumn rooks , from no one knows where , congregate in large flocks and spread over the fields from which the crops have been removed . Among them are old , diseased and disabled birds which are unable to follow their comrades . These are called ròcais aosda , ròcais ruideach ( luideach ? ) , ròcais leibideach , na leibidein ,
aged rooks , ragged or straggling ( ? ) rooks , contemptible rooks , the contemptibles . Boys follow them , sometimes seizing them with the hand , sometimes killing them with a sling or with a potato thrown from the point of a wand . The accuracy of aim which some of these boys attain with sling and sapling , at various distances , is marvellous .

ròg , rògair , rògaire .
A rogue , knave , rascal . A crofter in Lewis thus scolded his neighbour ’ s herd for allowing his charge to trespass : A rògaire , a mhic an rògaire , ogh an rògaire , iarogha an rògaire , ion - ogha an rògaire , dubh - ogha an rògaire , agus mur bitheadh tu ’ nad rògaire cha bhitheadh tu aig an rògaire ,
thou rogue , thou son of the rogue , grandson of the rogue , great - grandson of the rogue , great - great - grandson of the rogue , great - great - great - grandson of the rogue , and wert thou not a rogue , thou wert not the rogue ’ s man !

ròidheachd .
A waif - tale , a story without any authority or explanation ; bombast ; = sgeul fuadain ; sgeul ròidheach ,
a senseless story . [In Lochalsh the form is raidh , a ’ raidh ( v . n . ) . ]

roidhne , roinne .
See raidhne .

roileis .
Unstable person . [rolasg ,
hasty work , confused joy , Fr . Allan . rolais , roithleas , roithleis ,
slip - shod of working ; roileasg ,
confused joy or person , confused haste ; rolaiseach , roileiseach ,
slip - shod , remiss , Dw ; roileis ,
boisterousness ; roileiseach ,
slap - dash , Applecross . Cf . troilis , infra ? ]

roillean .
See coinneal .

ròiseal .
Living in luxury , or excess in food , etc . [This is a difficult word , or words , mainly confined to poetry . The following meanings may be tentatively allotted :

( 1 ) a band , especially a band of picked men . Cf . Mu Chreach Ghnòideirt neart na ’ n roisheòl , / Gaisgich chròdha nach tais ’ n àm còmhraig ,
E , 99 ; Struaidh gun roisal da chinnidh ga chòir ,
id . , 283 ; Siol Leod na roisail iuimmeach ,
id . , 351 ; Chuir thu ceo fui ’ n ròiseal bhradaich ( thieving gang ) , G , 77 ; Do ròiseal nan sluagh ’ s nam bratach ,
AD , 109 ; Sàr bhuachail ’ nan ròiseal ,
MC , 122 ; Bho ’ n dh ’ fhalbh Clann Domhnaill / Nam brat ’ s nan ròiseol ,
JMC , l . 2024 ; Tigh Eachunnach nan ròiseal ,
TGSI , vii , 120 ; ’ N àm do

( 2 ) topsail ? banner ? Cf . Seal mun togta orra roseal o thir ,
G , 269 ; Leis an eireadh am mór - shluagh , le ’ n roisealaibh ard ,
AD , 124 ; Nuair a nochdagh libh Roiseal o Thir ,
Maclagan MS . 185 . Other exx . may be : MC , 178 ; T , 303 ; Clàrsach na Coille , 178 ; SO , 107a ( Croinn - iubhair le brataichean sròil , / Loingeas air chòrs a ’ s ròs - iùll .
This appears to be ro - siùil and , as it rimes with tùs , it shows the compound with the stress on the second element . One would expect ro - shiùil .
)

( 3 ) a wave . Cf . ’ S mi bhi ’ g amharc nan ro - seol , / A bha ’ g aisig Mhic Leòid , bu mhor pris ,
S , 396 ; Chuireadh aghaidh an ròiseil , / Ri long mhòr an tombaca ,
Duan , 22 ; Deadh nighean Mhic - Cailein , / O Charraig nan ròiseal ,
id . , 31 ( but cf . Bu let cairdes Mhic - Cailain / Bho charric nan seol ,
GB , i , 130 . )
( 4 ) a fire . See the following entry . ]

ròiseal soluis = solus mòr ,
a great light . [Cf . Bithidh rosail gheala teinntinnin ,
E , 350 ; A nighean rìgh nan ròiseal soluis ,
MB , 37b . ròiseal mór teine ,
Applecross . ]

roith , raith , raoith .
The pin driven into the ground to which the tether is attached for restraining an animal within the limits of the tether ; ordinarily called cipean .

Fad a lurga dh ’ an laogh ,
Fad a thaobh dh ’ an chuilean choin ,
Fad a pheircill dh ’ an mheann
’ S a cheangal teann ris an roith .

ròmhanaich , ròmanaich .
Groaning , groaning out inaudibly [sic] . The still weather of the St Martin [sic] is called ròmhanaich na Samhna , ròmanaich na Samhna reamhair . [ròdhanaich ,
Fr . Allan . Rev . John MacRury spelled it Reòthanaich na Samhna and connected it with reothadh ,
frost , but if so , the vowel would be short , TGSI , xvii , 26 . ]
rònag [better ròinneag ? ] . A ball of hair put in a milk - pail .

ruadh - chas .
See dubh - chas .

ruadh - chas .
See sionnach .

ruaineachd .
Tale telling . [ruanachd ,
fiction , novel , romance ; harangues , Dw . Originally telling tales about heroes ? Cf . E . Ir . rúanaid , a strong man , champion . ]

ruais , ruaise .
Rush , hurry , scurry , ‘ throughtie ’ . Is tu an ruais ,
thou art the ‘ throughtie ’ . Ruais chaile , ruais bhalaich ,
‘ throughtie ’ unreliable girl , boy .

Bu tu sealgair a ’ chathain théid dh ’ an adhar le ruaise ,
’ S na circeige duinne bheir a gur as an fhuar - nid ,
’ S na circeige tìre , ian mìne nan cluana ,
’ S na circeige liathghlais , ian fiat ’ nan sgiath luatha .

[Cf . OL , 52 . ruaiseadh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

rùghan .
A stack of peats piled up in order for drying . [ ON hrúga , heap] .

rùid .
The swell of the sea . rùite .
Wave , a great wave , a high wave , a rushing wave , a wave rushing with great speed and force , an unusual wave . [Also means ‘ anger ’ : ghabh e rùid ,
he became wild ; cf . rùite ,
TGSI , xxxvii , 31 . ]

ruideach .
See ròcas .

ruid - ghuilbneach .
See far - ghuilbneach .

ruighlighean [dub . lect . ] . Fibs , lies , fables , romances . [ruileag ,
polite term for a falsehood , Dw . ]

ruis .
Rye meal and oat meal mixed .

ruitileachd [leg . ruidileachd ? ] . Playing . Cf . ruideis . [ruidil ,
skipping , bounding , frisking about , McL . A ’ ruidil ’ us a ’ sgiathlaich ,
BL , 200 . ruideis ,
skipping , Fr . Allan , 266 . Connected with roid ,
a run , race . ]

rusan .
Tail . rusan na cìoba ,
tail of the sheep . rusan na bó ruaidhe ,
tail of the red cow . Anything tail - like , anything that follows another thing in a straggling way . [Known in Ness , Lewis . ]

rustal .
A single - legged plough with a blade like a sickle . The rustal went on before the ordinary plough to cut the roots of grasses , rushes and bushes in rough land . The ordinary plough followed and turned over the ground . [Cf . rusladh ,
Gloss . to JMC . rusladh ,
Fr . Allan . riostal ,
a kind of plough used in the Hebrides , having a coulter formed like a sickle … sometimes drawn by one horse , Arm . ON ristill , a plough - share . ]

sabhd . Sabhd nan seachd Sathurn / air a ’ bhabhd gun mhath gun bhuadh ,
the fraud of the seventh Saturday be on the knave void of faith and good . ‘ The fraud of the seventh Saturday ’ ( lit . ‘ the seven Saturdays ’ ) means the fraud of Judas . The reference is to the seventh Saturday of Lent , when Judas hanged himself upon the Saturday following the Friday of the Crucifixion . Also : Sall nan seachd Sathurn / sian ort / dhut gach bliadhn ’ agus gu bràth ,
the gall of the seven Saturdays be thine every year and forever . Sall / sonar / call nan seachd Sathurn ort , a mhathas / mhealltachd agus a bhuadh / bhuanachd ,
be the gall / happiness / loss of the seventh Saturday thine , its goodness / irony and its gains / remunerations . Used in good - humoured banter . [sabhd ,
lie , fable ; sabhd ,
straying , cù s . ,
a stray dog ; chaidh e air sabhd ,
he strayed away ; sall ,
bitterness , satire , invective , lampoon , Dw . ]

sac = a ’ chuing ,
asthma . [sac ,
Fr . Allan . Sac air m ’ anail ,
OL , 77 , 121 . ]
sàideal [there appears to be a mark of length on - a - ] . A bay narrow at the mouth .

saighead sionn .
See sionn .

sail - fraighe .
The partition beam .

salchar ailleig .
Frog spawn . [glothag , glothagach ,
Dw . ]

sall .
A paw .

sall .
See sabhd .

sallt .
See sall ( previous entry ) .

Samhain .
On Oidhche Shamhna ,
Hallowe ’ en , All Hallow Eve , the flocks were brought home from the pastures and secured in their enclosures , the horses in the marclann ,
the cattle in the bà - theach , bàthach ,
the sheep in the cliath ,
the goats in the mainnir .
When all were brought home and secured , the goodman , fear an taighe ,
carrying a pot containing fire , and with scraps of iron , and followed by the goodwife , bean an taighe ,
and their family , walked round the flocks , spréidh ,
and the steading , all singing the Beannachd Samhna ,
Hallow Blessing .

Samhanaich .
Giants . [ii , 347 . Samhanaich ,
the giants who dwelt in caves by the sea , SCR , 62 , 140 - 141 . Cf . sadhanach ,
big , sturdy fellow , Fr . Allan , 266 ? ]

samhnachan .
The bànag when it goes upstream and becomes black / dark . She comes in summer and goes upstream with the salmon . Bànag , litheag , samhnag , samhnachan are the same fish in different stages .

saobh - bhleoghan .
False milking , filching the milk by night from cows in the fold . Also faobh - bhleoghan , iar - bhleoghan , far - bhleoghan . [iar - bhleoghan a misreading of far - bhleoghan ? ]

saodh , saodhanan .
Turn , turn back , as a dog does to sheep or cattle . Is e am buachaill ùr agus sùrd nan con agus na saodhnan fada dh ’ fhàg mo thàn / chrodh gun dàir am bliadhna ,
it is the new herd and the liveliness of the dogs and the long circuits that has left my cattle uncalved this year . saodh mór ,
big circuit . saodh fada ,
long turning , long wheeling .

saogh , saodh .
Seed , brood , issue , progeny ; pairing ; bringing forth .

Sneachd ri breith nan laogh ,
sneachd ri saogh nan aighean .

Snow in April when hinds are bearing , and snow in October when deer are pairing : under these conditions prospects are good for man and beast . [Cf . saoghach ,
iv , 74 ? ]

saoth .
Premonition , second sight . saothadh .
Prediction , vision . saothanan .
Visions , premonitions . Also saodh ( a ) , saodhadh . [saodh , saogh , saoth ,
Fr . Allan . ]

Saothair an Daobh .
‘ The Devil ’ s Work ’ , is a usual name for a trap - dyke . In some places it is called Lorg an Fhir Mhillidh ,
the Track of the Destroyer [i . e . the Devil] ; a dyke of this name runs across the south

shoulder of Caipbhal in Harris . In Lismore a trap - dyke is called Caisir Neamha ,
the Caisir of the Venomous One [ ? ] . [Saothair an daghaire ,
work that is useless , Fr . Allan , s . v . daghaire . ]

sasag .
See sunnadan .

sealaman .
Lingerer , malingerer .

sealasdair Frangach .
Species of bog - lily .

sealbh .
Wealth generally , especially cattle . Chan e sealbh na feudalach am faotainn ,
the wealth of cattle consists not in procuring them ; i . e . , ere they give a return they must be kept and well kept and perhaps for long . [ii , 349 ; iii , 84 ; sealbh chaora ,
ii , 249 ; sealbh uan ,
i , 162 . ]

sealbh .
See garbhan .

sealbhag , boinneag , poinneag , puinneag [puinteag ,
N . Uist] . Sorrel . A stomachic ; math gu geurachadh stamaic ,
good to whet the stomach . [sealbhag , buinteag , puinneag ,
Fr . Allan . ]

sealgair .
See corr .

seamhas [sèamhas ? ] .
Spell , charm , incantation .

Sùil na seamhais ,
Fuath na farmad ,
Gnù na geamhais ,
Dìl na dearmad
Cha tig ort .
Nor eye nor spell , nor hate nor envy , nor jealousy nor … nor flood nor neglect shall come upon thee .

[sèamhas ,
good luck , chance , prosperity , Dw ; seamhas , seanns ,
E chance , McB . Cf . sèabhas ,
meaningless talk , nonsense , TGSI , xxi , 263 ? See geamhais . ]

seanntraigh . [Centaury . ] Good for colic and geàrrach ,
flux . [seantruidh , seamrabhuidh , teantruidh ,
Fr . Allan . ]

searran = corran fiaclach ,
toothed sickle . [E . Ir . serr , a sickle . ]

seasaireachd .
Standing in church as a discipline or penance .

seasgan .
Reed - grass . This was used for bedding and was considered extremely healthy . [seasgann ,
Fr . Allan . E . Ir . seisc , sedge , rushes . ]

seideagach .
See tur .

seilmideir = seilcheag ,
a snail . [Ir . seilmide , a snail . ]

séis .
A homemade couch , unupholstered sofa placed against the wall of the house or in front of the fire in the middle of the floor . The séis of old was used as a bed and is still used as a place of rest when the people come home wet and weary from their work on sea and land . The séis is a settle with barred back . It is made of plain wood and is wholly bare of any cloth or stuffing or trimming of any kind . Almost any crofter house in the Outer Isles has a séis .
It is still occasionally used as a bed . The writer has grateful recollections of the séis when collecting lore . [In Lewis ʃe : ʃ , in North Uist ʃøiʃe . The origin of the word is obscure . E . Ir . sess , ON sess seem excluded by reason of their short vowel . Oftedal
( The Gaelic of Leurbost , 64 ) queryingly takes it from chaise longue . This , though phonetically possible , seems unlikely . ]

séisig .
Melody . [ii , 309 ; iii , 32 ; v , 339 , 342 . ]

seòcaire ( Argyll ) , steòcaire ( Inverness ) . The professional name of the man who carried the hawks in hunting and cared for them at home . The seòcaire was the predecessor of the modern gamekeeper . The seòcaire had a piece of land from MacLeod of MacLeod for his services , as had the piper and the clàrsair ,
harper , and the various other men about the MacLeod family . The remains of the seòcaire ’ s house are still pointed out . The place is about a quarter of a mile north of Dunvegan Castle . The ruin is called Tobhta Sheòcaire . [This appears to be the place now called Tobht ’ a ’ Chòcaire .
Is this a modern corruption or is Carmichael mistaken ? The omission of the article casts doubt on the form given by him . There are references to falconry in the MacLeod accounts as late as 1706 ; Grant , History of the MacLeods , 360 . seòcaire is from seabhag , seobhag ,
hawk . steòcaire is a stalker , a different word , not a variant . ]

seòl .
A sail . The sails of the Western Isles were home - made . The material was either wool or canvas . The former was called clòth , clòth bàn ,
cloth , white cloth ; cùrainn , cùrainn bhàn ,
flannel , white flannel ; plaide , plaide gheal ,
plaiden , white plaiden . The woollen sail was called seòl plangaid ,
blanket sail , to distinguish it from the seòl cainb ,
hempen sail or canvas sail . The woollen sail was heavy and cumbrous at all times , and in rain and wind it was dangerous . The last seòl plangaid seen in the Long Island was that of a boat which came from St Kilda to Hoghgearraidh , North Uist , in 18 — , having been driven out of its course [on a voyage] to Obbe , Harris . The boat was in danger of being swamped in the stormy bay of Hoghgearraidh , and the people in a miserable plight from cold , wet and hunger , and afraid to land lest the Uist people , known to eat seals , which are simply men and women under enchantment , should kill and eat them ! At the risk of their own lives , however , the Uistmen rescued them and treated them most hospitably . The woollen sail was driven out by home - made canvas , and home - made canvas has now been ousted by canvas from Glasgow .

sgadan .
See liabag .

sgagaire .
Poltroon . See lòchraidh .

sgaid .
Dues , farm dues , taxes . sgaid a ’ ghobha ,
the smith ’ s dues ; sgaid a ’ mhaoir ,
the mair ’ s dues . See cùileag . [Probably pl . of sgad ( or sgat ?
) ; ON skattr , tax , tribute . ]

sgaid .
Scathe , destruction . Chaidh an duine a sgaid ,
the man went to ruin .

Mo chreach ’ s mo sgaid mar dh ’ éirich dhomh
An dé ’ s mi dol dh ’ an teampall .

[sgaid ,
Fr . Allan . Fr . Allan uses the word himself in Eilean na h - Òige : Là gun dad aca ’ gan ragach / Is latha sgaid gu leòir ann . ]

sgàinteag .
See bà - chaorain .
sgair = sgaoin = sgeul a chumail air chuimhne . [ ? ]

sgaldair , sgolldair .
Medusa , jellyfish .

sgarbh callaig ( ? ) .
See bura - bhuachaille .

sgarbh mór , sgarbh buill .
See odhrag .

sgarsach = guth ciùil ,
voice . [Cf . sgairteachd ,
shouting , shrieking , Dw . ]

sgath na nathrach .
See tapag .

sgathach .
The thin fluid remaining in the bottom of the dish when the cream is drawn off for churning . The sgathach is drawn off by means of a tap at the bottom of the dish . It is bitter but pleasant to drink ; is seann - sàth ( no teann - sàth ) deoch dheth ,
a drink of it is filling . [Deoch fhionna - ghlas was the most effectual drink for quenching thirst . This “ whitey - grey ” mixture was milk and water in equal proportions , and the sour thick milk that was under the cream that was kept for butter was churned into a froth , and it made a cooling drink . It was called sgathach .
— TGSI , xiv , 148 . ]

sgealbach , sgealpach .
A half - grown lad . sgealbag , sgealpag .
A half - grown girl .

sgeip , sgeap .
See losaid .

sgeith nathrach .
See clach nathrach .

sgeoch , sgoich , sgocharaich .
The heart , lungs , lights and kidneys of a sheep . [sgoich ,
v , 262 ; ? sgothaich ,
v , 230 . sgochraich ,
liver , Dw . ]

sgeul fuadain , sgeul ròidheach .
See ròidheachd .

sgiath faochaig .
See faochag .

sgiath ime .
A slice of butter . See clàr càise .

sgiathag .
A hoop - net for holding grain , generally rye , bere or barley , over the fire . The net is made of bent . It is suspended over the fire on the middle of the floor . The hoop is taken off now and then to shift and turn the grain . The corn is quickly dried and then ground in the quern . The meal is palatable , if peaty in flavour .

sgiathalan .
A kind of wickerwork door .

sgiathan leathair .
A bat ; in Ireland also a swallow . See ialstarag .

sgiobal .
See potag .

sgionn .
Marten - cat ( Skye ) .

sgiot .
Scatter .

Fanaidh sgeulachdan ’ san fhonn
Fhad ’ s bhios sìol nan sonn ’ na bhun ,
Ach dar a dh ’ atharraicheas am pòr
Théid na sgeòil gu sgiot ’ s gu sgur .

[sgiot ,
disperse , scatter ; fling or throw about , Dw . Tha trian mo stuic am fiachan cip / Aig aon a sgiot a chùinneadh ,
RD , 331 ; Goirtean nam Broighleag / Sgiot e mo theaghlach ,
PB , 127 . ]

an sgleog Uibhisteach .
See glug .

sgòd .
See smùr .

sgonnag .
The chief rafter in the end of the gableless house , and when the end is curved and not square . The clach sgonnaig is the stone below the sgonnag in the byre .

sgrath .
See ceap ; suimir .

sgreagag , sgreagag nan creag .
See crotal ; gròm .

sgriamhail , sgriamhnail .
The crying of a spoilt child . [Perhaps a portmanteau word sgriachail + sgiamhail . ]

sgrogach .
See caora .

sgroigean .
See ealpag .

sgrù ’ an .
Stook . [sgrùthan ( sgrù ’ an ) ,
a shock of corn ( Assynt ) , from Norse skrúf , hay - cock , McB . ]

sgucha - féithe .
See tolm .

sgùill .
A clown , clownish man , clumsy fellow , dastard . [sgùil ,
v , 356 . ]

sgùman .
See caora .

siabhan = seachran ,
wandering . [sēabh , seubh ,
stray , McA . ]

sìdhean mór = cìochan na mnà sìdh . [Some plant . ] This is good for pains in arms , shoulders , etc . Boil it a little and apply it half raw and rub it well in . Keep ducks from it as it will kill them . [cìoch na mnatha sìdheadh ,
Fr . Allan . Said to be the name for sea anemones in Barra . ]

sileadh .
Flow , flowing . Tha sileadh air an oidhche ,
there is flowing / dripping on the night ; tha sileadh air a ’ bhoin ,
there is flowing on the cow ; is minig a bha sileadh sona air boin chaol - chasaich ,
oft was happy flowing upon slim - footed cow . [Cf . is minig a bha ùth mhòr aig bò chaol - chasach ,
Waifs and Strays , v , 135 . ]

simid .
Mallet , beetle , clothes - beetle , potato - masher ( also ploc buntàta ) ; churn staff . The head of the simid for churning was made of horse - hair , preferably the hair of the tail of an entire horse . Simid and ceann - simid also mean tadpole .

sineag , an t - sineag .
The uvula ; also a ’ chìoch , a ’ chioch - shlugain . [sine = teat , dug , nipple ; sineag also = wick of a lamp . cìoch - shlugain ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . slugaid . ]
sìochaire . [Fairy - host . ] A fairy . Pl . sìochraiche , sìochraichean . [E . Ir . sídchaire , a troop of supernatural beings . ]

sìodhach ; sìochach .
A fairy . Pl . forms are sìodhairean , sìochairean [sìochairean from the previous] ; a female fairy is sìofag , sìochag .

siogada sìn - seanair .
Great - great - grandfather . Mo shiogad sì - seanair ,
my great - great - grandfather . [Cf . siogada - sinn - seanaireach ,
sly , old - fashioned , Dw . ]

sìol a ’ mhairt .
See cudaig ruadh .

sìolag .
See cladach ; langaidh .

siolpan , siolpan maide .
Stake of wood . Also stàl . [siolpan ,
constable ’ s baton , Dw . In Ness , Lewis , the word is giolpan ; giolpan maide ,
chunk of wood . ]

sionn .
Unseen , hidden , mysterious , dread ; saighead sionn ,
an arrow from the unseen or unknown , an arrow shot by the hosts of the air or the fairies of the knoll at a human being ; bodha sionn ,
an invisible reef . These reefs are extremely dangerous ; on a calm and unruffled sea , moved only by the slow Atlantic swell , a huge wave will suddenly rise and rush with great speed and terrific roar to break on the bodha sionn .
MacQuarrie of Ulva and his run - away bride were lost on such a reef in Loch nan Ceall , Mull , which is hence known as Bodha Mhic Guaire ,
MacQuarrie ’ s Reef . The rugged islands of Jura and Colonsay were known to Mull boatmen as Na h - Uinnlean , Na h - Eileanan Uinnleach [MS . Uillean ; Uilleach] ,
the elbowed islands , from which Campbell made the name Ullin . The story of the drowning is still known in Mull . Teine sionn is a form of teine sionnaich or teine sionnachain ,
phosphorescence . Chuir thu teine sionn a m ’ shùil ,
thou didst drive fox - fire from mine eye . [sionnach , sionnachain ,
Fr . Allan . ]

sionnach .
Fox . A species of fox with black feet was called dubh - chas ,
the species with red feet ruadh - chas ;
the latter is the sionnach ruadh or sionnach buidhe ,
red or yellow fox , and is larger than the other . Both were well - known to fox - hunters .

siosdair .
See coinneal .

sirtean cuagach .
A shapeless mass .

slabhdan . Sùil an t - slabhdain ,
soft eyes .

slabhairigeadh .
See slaig .

slabhraidh .
See dealan .

slaig .
An egg plaster . slabhairigeadh . [Applying the plaster ? Cf . slabhaigeadh ,
Dw . ]

slaistreadh .
See luistreadh .

slaobag , slaopag .
Clumsy woman ; slaobag bhoireannaich ,
clumsy woman ; slaobag fhireannaich ,
clownish man . [See laobhag . ]

slapar , slaparan .
Stamping with the feet as among pools of water . slaparaich , slapanaich .
Splashing among pools of water .

slat - shiùil .
See rac .

sliadh .
Leech . [sliagh ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . sliabh ,
juice of leeches , Dw . ]

slige - chreachainn .
The concave shell of the clam [see also leasgadan] . It was used for several domestic purposes — skimming milk , lifting butter and drinking whisky .

Is toigh liom fhéin an t - slige chreachainn ,
O ’ s aist ’ as blasd ’ an dram ;
Is math an t - ainm dhi an creachann ,
O ’ s i ’ n t - slige chreach mi bh ’ ann !

[With a pun on creach ,
to ravage , plunder , ruin . The verse is a variant of a verse in Alexander MacDonald ’ s Oran Rìoghail a ’ Bhotuil , beginning Lìon suas an t - slige chreachainn ,
AMD ( 1924 ) , 204 . ]

slìm , slìom , slìmeadh .
See lìme .

slinn .
Reed / reeds of loom . Also slinneachan . [E . Ir . slinn , a weaver ’ s sley . ]

slioc = lioc ,
a gravestone . Also called darag .

slogan , sliogan = slugan ,
throat . [slugaid ,
Fr . Allan . ]

slongag = crann - tabhaill ,
a sling ( weapon ) . [Other forms are : sglongag , glungag , gliongag , longag , lungag , spleangag , spliongag .
ON sløngva , a sling . ]

sluagh .
Host , the spirits of the dead . Tha an sluagh a ’ tighinn ’ s a ’ falbh , is marbh gun bhith beò ,
the ‘ host ’ comes and goes , dead and not alive .

slugan , sluganach .
A person given to gossip . slugan sleamhain ,
‘ a slippery gullet ’ , a man or woman who cannot keep a secret .

sluistreadh , sluisteadh .
See luistreadh , etc .

smàchdan , smachdaire .
See tarmachan .

smalag .
See cudaig ruadh .

smear .
The finest linen , used for men ’ s shirts . [Cf . smior ,
best part of anything ( smior ,
marrow , pith ) , Dw . ]

smeòla , smeòr , smeòrach .
Mavis , thrush . [See ii , 359 . ] It is called smeòrach Chrìosda ,
the thrush of Christ . [E . Ir . smólach , thrush . ]

smùr , smùire , smùirn , smuairn , smùrnan , smùirnean , smùrdan .
A mote in the eye ; item , iota . Nar bheil smùire tùir / toinisg / tuairim aige = nar bheil sgòd toinisg aige ,
he has not an atom of sense . [The forms smùirn , smùirnean ,
etc . , point to the former existence of a singulative in - ne , smùirne ,
from smùr ,
dust ; see O ’ Rahilly , SGS , iii , 69 . ]

an t - snag .
The nightjar . See ii , 299 . The snag is a summer bird , small , with a bluish head . It is also called gocan cuthaige .

Cho sgiobalta ris an t - snag ,
as trim and clever as the nightjar . [There seems to be a good deal of confusion here . snag is not the nightjar but the woodpecker . On the other hand if the bird meant is gocan na cuthaige ,
then that is the meadow pipit or titlark , the Gaelic for which is snàthadag ( snàthdag , snàthag ) ,
q . v . , or riabhag .
In which case what is meant is snàg ,
reduced form of snàthag ? ]

snàithle .
Thread . gearradh snàithle ,
‘ cutting the thread ’ , gearradh snàithle na beatha ,
‘ cutting the thread of life ’ , are symbolic phrases frequent among the old people and often symbolised on the old tombstones . On some

of these the shears only are shown , on some shears and thread , on some the shears , thread and ball of thread . The ball is down at the foot of the stone ; from it the thread ascends , winding and twisting between the blades of the shears and thence ascends and disappears in cloud above . On some stones the thread is between the blades ready to be cut , on others the thread is cut , the lower part falling in crooked coils on the ground . [Cf . Olc liom giorrad a h - íorna , / ’ n bhé lér sníomhadh a snáithe ,
ill I deem the shortness of her skein , by whom their thread was spun , SVDL , p . 92 , and note , p . 279 . ]

snàthadag , mionan , mionan min .
Meadow pipit , a bird which follows the cuckoo . At Inveran in 1888 I saw two pipits , which had thrown their own young out of the nest and allowed them to die of starvation , follow a fledgling cuckoo , feeding it as hard as they could . [Cf . snag ( leg . snàg ? ) , supra . ]

snìomh .
See pala , palla ; uiridh .

snòdaich .
To sniff . See pàl . [snòtaich ,
Ness , Lewis . ]

snòdan .
Leisure , calmness in movement or action ; tha an crodh a ’ tighinn dachaigh air an snòdan fhéin ,
the cattle are coming home at their leisure , not driven ; tha an crodh ag inghilt air an snòdan fhéin ,
the cattle are browsing upon their own calm course . [Thànaig an spréidh dhachaigh air an snòdan bòidheach fhéin ,
v , 132 . ]

sodalach .
See tur .

sògh .
See tògh .

soidh - thòs , soidh - thoisich .
Stem - post of a boat . soidh - earr , soidh - dheiridh .
Stern - post of a boat .

An uair a chual an Gill - Easpa
A ’ bhuile chuir an t - soidh - earr dhith
Is ann a dh ’ éirich e air uilinn
Feuch na chuir e na b ’ fhearr i .

[saidh - thoisich , saidh - dheiridh ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . saidh .
Cf . Bho sāil gu aird ’ a saoith - thoisich ,
AD , 193 ; Bu darach dìreach , daingean / Bha ’ na saithean ’ s ’ na cuid chluas ,
MC , 307 ; Bha fiodhaidh math ’ s na saithean aic ’ , is darach anns an ruadh - bhord ,
BTh , 145 ; ’ S a saithean arda ’ s direach iad ,
id . , 356 ; ( of the edge of a razor ) ’ N tra chi thu ’ n ealtain gheur ghlan , / Saltair gu seamh seach a saigh ,
G , 296 ; NGP , 395 . ]

soilleadh .
Roasting , frying . soilleadh sidhinn ,
roasting venison ; soilleadh éisg ,
frying fish .

soll .
See clach - shuill .

sollaidh .
An anchor . air sollaidh ,
at anchor .

an t - sonasag , an té ruadh , a ’ mhìola - mhàg .
The toad or frog . [sonasan ,
the young frog when it has passed the tadpole stage , TGSI , xxiv , 364 . ]

sop . air na suip .
See glùn .

sòrn .
See brat ; cuilig . [sòrn ,
Fr . Allan , 267 . L furnus . ]

sorrag ,
sometimes torrag .
The circular cavity or basin of a kiln , occasionally called sùil ,
eye . Over the sorrag the brat ,
covering , is laid on which the grain is dried . See brat ; cuilig . [Also surrag . sorrag ,
flue of a kiln , Fr . Allan . ]

Spàinteach .
See caora .

spàl .
A shuttle . In Uist the spàl is of reeds , in Harris and Lewis it is often of the shank bone of a sheep , the joints being sawn off .

spalt , spaltadh .
See spòltadh .

spang .
Green stubble . See treothad .

spathalt .
See spòltadh .

spearrach .
See fialtag .

speil .
See leagan , leagadh .

spiol = a chuile dad ,
wholly [in phrase a chuile spiol ?
For meaning , see spioladh . ]

spioladh .
Picking off the ears of corn with the hand . [For the etymology see O ’ Rahilly , SGS , ii , 26 . spioladh ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . taghadh . ]

spìllireachd .
Danger . [Cf . spéileireachd ,
game ; also sword play . ]

splang .
Share , portion , division ; the spawn of fish before separation . splang grùthain ,
share of liver of fish , fowl , sheep or cow .

spolgan = spiolgan . Unhusk[ing] with the teeth . [spiolg ,
Fr . Allan . ]

spòltadh , spaltadh , spalt , spathalt .
Tear , tear asunder limb by limb , as by horses in punishment .

Is ann a dh ’ iarr iad mo spòltadh
Eadar eich Mhic an Tòisich ,
Mo chur timcheall a ’ chaisteil
Gun mo charaid dha m ’ chomhnadh .

[For these lines see LG , 119 , and TGSI , xxviii , 361 , which have spealtadh instead of spòltadh .
A less complete version is in T , 291 ff . ]

Cha spadar mi , cha spaltar mi ,
Cha spùilltear mi , cha spailtear mi ,
Cha chùram oidhch na latha dhomh
Is Fear mo Thaigh am chomhnadh .

Ge do rachadh mo spòltadh
’ S mo chrochadh air chòrcaich ,
Bu sholta siubhal leat , Ìosa ,
Ann an sìth agus sòlas .

Bhiodh fir chalm ’ air a tobhtaidh ,
I ’ na deann chun na cloiche ,
Is muir dhubhghorm a ’ spoltadh m ’ a bord .

[There are two words , if not three , here : ( 1 ) spòltadh ;
( 2 ) spaltadh , spoltadh ( if these also are not different words ) . spaltadh is probably the same as spealtadh ,
split . For spoltadh in the last verse cf . spoltadh ,
scattering drops of water , etc . , from a vessel , TGSI , xxii , 40 . ]

sporan .
Purse . sporan leathair ,
leather sporan ; sporan béin ,
sporan of skin , made of the pelt of the otter , the pole - cat , the marten - cat or the wild - cat ; sporan mollach ,
shaggy sporan , of goatskin ; sporan donn ,
brown sporan , of dressed leather .

sporracan .
Crumbs .

spreaghan .
Sherd , a piece of broken pottery or a piece of broken pot used in the preparation of céirein [sic] , ointment , acuinn / céirein [sic] leighis . [Cf . spriadhan na muic / nan cearc ,
broken vessels for the use of pigs / hens , Ness , Lewis . For the vowel cf . Lewis spria ( gh )
for spreagh . ]

spriodach .
See isean .

spuing .
See cnò .

sreath , streath .
See faircill .

sreathainn . [Straw on which corn is laid in a kiln . ] [= traoghaig , q . v . ] Cho tioram ris an t - sreathainn ,
as dry as kiln - straw . See brat . [See under tarran ,
Dw . ]

sriutan , striutan .
Small sneeze . As in sriutan na triughaich ( see triogh ) . In Benbecula striutan is a name for the “ kinks ” in hooping cough . The Uist and Argyll name is braise ( lit . suddenness ) and triughair . [striutan ,
Fr . Allan . striutan ghuidheachan ,
a volley of oaths ( North Uist ) . ]

srùban .
See cladach .

stail .
See staoil .

stail .
See clogad .

stail - bhòil , stail - mhòil , stail - bheòil .
Boasting . [stail
stailc ? ]

staing .
A paling . [ON stöng , staff , pole . As a measure of land it occurs in Irish as stang ; see Éigse , i , 35 ; v , 221 . ]

stàireachd .
Sauntering [pacing back and fore] . [stàrach ,
Fr . Allan . Cf . Cha ’ n fhaigh thu cead ’ bhi ’ stārachd / Ann sios us suas mar b ’ àbhaist ,
LG , 67 ; ’ S mise a bhios gu stātoil / A stātharachd sa ’ n am sin , / Ma ’ n cuairt do mo phlantation ,
DMcL , 76 ; ’ S ann bhios mi stātharachd an aite folluich ,
id . , 78 ; Stàreachd nan magarain lachdain ,
id . , 190 . ]

stàl .
See siolpan .

stallaire .
A rock - man , a rock - dweller , from stalla ,
