a rock . A Culdee anchorite of this name lived in Boreray of St Kilda . The ruins of his cell are still traceable and still called Taigh an Stallair .

stamh , staimhe , stana .
The stalk of the broad tangle ; oarweed . [stamh ,
Fr . Allan . ON stafr , staff . ]

staoig an amadain .
Spleen in sheep ? Cat ’ s collop ? [Sic . Another hand has deleted spleen and substituted ‘ money spent foolishly ’ . staoig an amadain , dubh - liath ,
a thin leaf of flesh inside sheep and cattle , but lean and not very good , Fr . Allan . staoig
ON steik , Bidrag , 68 . Perhaps originally the part of a slaughtered animal apportioned to the chief ’ s jester or fool . See loch - bhléin . ]

staoil , straoil , straoileag = stail .
Bandage , rag . straoileagan .
Rags . tha an duine ’ na straoileagan ,
the man is in tatters . [stail ,
a bandage , Fr . Allan . stail ,
bandage , scarf ( North Uist ) . E . Ir . stoil , a stole , L stola . ]

staorainn , staorum .
Stiff , straight up and down ; inclined to a backward lean . duine staorum ,
a man so straight as to appear to be leaning back . [staorum ,
bending of the body to one side , Dw . ]

stapag .
See grainnseach ; graothaich ; potag .

steàirneal , steàirnean , steàrtan , steàirtean .
Tern , Arctic tern .

stéill , stéille .
The top of the house wall , like anainn .

stèin , stùn , staoin .
Fool , churl , lout . Chuir an stùn an dréig aige am Poll Fhaolain agus cha do rinn am bùrn feum riamh tuillidh ,
the clown put his nag in the Pool of Fillan and the water never did good again — so said Ferguson , shoemaker , Rose Street , Edinburgh , a native of Aberfeldy , a grand specimen of the old Highlander , full of Perthshire lore of the most interesting kind . [Accents doubtful . staoin ,
shallow , “ soft ” , silly , applied to a fellow lacking in perspicacity ; and staoin ,
pewter , tin ; in derision , soft , inactive fellow , Dw . ] See dréig .

steòcaire .
See seòcaire .

stiapach .
Slippery . soc stiapach ,
slippery snout .

stìom .
Snood , maiden ’ s snood , a narrow band of silk , satin , linen , velvet or wool worn by maidens .

Rìgh ! gur mise tha dheth truagh
Dar chì mi chlann - nighean uam , [shuas
Stìom an camagaibh an cuach
Is mis ’ a ’ cumail suas an anairt .

A chaile dhubh dhona , [bhreun
Dh ’ ìobair thu do stìom ,
’ S cha d ’ fhìrinnich thu do bheannag . [d ’ iochdaich thu
air do bhréid

A girl who wore the snood was called stìomach ,
in contradistinction to a girl who wore the bréid — bréideach .
The first meant maidenhood ,

the last matronhood . stìomag .
Snooded one . stìom gruaige ,
hair snood ; stìom cuailein ,
ringlet snood ; stìom maighdinn ,
maiden ’ s snood . [stìom ,
i , 206 ; ii , 212 , 364 ; iii , 352 ; v , 18 , 44 , 70 , 74 ; stìomach ,
ii , 364 ; v , 350 ; stìomag ,
ii , 364 . Ir . sdìom , lace - work , AiD , ii , 236 . ] See bréid .

stòl faircill .
See faircill .

stòp .
A small churn , a milk pail , etc . The imdeal ( q . v . ) is tied round the mouth with the iall ,
thong .

stòp faircill .
See faircill .

stòr - fhiacail .
See fiacal goibhre .

straoil , straoileag .
See staoil .

straoghag .
See traoghag .

streamach .
See broc .

striachach .
See broc .

struilleag = cailleach ( ? ) [sic] . The struilleag had to be sent away with a rann ,
rime . No milk , no cream , no cheese would come from a cow if the struilleag was not sent away with a rime . struthlag is the Appin pronunciation . [Cf . Oran a ’ bhàta do ’ m b ’ ainm ‘ Struileag ’ ,
MC , 316 ; see Dw , s . v . struileag ;
An t - Eileanach , 2nd ed . , 314 . ]

strùt = ceò ,
smoke , smut .

struthach .
Hooping cough . See triogh .

stuagh .
See tonn .

stucanach = rag ,
stiff - necked . [Cf . ii , 168 ? stoganachd ,
Fr . Allan ? ]

suath .
See mot , mod .

sùgan .
See lonachan .

sugan - braoide .
Horse collar . [Mark of shortness on - u - . The word is sùgan shortened in pre - tonic position . braoide = braighde
bràghaide ,
a gen . of bràghad ,
itself originally gen . of bràgha ,
neck , etc . Cf . braighdean ,
straw collar for horses , Ness , Lewis . ]

sùghan .
See carran .

suidhichean .
Roof couples . [suidhe ,
beam or supporter of a house ; maide - suidhe ,
couple of a house , Dw . ]

sùil .
A round brooch . [sùil etymologically means the sun ; see O ’ Rahilly , EIHM , 58 . ]

sùil .
See sorrag .

suimir , suimear , suiminear .
Rafter . suimir taighe ,
the rafters running lengthwise in a thatched house ; suimir faraidh ,
the cross - beams supporting the faradh ( q . v . ) ; across these go the cabair ,
i . e . , lengthwise the house ; on the cabair the sgrath ,
divots , laid over the cabair like slates on a roof . This forms a loft , often used as a sleeping - place . [Sc . timmer , E timber . ]

sul , sul mara .
Jellyfish .

sulchas .
Joyousness . [Cf . sulchair ,
cheerful , affable , etc . , Dw . ]

an t - Sultain .
See broc .

sunnadan .
In some districts tràghach [see tràthach] . It is singularly tough

and in former times was used much for ropes , baskets , bags , etc . , and especially for the sunnag ,
easy chair . Sasag is the same form of chair . Were a herring barrel cut lengthwise along the middle and then cross - wise across the middle , the result would resemble the shape of a sunnag . [sunnag ,
v , 364 . sasag is also a kind of basket , as in the saying : ithidh tu fhathast moll a sasaig . ]

surrag .
See sorrag .

susadh , saosadh .
Outlining , marking off . susadh nam feannag ,
outlining the lazybeds — a flat - topped square - sided agricultural ridge . [susadh ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . crann - ruslaidh . ]

susgann = dad , nì , sian ,
a thing , a whit ; perhaps a form of susbann , susbaint ,
etc . , E substance .

suthag = tuthag .
A patch on a garment . A beautiful singer , listening to a bad singer , at last burst out —
‘ Gum faiceadh Dia mi ! Cha chàs thu bhith ’ gam blaigheadh , ach ’ gan suthagadh ! ’
May God behold me ! not only are you mangling them but patching them ! ’ [suthag , subhag ,
Fr Allan . In N . Uist tuthag , dubhag .
Perhaps = tughag
tugha ,
thatch ? ]

tabhal .
Hollow , roof , rooftree , a mean hole , a mean dwelling , còs ,
a hole under tree roots .

tabhann .
See comhart .

tabhasg .
See tàsg .

tacar .
Used for the breast bone or chest of a man , i . e . , that which supports .

tachran , tacharan = taibhse = manadh .
Ghost . [tacharan ,
a puny thin man , Fr . Allan , who draws attention to the short initial vowel . E . Ir . tacharān , orphan , waif . It is , however , also found with initial vowel long . Cf . Ag iarguin m ’ a cāirdibh ; / Cha b ’ iad na tàcharain chrìon ,
G , 55 ; Chor ’ s nach fhaichte gu bràth diot , / Ach do thâchran air ais ,
Kenneth MacKenzie , 180 ; ’ S gun cuir e as a làraich / An tàcharan a th ’ ann ,
DB , l . 2553 . Other meanings are ‘ a changeling ’ , ‘ an illegitimate child ( ? ) ’ . See manadh . ]

taibhse .
See tachran ; tàsg .

taibreadh .
Doing anything with smartness or a jerk . [Another MS . appears to have tarbradh ,
a thing quickly done , akin to tiolpadh . ]

taigh .
See nasg .

taisgeal .
News , secret news . [E . Ir . taiscél , account , description ; prognostication . ]

talcas .
Scorn , disdain , contempt . The Four Contempts of the World ( Ceithir Dìmeis an Domhain ) were :

Talcas nam ban ,
Tabhann nan con ,
Corrachd nan sìodh ,
Snighe nan arddorus .
The converse was greatly desired , the Four Excellences / Desires of the World ( Ceithir Càrlais na Cruinne ) :

Urram mo mhnatha ,
Urram mo chloinne ,
Urram mo chairdean ,
Gràs Dé nan dùl .

[tailceas ,
Fr . Allan . Also talcuis , tarcuis .
E . Ir . tarcaisne , tarcaise (
tarm - ad - cí - ) , contempt , contumely , insult . No idir mar thailceas air sprēidh ,
G , 248 ; Dh ’ fhāg thu mise mar thalcais ,
id . , 203 ; Ga be bheireadh tàir le tàilceis ( sic ) , Kenneth MacKenzie , 68 . ]

tallan .
Chance , opportunity .

tamhan - eallaich .
See damhan - alla .

tamhasg .
A brownie , a kelpie , supernatural deity akin to the ùraisg .
The term is applied to a man of great strength and little sense . Lag nan Tamhasg ,
‘ hollow of the brownies ’ , is a place near Paible , North Uist . [But Lag nan Tanchasg ,
iv , 119 . tamhasg ,
a thin skeleton of a man , Fr . Allan . Also means a blockhead , fool . In SD , 51 , tamhaisg means ‘ mercenaries ’ ( amhas ) . ]

taobh nan tairrngean de ’ n dorus .
‘ The nails ’ side of the door ’ . A phrase heard in Lismore , meaning the outside of the door . Wooden nails were of old used in doors and elsewhere ; these had neatly squared heads and the row or rows of nail - heads were obvious to the most casual glance .

taod - guailne .
See biast - mhaol .

taodaire .
A person leading a horse , or other animal , by a halter .

taois .
See brig .

taosg .
Quantity . taosg sgadain ,
a heap of herrings ; taosg talmhanta ,
a quantity of earth ; taosg bainne ,
a quantity of milk . [Often means the precise full or near the full of a liquid measure . taosg ,
Fr . Allan . E . Ir . taesc , jet , spurt , flow ( of blood , etc . ) ; taescach , flowing , gushing . Cf . Ann am malairt nam buillean , / Bu taosgach fuil as a chreuchdan ,
AD , 172 . ]

tapag .
The tapag is a word or exclamation said in a sudden surprise , a sudden occurrence , a sudden start , e . g . , when one touches something hot suddenly or drops something accidentally etc . The following are examples [many of these are properly imprecations] :

Bodach ort ; brigis ort ; ball dubh is dearg ort ; brioghas ort ; braman ort ; cailleach ort ; breacan dubh is uain ort ; tartan dubh is dearg ort ; bodach as do dhéidh ; cailleach as do dhéidh ; triubhas ort ; Dia leat ; contrachd , contrachd ort ; dubh , dubh ort ; dearg , dearg ort ; dubh is dearg , dubh is dearg ort ; donn , donn ort , dubh is donn ort ; bodach breac ort ; bodach Irteach , bodach Irteach ort ; piollag , piollag ort ; dóbhran , dóbhran ort ; dóbhran donn , dóbhran donn ort ; dóbhran donn an t - sruth , dóbhran donn an t - sruth ort ; deannag , deannag ort ; clisgeadh , clisgeadh ort ; bodach teth , bodach teth ort ; teth , teth ort ; marbhaisg , marbhaisg ort ; ùir is anart , ùir is anart ort ; mollachd ,

mollachd ort ; beannachd , beannachd ort ; ùir , ùir ort ; anart , anart ort ; ceangal ort ; piseach ort ; gaolach ort ; geòlach ort ; baobach , baobach ort ; bodach cam ; bodach breallach ; breallach , breallach ban ; turran , turran ort ; dunach ort , dunaidh ort ; losgadh do dhunach ort ; bial sìos ort ; bial bàis ort ; bial seachad ort ; galar fuail ort ; siubhal Mhurchaidh bho ’ n bhothan ; guma h - anamoch dhut ; guma h - éitich dhut ; sgath na nathrach ort ; crois an donais ort ; dos an daoi ( probably = b - d an Donais ) .
[Cf . ON happ , good luck ? ]

tarbh - nathrach .
Male of sand - eel . [Perhaps a mistake for tarbh - shìolag ?
But see tarbh - sìolaig ,
Fr . Allan . tarbh - nathrach usually means a dragonfly . See toradh - neithe ,
Fr . Allan . ]

tarbh - uisge .
See corcach .

tarmachan , tarnachan , tormach , tormachan , tuirmeachan , tuirmean , tuirmeanach , smàchdan [ - à - thus] , smachdaire [no accent] , ian bàn an t - sneachd , gealag , gealag bheinne .
Ptarmigan . [In West Ross tormachan an t - sléibhe ,
TGSI , xxiv , 365 . ]

tarra / torra talamhan .
Shroud , léine bhàis .

tàsg = tabhasg = taibhse .
The bird that comes to foretell death . This bird comes about the dwelling of the dying in the dusk of the evening . He gives trì sgiamhan / sgriachan granda ,
three ugly cries . It is less than the corra - sgriach / sgritheach ,
heron , but bigger than the bòdhag ,
ringed plover . See brollach - bòdhaig . [tathasg ,
Fr . Allan . tàsg ,
a ghost , sprite , TGSI , xxiv , 365 . Cf . E . Ir . tásc , news of a death , fatal tidings . Ge d ’ sheinneadh Tathaisg , ’ s ge d ’ rànadh slèibh ,
G , 159 . ]

tat , tatan .
To attract , draw to one , entice . Tataidh am biadh am fitheach bho ’ n chraoibh ,
food will entice the raven from the tree ; tatan am bleidir ort agus bithidh e oidhche agad ,
encourage the beggar and he will stay the night ; tataidh an long laimrig ghlan ; tatan an cù , tatan ort an cù , tatan dachaigh an cù . Luibh / lus an tataidh ,
see s . v . lus an tàlaidh . [tat ,
Fr . Allan . taiteadh ,
to tame , reconcile to a new home , TGSI , xxii , 40 . ]

tathach .
Visitor , uncanny visitor . tathaich .
Uncanny visiting , ghost frequenting ; the gift which enables one to know about the absent .

an té ruadh .
See an t - sonasag .

teach triubhais .
See triubhas . [Cf . JMC , l . 2542 n . ]

teadhair .
Royal stag . See treadhar . [teadhran ,
royal stag , Dw . ]

teaghail .
See galar tioram .

teaghlach .
See faircill .

tealbh .
See garbhan .

tealpach , tealapach , teileapach , tearrachd .
Bye - name , tee name .

teanacadh , tionacadh , teanachdadh , teannachdadh , teanacsa .
Saining , saving , saving by magic , saving by sorcery , safeguarding , protecting , charming . teanacadh an aodaich / a ’ chlòth ,
charming / consecrating the cloth ( often mistaken for teannachadh ,
tightening ) .

Làir dhubh bhreabach
Feadh nan creagan ,
Làir dhubh bhreabach
Is i ’ na ruith ;
Làn an dùirn de chaora dearga
Am bun a h - earbaill
Chum a teanacadh
Is i ’ na ruith . [See ii , 246 . ]

[teanacsa ,
ii , 369 . tionacadh ,
Fr . Allan , s . v . friochd . teanacadh ,
delivering from danger , warding off anything , TGSI , xxxvii , 36 ; A ’ s co is urrainn teanachdas ,
G , 176 ( glossed : to defend , to save from imminent danger ) ; ghreas iad air an aghaidh g ’ ar teanachdadh ,
T , 40 ; Iad a greisid gu air teanachdse ,
DMcL , 30 ; Sinn ’ gun chuiraidh gu teanachd - sa , / Bheir o bhuilean nan arm sin ,
id . , 241 ; ’ S thug iad ’ uam gus mo theannacs ’ iad ,
UB , 193 ; ’ S nach beireadh tionchds ’ orr ’ a dhianamh feum ,
LG , 104 ( glossed : mercy , salvation , saving power ) ; tionachd m ’ anam dhomh ,
SD , 20 ; thoir thugam teanachdas de bhiadh ,
WHT , ii , 198 ; the following forms occur in DIG ( see ii , 344 ) : teanachds ’ , teanchds , teanacsadh , teancas , teanc - s ’ , teanacaiste , tionchds and the form tionac is quoted . ]

teàrnanaichte .
A hogg of last year ( ? ) [gimmer ? ]

tearrachd .
See tealpach . [tearrachd ,
keen sarcasm , McA . ]

teileapach .
See tealpach .

teilm , teilinn .
A stringed musical instrument . [ii , 369 . Cf . W telyn , harp . ]

teine bruthadair .
The fire upon which witches were burnt . [leg . brathadair ? ]

teine mara .
Sea - fire , phosphorescence . See coill .

teine mór .
See laomachan ; teine tana .

teine sionn .
See coill ; laomachan ; sionn ; teine tana .

teine tana .
Thin light , evanescent light , phosphorescent light , fitfully flitting over the mane of a horse in a calm drizzly night . The writer often saw this light fitfully playing on the mane of his horse when driving across the fords and along the machairs of the Outer Hebrides . The same kind of light is seen on the backs of cattle and upon the udders of cows in the Outer Isles . It is also called teine mór ,
big fire ; teine ghealain ,
flicker fire ; teine ghealachain ,
flickering fire ; teine sionn ,
mystery light ; teine sionnachain ,
mysterious light ; teine a ’ mhadaidh ,
wolf ’ s light ; teine a ’ mhadaidh ruaidh ,
the fire of the russet dog , the fox , i . e . , deceptive fire . [Cf . E . Ir . teine sinnaig applied to the phosphorescence on decayed wood ; see note in Sàr Òrain , p . 70 . ]

teirbheis .
Rump , handle .

teum , teóm .
A handful , ‘ puckle ’ , a small thing , a small gift ; teum bheag mhine ,
a small ‘ puckle ’ of meal . [ii , 371 . In West Ross teum éisg = one fish ; see TGSI , xxiv , 369 . Probably the same word as teum ,
a bite , etc . ]

tiobairt , tiobrat .
A well , spring . Tiobairt and Achadh an Tiobairt at Inveraray ; Tom an Tiobairt at Dalmally ; Tiobartan at Smèaracleit , South Uist ; Tiobart and Blàr an Tiobairt in Knapdale ; Tiobartaich at Ceann Tràgh , Barr Breac . [E . Ir . tipra , gen . tiprat . See CPNS , 504 . ]

tiolpadh .
See taibreadh .

tiomnadh . Air a thiomnadh ,
denied with oaths . [ ? ]

tionacadh .
See teanacadh .

tionnlainn .
A crowd , meeting . [ tional ,
a gathering , assembly ? ]

tiùbadaigh .
See diùbadaigh .

tiumachd , tiumachdas , tiumachasgain .
Gleaning corn . See dìoghlum ; dòman ; iunntachd . [Cf . tiumsachd , tiomsachd ,
collecting ? tiomsachadh ,
Dw . ]

toch .
A pit , underground dwelling , house , home .

tòchd .
Pink in animals . A film grows on the eye of the animal like the cataract on the human eye . A needle or some similar instrument is inserted under the scale and the scale prised off . [tòchd ,
Fr . Allan . an tòc ,
Lewis . ]

tódhradh .
The act of manuring , as with seaweed .

Togarradh an Dóbhrain Duinn .
See Marbhadh na Béiste Duibhe .

tògh .
Fatness , possibly a form of sògh ,
fatness , fat food , rich food . Iarr gach sògh air Camaranach ach na iarr feòil air Camaranach ,
ask every rich food from a Cameron but do not ask meat from a Cameron ; iarr gach nì air Camaranach ach na iarr nì air Camaranach ,
ask everything from a Cameron but do not ask cattle from a Cameron . The Camerons were sometimes called Camaranaich mhór na feòla and Camaranaich bhog an ime .
The Macphersons are called Clann a ’ Phearsainn bhog a ’ bhrochain because they were late for the battle of Culloden by halting to partake of some porridge . The Macphersons justly resent this name as their conduct during the Forty - five , as well as before and since , proves their extreme hardihood and gallantry .

toilleadh a ’ mhuilleir .
See cùileag . [Also toinneamh ,
etc . ]

toirmeasg .
See lach le linn .

toirmeasg .
See tonn .

toiteal .
Cooked dulse — very wholesome . [totan ,
boiled dulse , Fr . Allan . ]

toll - càthaidh .
See càthadh .

tolm .
The thread put upon the sgucha - féithe [sgocha - féithe] , [sprain . ]

tolm , holm , tuilm .
An uninhabited island used for pasture . [ON hólmr , holm , islet . ]

tonn .
Wave , wealth , fortune , prosperity . Cha dànaig tonn air Domhnall bho rinn e am pòsadh luideach .
‘ No wave came upon Donald since he made the luckless marriage . ’ Phòs Mór , mo nighean , eirmisg dhuine , agus cha d ’ éirich tonn tuilleadh air a gnùis ; cha d ’ éirich , cha d ’ éirich , a luaidh , gun do chuir an toirmeasg dhachaigh dh ’ an ùir i .
‘ My daughter , Marion , married a wretch of a man , and a wave never rose on her face again ; never , never , my dear , until the wretch sent her home to the mould . ’ Cha dànaig onn

Old people in the Isles differentiate clearly , as the young people do not , between stuagh and tonn ,
as people on the mainland differentiate between beinn ,
a broad - based peaked mountain , and monadh ,
a peakless mountain . Stuagh is the upstanding crest of the wave immediately before breaking . Tonn is the long - drawn wave heaving and rolling along without breaking . Hence a phrase common in Uist : Cha dànaig tonn tràghaidh air an fhadhail ,
no heave of ebb has come upon the ford . Cha dànaig tonn lìonaidh am Fadhail na Comraich ,
no wave of flood has come in the Ford of the Sanctuary — the sanctuary of the Temple of the Holy Trinity at Carinish , North Uist . [tonn ,
Fr . Allan . ]

tonnag = guailleachan .
A plaid , generally of tartan , occasionally of iomairt ( q . v . ) , worn round the shoulders of women , fastened in front with a brooch of bone , bronze , copper , silver or gold ; it may range from a yard to a yard and a half in length and from half a yard to a yard in width . Pretty , picturesque and comfortable . [See tunnag , infra . Cf . E . Ir . tuinech , tonach , coat , mantle , covering , L tunica . ]

topan [also toban , taban , tuban] . Tuft , the tuft of wool or of tow or of lint on the rock and from which the thread is spun . Topan gòraig air cuigeal crìonaig ,
the tuft of silly on the rock of wise .

A girl who had lost her mother and had not been taught calanas ,
wool working , married . Her mother - in - law and sisters - in - law twitted and taunted the young wife that she could not do calanas and the young wife grieved sorely . When her husband lay asleep she lay awake sorrowing that she could not card and spin and weave . Then the dead mother of the girl came to her and soothingly said while drying her tears , ‘ Weep not , thou my beloved child , and I will teach thee calanas ’
—

Cuir làmh an t - sniamh air an topan ,
Làmh an tuigein air an t - sniamh ,
’ S mar a chrimeas a ’ chaor an toman
Dèan - s ’ a chomain air an t - sniamh .

The kind words of her dead mother inspired the girl with hope and courage and she set to work in good earnest at calanas ,
retiring to rest with the benediction of Mary ’ s lark and rising again with the first crow of the old cock . Before the young wife had become a mother she had made tartans and plaidings and blankets for her husband such as he had never had before .

toradh . Essence , substance , fruitage . Occurs frequently in the occult science and beliefs of the people . A woman reputed guilty of spiriting away the toradh ,
substance , from milk or from meal or from any food

product whatsoever was publicly rebuked upon the knoll , cnoc ,
in presence of three witnesses . When this was done the toradh was restored and there was no further action . See cuibhreachan . [ii , 319 , 334 . See caoibhreachan ; mulchag Bhealltainn ,
Fr . Allan . ]

tòradh .
Run , yard , enclosure , a thing that surrounds another thing ; tòradh a ’ chruidh ,
cattle enclosure ; tòradh an teampaill ,
the temple enclosure ; tòradh an duine ,
the circumference of the man . [Cf . Ir . teóra , O . Ir . tórand , marking off , delimitation ; O ’ Rahilly , SGS , ii , 16 . ]

torc - sona .
Bird of luck . [See Campbell , Superstitions , 99 . Rud anns a robh cumail ris / seasamh fada , chante : ‘ A chiall , ’ s ann ann a bha ’ n torc - sona . ’
— Ness , Lewis . ]

tormach , tormachan .
See tarmachan .

torrag .
See sorrag .

tortach .
Powerful . As in the Urnaigh Oidhche ,
Night Prayer :

Tha mi ag cur m ’ anama ’ s mo chorp
Fo do chomraich , a Thrianaid thortaich thréin ,
An Triùir bhith dham dhìon ’ s dham thearmad a nochd ,
Athair agus Mac agus Spiorad sèimh .
[E . Ir . toirtech , bulky . ]

trachailt , trachailte .
Trouble ; as thug a ’ ghriùrach móran trachailt as ,
the measles took much out of him . [Cf . trachladh , treachladh ,
fatigue ; Fhuair a treachladh le h - eirbheirt ,
S , 408 ; Sc . trachle ,
draggle , fatiguing exertion . ]

tràigh .
See cladach .

traoghag , straoghag .
Straw when drawn and combed out . See brat ; sreathainn . [straothag ,
bed of straw in a kiln on which to lay corn when being dried , Dw . ]

trataran - tréan .
See treòn .

tràthach , tràghach = goineir , goineir mara .
Crested dog ’ s tail , a grass which prevails among potatoes and is extremely apt to propagate and hard to kill out . See lòban ; sunnadan . [tràthach ,
long sweet meadow grass , Fr . Allan . ]

treach .
Dig . treachadh .
Digging . treachlaireachd .
Digging away . treachaire .
Digger .

A chléirich a ’ treachaid an uaigh , [sic
Càirich Conn cruaidh ri m ’ thaobh ,
Càirich Ailne eadar mo dhà làimh ,
A chléirich àidh , càirich rium Aodh . [chàidh ,
holy ?
Thou cleric digging the [ ? in a] grave , place hard Conn by my side , place Ailne between my two hands , thou cleric of grace , place Aodh beside me .

[treachailt ,
to dig , Fr . Allan . Cf . Gus ’ n do threachailte uaigh dha ,
T , 22 ; ’ N àm bhith treachailt na h - uaghach ,
DSG , 50 ; ’ Nam an uaigh bhi ga trechailt ,

GB , i , 23 ; Ged a threachail sin uaigh dhuit ,
id . , ii , 106 ; ’ N am ’ bhi ’ treachailt na h - uaghach ,
id . , 117 ; Biodh an uaigh air a treachaid ,
UB , 159 ( air a treach ’ ladh ,
S , 393 ) ; An àm treachladh na h - uaighe ,
LG , 135 ; N ’ am bhi treabhailt na h ’ uaighach ,
E , 278 . Considered in Uist to be the right word for digging a grave ; not cladhach .
E . Ir . trechlad , act of loosing , separating ; trechal ,
act of digging . ]

treacha , tracha .
Trench , pass , gorge , gully ; tracha also = gullet , windpipe . [ L trachia , trachea ? ; trach ,
ditch , Dw . ]

treadhar , treaghar , treaghair .
A royal stag . See teadhair .

tréan - ri - tréan .
See treòn .

treapag .
See tripleag .

treòdag .
A cloak , mantle .

Nall mo thonnag / threòdag ,
Nall mo bhrat / bhat ’ ,
Nall mo bhràiste
Feuch an déid mi mach .

treòn , treòna , treònachan .
Corncrake ( Uist ) ; tréan - ri - tréan ( Lismore ) ; trian - ri - trian ( Lochaber ) ; trataran - tréan ( Lorne ) ; bramach ( an ) - roid ( Perthshire ) ; rac - an - fheòir ( Glenelg ) . The bird comes in summer and goes in winter and is sianta ,
sained or sacred ; a man who kills it dies , a man who knocks feathers out of it becomes ill . [dreóghann ,
Fr . Allan . tradhn ,
Ness , Lewis . E . Ir . tragna , tradna , tradnach , traona , corncrake . ]

treonal .
Crowd , group . treonal bhan ,
group of women ; treonal chon ,
a pack of dogs . [According to the late Mr Duncan MacDonald , South Uist , the word is trional . Treonal is perhaps due to a misreading of the MS . See v , 132 . ]
treothad [leg . treabhad ? ] ; spang ( q . v . ) . Green stubble .

trian .
Share , part , portion . làn - trian ,
full share , full portion , the whole portion . This phrase is akin to làn leth - dusain ,
full half dozen , which means seven . làn dusan means fourteen . Mór leth - dhusan and mór dusan ,
big half dozen and big dozen , mean the same . [Cf . E . Ir . mórfeser = seven persons . For trian see SGS , vi , 21 f . rian ,
Fr . Allan . ]

trian - ri - trian .
See treòn .

trì - bhliadhnach .
See isean .

trìleach .
Trouble , fight , squabble . [See Gloss . to JMC ; E . Ir . trírech , trilling of birds . trinnleach ,
Fr . Allan . ]

trìlleach . [ ] in winter ; gulmag in summer . The bird changes its colour in summer . Cf . gudaboc . [trinnleachan ,
Fr . Allan . ]

trine .
See giuthas coinnil .

trinnse .
A trench . trinnseadh , trinnsigeadh [trainnsigeadh , Lewis] . Act of trenching or delving . [truinnse ,
the sluice of a mill dam , Fr . Allan . trainnse ,
pl . trainnsichean ,
trench ( in 1914 - 18 War ) , Lewis . ]

trioc , triochd , triochdadh .
Save , rescue , protect ( Kintail ) . [Cf . friochd ,
Fr . Allan ? ]
triogh [also triuthach] . Hooping cough . [E . Ir . trichem , cough , paroxysm , fit ; trichmech , fit of coughing . ]

tripleag , treapag .
A fairy spell . Chuir an t - sìdheag tripleag ( treapag ) ort ,
the fairy woman has put a spell on thee .

triubhas .
See brigis . Cumadh an Triubhais :
trogail [ - ò - ? ] . Disease , sickness , complaint .

trogal .
A hut , hovel . trogal taighe ,
a hut of a house ; trogal muice ,
the hovel of a pig .

troilis , troilisg .
Disorder . [troileis ,
any trifling thing , childish merriment , Dw . Cf . roileis , supra ? troileasg , rolasg ,
Fr . Allan . ]

tromach air thorach , truimeach air thearrach .
See bromach air tharrach .

trotag - thràghad , ceard - tràghad , bòthag , bòdhag .
Shore - pipit . [The meaning ringed plover is deleted . ] See brollach - bòdhaig .

truillich .
Travelling , journeying . [Cf . truidhleach ,
lumber , baggage , Dw ? ]

trusdar .
See baobach .

tuathal .
See càrn .

tuigean , tuigein , tuigeanach .
Small , fine , slender , from taog ,
slender . [See topan . taog is a thin part in a thread of worsted ; also gaog ,
see Fr . Allan . Cf . Cha robh pluc no meall no gaog ann ,
DB , l . 2050 . ]

tuil .
A flood ; tuiltean na Lùnasdail ,
the Lammas floods , in the first twelve days of autumn .

tuirmeachan , tuirmean , tuirmeanach .
See tarmachan .

tùirneis .
The egg - game on Easter Monday [sic] . Di - domhanich Tùirneis , Di - domhnaich na Tùirneis , Domhnach Tùirneis , Domhnach na Tùirneis ,
was a day of much excitement . It was the Sunday after Easter Sunday [Low Sunday] . In Uist children used to play with hard - boiled eggs . They rolled them down a slope and watched their course for omens .

[Cf . toirnéis , toirtéis , noise , commotion , RIA Contrr . According to Dinneen Domhnach na Tóirnéise is Palm Sunday , and Fr . Allan , s . v . tùrnais ,
agrees with this . He says that the egg feast was kept in Uist on Palm Sunday and not on Easter Sunday . Henderson , who equates it with Di - domhnaich Crom Dubh ,
makes it the last Sunday in July , Gaelic Dialects , ZCP , iv , 269 ; but a verse quoted in NGP , 167 , makes it seem likely that Di - domhnaich Crom Dubh meant Easter Sunday . ]

tunnag .
A shawl . [See tonnag . ]

tur .
Drought , dryness , lacking moisture , lacking something , as tur tombaca ,
dearth of tobacco ; tur éisg ,
want of fish ; tur dibhe ,
lack of drink .

Is iad muinntir a ’ bhaile seo thall
Clannd as dona ’ san domhan ,
Salach seideagach sodalach sannt ,
Loireagach ladhragach ludagach lothan , [lobhach ?
Daoine gun tùr gun toinisg gun taing ,
Daoine daobhaidh daochaidh dona ,
Tur air a ’ bhaile seo thall —
A Chalainn a nall an seo .
— From Dugald MacDonald , Tiree .

The people of yonder townland are people the worst in the world , dirty filthy flattering avaricious , swampy footling little toy hounds [sic ; bedraggled , bare - footed , slovenly , ( ? ) stinking] , people void of sense , void of gratitude , people ugly [frightful] ill - hued [perverse] , wicked , drought upon yonder townland — the Noel over here [let the Hogmanay revellers come over here] .

tur ( adj . ) . Dry . tìr tur ,
dry land ; aran tur ,
dry bread [bread without any butter or condiment] ; turadh ,
dry weather , cessation of rain . Tha an dialtag ’ na siubhal / a muigh , bios turadh ann a màireach ,
the bat is abroad , it will be dry tomorrow .

Mo ghille dubh , mo ghille dubh ,
Mo ghille dubh , mo laochan ,
Cha dugainn fhéin an t - aran tur
Dham ghille dhubh nam faodainn .

Mo ghille dubh , mo ghille dubh ,
Mo ghille dubh , mo ghaoilean ,
Mo ghille dubh ri cabhadh cuir [am bun an t - sruth
’ S tu muigh ag cur nan caoiltean .

turasg .
Saw , cutsaw . [tuireasg ,
Dw . ; E . Ir . tuiresc , tuiresg . ]

turbaid .
Turbot . The people of Berneray , Barra , will neither eat the turbot nor name it at sea . I have seen the turbot rotting on the rocks in Berneray — no one would touch them . They ate and eat the less delicate halibut . It is the same among the old people of Orkney and Shetland . [It used to be the same in Lewis . ]

turma .
Quantity , measure . [Probably = tuaiream . ]

turran .
See tapag .

turran , turraran .
See durraran .

tùrsairean . [Stitchwort . ] It is good for at bràghad ,
swelling of breast .

tuthag .
See suthag .

uainisg .
A sallow girl or woman . Also uiniseag , uainiseag , uinisgeag . uinisgean , uainisgean .
A sallow - faced , green - complexioned man .

uanallach .
Lamb ’ s wool . marbhalach .
Wool from sheep killed or which had died of braxy , etc . garannach , garralach .
Wool clipped or pulled by hand barr - feall [ - pheall ? ] .
Old wool on the top of new wool . fionndarlach . Wool from anus and between the legs of sheep ; also applied to a youth with a thin straggling beard . [See marbharnach , supra . In Ness , Lewis , marbhannach ,
also bearranach . marbhanach ,
Fr . Allan . marbhchann , marbhtach ; earrannach ,
Dw . garralach and uanallach are cpds . of ollach ( olann ,
wool ) , i . e . , garbh + ollach and uan + ollach . ]

uarad .
See cambar .

ùbartach .
Proud , haughty , dignified .

uchd . uchd na h - oidhche ,
near morning , later than bial na h - oidhche . Nochd agus uchd [ ? ] . [The sequence is ( 1 ) bial ,
( 2 ) druim ,
( 3 ) uchd — na h - oidhche . ]

ùdlach [ùdlaiche] .
A stag that goes alone in autumn . [Air uiltacha cabrach na ’ n croic ,
E , 284 ; Dh fhagadh ùltach gu ’ n anam ,
id . , 344 ; Air Utluich an langain ,
G , 77 ; B ’ e sud udlich ’ na maise ,
GB , ii , 109 . ON útlagi , outlaw . ]

uilein , uirlein .
Orphan , fatherless child . [Cf . uilleagan ,
a spoilt child , Ness , Lewis ? ] Cf . uitlean , infra .

uiniseag , uinisgeag , uinisgean .
See uainisg .

uiridh .
A bed , a couch , a ledge in a cliff , in some places called snìomh , sniamh suaineach .
Cf . palla . [E . Ir . airide , a high seat , dais . ]

uisge .
See bùrn .

uitlean .
Orphan ; child that has no apparent father . [uitbhlean ,
orphan ( Skye ) , Dw . ] Cf . uilein , supra .

urachal .
Cross - fetter on an animal . Cf . langais . [urchail ,
fetters , chains , Dw ; urchall ,
fetters , shackles , McB . airchaill , fetter , chain , Contrr . ]

ùraisg .
See tamhasg .

urra ,
pl . urrachan .
Used in Uist = leanabh ,
child . Rug i urra ( Uist ) = Rug i leanabh ( Lismore ) . [urra ,
Fr . Allan . In the meaning of child urr ’ òg or urra chloinneadh ( Fr . Allan ) ; also urra bheag .
Cf . Deirdre , 2nd ed . , p . 18 . ]

urracag .
A jerk . Urracag eile null gu Ceileagraidh , urracag orrach [fhorrach] null gu Stròmaidh ( two islands in the Sound of Harris ) . This is said when swinging children . [Somewhat similar is : Tulgadh null gu eilean Iosaidh / Far na rinn Mac Leòid a dhìnneir .
See also MC , 32 . ]

urrachd .
Ill , bedraggled appearance .

ur - reotha .
See dubh - reotha .

urradh .
Place , position . Anns an urradh air a ’ chléibh ,
in the place upon the wattle [i . e . , upon the wattle partition wall] .

uthar .
Any sore , any lionn . [= othar ,
abscess , ulcer , ailment , Dw . E . Ir . othar , uthar , sickness , illness . Dh ’ fhag uthar fui ’ m ’ lèinidh / Nach fothair lèigh tha air thalamh ,
E , 52 . See also Dw , s . v . leann . ]

ùtraid .
By - road , cattle road . See crath . [ ON útreið , riding out ? ]

Fairy ,
Faoileann , Feannag , Fionnach .
Niosag [Niosgag ? ] .

Seileidh , Sgiamhach , Sgianach , Sgitheanach , Siolach , Siubhal , Siubhlach , Sléibhteach , Smeòrach , Snaoiseach , Sonasag , Speach [Spéach ? ] , Stàbhan , Suaineag , Subhach , Subhachag , Sunnais .
